number of helpful: 11 of 13 people (85%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 1, 2014
												If you were ever a fan of the old games, make no mistake, this is a perfect sequel for the franchise.Having grown up playing the first three Age of Wonders games, it's hard to say in words exactly how excited I was in the lead up to this game coming out. I was worried in part by how it seemed as if your class defined the vast majority of your army but, having finally gotten the chance to play, all my fears from watching the previews have been quenched. This game feels exactly like AoW2/SM in all the right ways; next to nothing was removed mechanically and the new class and neutral city systems are simply additions, not replacements, to the old ways and they blend in perfectly.While it seems weird to review a game less than a day after having first played it, you should understand that I am the kind of gamer who will play a game I adore for only an hour per day when I'm "into it" and yet, with AoW3, I haven't been able to put it down. The sense of adventure and discovery I've found playing this game is unmatched, though I admit I'm looking at it through rose-coloured glasses. It really feels like a fresh take on the series, and the genre as a whole, without seeming too attached or too spiteful towards its predecessors.It is not a flawless game by any means. I've found numerous graphic and sound bugs in the time I've been playing with some battle map terrain acquiring a strobe effect and a few attack sound effects simply missing in the ether. The map generator is still somewhat flawed, leaving a suspicious trail of grass along the edges of some maps and awkwardly placing patches of water in giant lava pools. My first encounter with an NPC in a match had me face to face with the character I had just created minutes before and was currently playing, turning the war into what looked more like bickering twins. These issues to hinder on the immersion quite a bit and hopefully they will be patched in time but it's never enough to make the game any less fun. What DOES make the game less fun is how suicidal the AI is when trying to rely on auto-combat, which is mostly a problem in multiplayer as not using auto-combat takes up a lot of time from everyone involved.Tactical combat is, in my opinion, far more intricate and engaging as any of the older titles. The simple addition of the flanking and defending mechanic, as well as the reworking of the accuracy systems, was enough to vastly increase the depth of the combat but the sheer number of new units and abilities added on top of what we're already used to is almost overwhelming and it makes combat much more surprising, adaptive and satisfying.The reworked city system is a rather significant departure from the originals and is what leads many to believe it's taken too much inspiration from Civilization. Having played Civ 5 to death as well, I can say the change does feel more in line with Civilization than the previous Age of Wonders games but it's very unintrusive and comes with a purpose. Now you have to be careful about where and how you place your cities because their growth (and, by extension, they effectiveness) is inhibated by whatever borders surround them and the structures nearby have significant rewards attached whereas, in the older games, you would place cities as close as possible because more cities just meant more gold, no more thought involved. Here, cities hold a much more strategic purpose and can lead to epic battles fought over one mostly unimpressive city just because it has a structure you want in its domain. It's exciting and thought provoking and feels natural in the evolution of the series.Overall, I love this game. I don't think it's an easy game to get into but it's clearly a game made with their fans in mind and is completely unapologetic about that. If you ever felt the other Age of Wonders game appealed to you before, chances are you will love this new installment. As a child of the AoW era, I can honestly say this has turned out to be everything I have hoped for for the past 11 years.

content:
Posted: June 22, 2016
												This game has the best combat system out of all the 4x games I have played. Rather than watching your army play an attacking animation against the enemy on the map like in most 4x games, you are transported to a seperate battle map. In this battle are the units of the attacking army, the defending army, and any adjacent armies, for a total of up to 42 units. There are lots of unique units with unique spells and abilities. The combat is very strategic, you have to think about how you position your units to flank your enemy and not leave them vulnerable to be flanked by the enemy.The empire building isn't as in-depth as other 4x games though. This game is focused more on your hero, whom you can level up and acquire new armor, weapons, spells and abilities for. You can also recruit other heros to join you. This is one of my favourite 4x games and I would highly recommend it if you are looking for one with a more engaging combat system than most other 4x games.

												A wonderful game!This is what Heroes of Might and Magic 5,6 and 7 should have been like! Clearly developed to beat these titles and it succeeds I think!Essentially Age of Wonders III is HOM&M but with far superior combat, tactics, spells, heroes and troop development.The graphics are as good as later HOM&M titles but the 3D used here seems to work so much better than HOM&M I feel, the interface is also more intuitive. The one small issue with it is that the maps, at least in the Scenario's, do not seem quite as heavy on resources and independant enemies as HOM&M games but I guess this is because the game is trying to break away slightly here.I will also say, it's HARD! I like this but was continually getting my backside kicked until I realise how much effect terrain variations had on different troops types! I love this and it really distinguishes it from HOM&M games where morale was a simple mechanism. AOWIII brilliantly bridges the gap between HOM&M and a more traditional squad/unit-based wargame.Think of a cross between HOM&M and Warhammer and you are just about there :)

content:
Posted: April 7, 2014
												****Edit on Feb 2015****Purchased and played Golden Realm DLC...ExcellentPro 's-3 part Campaign with storyboard and voice acting, extra gametypes, leaders, units, etc.-Game seems much more balanced and only crashed once on a custom scenario.Con's-I use to be able to host internet games but now you get a connectivity rating and if it is poor you are   not allowed to host game although you can still join them.  (Nothing in my hardware setup has changed, so one of the later game patches must have implemented this.)-though they have done balancing to the game, I still found myself having to reload ingame saves while playing on the easiest skill level.In all I'm moving my rating up to a 9.April 7 2014My review for the 4x, fantasy genre, strategy game called Age of Wonders III.   I had high hopes for this title, as these types of games seem to be few and far between, especially when it come to the game raising the bar and setting a standard for its genre.  I wasn't disappointed at all.  Lets break it down:Graphics: 8 Graphics had lots of detail, varied terrain types and meshes that blended well. Music/Sound Effects/Voice acting 8.5Had a great musical score, character acting was top notch, sound effects and environmentals were good too.Controls 8Controls are actually good.  Small issue with some poorly placed, floating info boxes that interfere with selection choices for hero skills. Gamplay 8This could have been so much higher.  The good part is content: 2 campaigns, each with 2 different endings.  I have put about 50 hours into the first campaign finishing off both endings.  With still another campaign left, it seems there is alot of content to keep you immersed.  The game also features a multiplayer/co op multiplay option (and it aint "hotseat").  You can now finally battle it out, with or against your friends, in a 4x game turnbased strategy game.  The bad part is there are some issues.  I started the campaign on normal difficulty and after two or three maps I had to change the setting to easy.  On easy settings it got just as difficult and impossible to complete the last 2 maps without dying a couple dozen times and having to reload the game.  Multiplayer also has issue, infrequent game hangs, and the more frequent friend dropped from game issue.  However, the game allows you to continue with an ai friend or save the game and reload and have your friend rejoin.  Nothing gamebreaking, just a minor annoyance.Overall 8Final thoughtsTriumph Studio was very attentive and  helpful with any issues on launch day.  There are obvious issues that they have noted and promised a quick patch for.  I take it as a good sign if they start pumping out patches before DLC for their game.  There are also gamers who feel the game lacks customization of units or this and that.  I personally feel we have been flooded with sandbox type games, and it has become an expectation that we should be able to create our own game, with the game you give us.  You can create your own custom hero and there is a map maker/editor I have yet to mess with.  With all this to consider, the game doesn't lack, but as any game, can always be improved upon.  Let Triumph get on with the bug fixing, and be patient for the additional content that they promise to work on and deliver.  The game is complete as is and will most likely go down in history as a "classic".

content:
Posted: April 19, 2015
												A fantastic strategy game that will appeal to anyone who loves the genre. The game is a 4X similar to Civilization and Master of Magic, but it takes heavy cues from Heroes of Might and Magic in that the world is littered with goodies thrown about to plunder and neutral enemies guarding them, as well as customisable hero units that you can recruit and level. The best thing about it though, is the tactical battle system. This is nothing new, as Master of Magic, Heroes of Might and Magic, as well as the original Age of Wonders games, all did this a long time ago, but here it feels so refined. Terrain has a big impact, units have cool active and passive abilities, and the strategic choices that you make in battle all feel meaningful. On top of this, the game has great variety. Not only do you have a selection of races to choose, all with their own tech trees and units, but you also have character classes and traits to choose for your leader. Your leader's class and traits will determing what extra special units you can produce, as well as the spells you have access to. The combination of both race and class makes mixing and matching fun to do, and allows you to have much more variety if you get bored of a certain setup, yet still like certain elements of your previous games. The expansions are absolutely worth it if you enjoy the game already. The Necromancer class added by Eternal Lords is amazingly fun, and plays entirely differently than the other classes, with a much more agressive play style that emphasises growing your cities and armies through combat. Over all, Age of Wonders III is one of the best in the genre to date.

content:
Posted: May 8, 2015
												Age of Wonders III is already a very in depth and well made title. With Eternal Lords thrown into the mix. It just seems even better. This title has a laundry list of features, game modes, and more. Going through all the aspects of the game will take you easily more then a hundred hours to fully assimilate. To break it down, Age of Wonders III is a mixture of Civ meets Masters of Magic. You will bring your spell-flinging champion into the fray against other champion leaders. The empire aspects compliment your hero. This 4X title has more of a focus on individual heroes and tactical combat. Ordering your troops around the map isn't enough in this title. You must command them in battle as well. While the combat is optional, to fully experience this title I would suggest it. Simply put Age of Wonders III: Eternal Lords is an impressive accomplishment. For such a small studio. Graphics, music, and design are all top notch here. The only true complaint one could form is the price. While it can be a bit pricey. You will be playing one map for hundreds of turns and then there is there multiplayer, The level editor, and more. Bang for your buck is guaranteed. number of helpful: 7 of 7 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 28, 2015
												This game is great. I really like that the developers chose the right path, they not only did not move towards contraction but instead they actually introduced lots of new features into the game, which was very risky in the first place, knowing how conservative are fans in such games like AOW, Disciples and HMM. But in reality, compared to Heroes of Might and Magic and especially Disciples, which both went the wrong direction, this game is a masterpiece.The new added features make the game different on the one hand, but also more interesting. I do not want to compare this game to Age of Wonders II, which of course is a living classics, but I can tell that this game has set the bar very high. This is obvious when you look at everything - the picture is amazing, it creates an impression of a beautiful fantasy world - very often I stopped the game in order to look at the map, take a look at the river, mountains, forests, and to look at how my pocket kingdom is doing. The music is great, altough I always consider the Age of Wonders II contained the best soundtrack of all times in games, the compositions of Michiel van den Bos are very powerful, and are used when they are actually needed, very often giving an additional inspiration in difficult battles.I think the best argument which summarizes overall impression of the game is that there is always a wish to let the game go even when the map is already won. This is paradoxical on the one hand, because each map takes very long time to beat, but it was always a part of Age of Wonders gameplay, and compared to the previous games, in my opinion, it feels way faster. There are always so many things to do, do some research, build more buildings, recruit more units, build improvements, and to build new cities... So sometimes I regret that there is no single unified map like it is in Civilization, where you could develop a huge Empire and allow it to stand the test of time - this is perhaps the only bad thing about this game.8.5 / 10

content:
Posted: June 21, 2016
												I wish I knew about this game sooner. It incorporates features from Civilization, Total War, and XCOM in a turn-based format.=========================================Pros:I'm just playing single-player so far, but I'm loving the RPG elements of leveling your leader and troops.You can research spells which you can use to cast spells in combat (buffing troops, damaging enemies, etc), or cast spells outside of combat (damaging enemy armies, buffing your cities, etc.)Sieges are well done as far as giving the defender a big advantage, but still making siege weapons useful. Not enough games use these mechanics properly.Each race has it's own pros and cons, and each leader has their own spells and stats, some of which you can influence when they level up. There is a custom leader creator as well which is pretty cool.Great value. Got this game on a -66% Steam sale, absolutely worth the price. Only bought the base game, but in the first hour realized I would enjoy it enough to buy the whole package.=============================================ConsThere is a lot of micro-management, but it's turn-based and similar to Civilization. So if Civ was overwhelming, this may not be the game for you.Battles can be a little tedious because you move and attack with every unit. Also most units have their own spells and ranks, so it's not too horrible. I'm not disliking combat yet, but I can see where some might. There is an auto-resolve option like Total War though.Edit for multiplayer review; highly not recommended. You have to watch every battle as other players complete their battles. There is auto-resolve, but this game is all about tactical battles and it's unplayable like that. However, there is play-by-email and that works fine, so if you don't mind doing that, then it's do-able. Really disappointing, but it's because of gameplay balance. =================================================All in all, if you enjoy Civilization, XCOM, or Total War, then you would probably enjoy this game.Also, that guy who has 100 hours played and still didn't recommend this game, stop being so entitled. That's a great value.

content:
Posted: April 2, 2014
												At the writing of this review I have just finished one random map on normal difficulty. I had a lot of fun with this game but there are a few things you should know before buying it.This game excel with its tactical combats and it does it very well.  And the game is developed as a war game and the developers made this game around this concept, and you should accept this game as it is, a war game, where you need to carefully maneuver your units on a battle field behind covers, flanking enemies, exploiting enemy's weakness (elemental, armour, speed etc), and the game does it really well, and the ai is also very well done which employ a variety of tactics and is challenging even on normal.Now about what this game isn't. It is not a sophisticated empire builder like Civilization. In fact, because the game is so build around the tactical combats, the designers want you to intelligently maneuver your troops tactically, that you simply cannot win by strategic planning alone. There are no super units that you can simply steam roll through your foes. There are no super spells that will wipe out an entire stack of enemy on the tactical map. It is even hard to win by economy alone because even with one city you can produce a quite powerful army, on standard map the resources are so aboundant that you simply cannot starve a city out.Some people criticize the game because it is not what they expected, a fantasy Civilization game, and you should accept this game as it is, a very well done tactical war game. I really love the presentation of this game, both the visual arts and music are full of imagination and epic. I did encounter a few freezes although they are relatively rare. I hope you enjoy this game as much as I do.

content:
Posted: April 20, 2015
												This game is a true spiritual successor to Age of Wonders 2 and Shadow Magic that manages to remain true to and enhance on many things that make Shadow Magic such a timeless classic. One great improvement is the new and improved custom wizard creator, which allows you to make really interesting custom characters and save them to use or play against. One of the big changes is the addition of a class system, each wizard chooses one of seven classes, and some of the classes take over the function of some of the old races (Dark Elves, Undead, Archons, Nomads), for example, Rogues build Shadows and Succubi and can do so for any race, and Necromancers can summon or build a lot of the iconic Undead units, as well as ghoul forms of normal racial units.Each of the seven Wizard Classes contain a variety of unique units and spells and can provide unique upgrades to their armies, each of the nine races has several unique units and a few generic units and can build class units for any class that commands them, in addition wizards can choose from several masteries similar to Spheres of Magic in AoW2 and Shadow Magic, each of which have their own spells and upgrades.Now with the recent surge of mods, it's also possible to customize your experience beyond what normal options allow, with mods that range from allowing custom wizards to wear any armor with any class, to more custom colors for wizards, to more powerful terraforming spells.The game has a slightly greater focus on Hero Units than Shadow Magic did, but that can also be configured in settings if you don't like it. However your wizard doesn't have to sit around in a tower and will gain levels like heroes so it's usually a good idea to take it into fights. The Building Selection is mostly just like in AoW 2 with the main focus of the game remaining on exploration and combat. Patches have added buildings based on resources within a city's domain with a variety of effects, such as unlocking special units, or increasing research speeds. A racial governance system has also been added that allows you to select one of two race wide bonuses with each upgrade.The Diplomacy system is improved in many ways over Age of Wonders 2, but compared to games like Civilization 3 it still falls short, it's impossible to threaten and coerce other Wizards, and the AI is usually unwilling to participate in diplomacy unless it fully sets the terms.There are a variety of game modes, including Play by Email. It's possible to play single player, and to my understanding local host multiplayer without creating a Triumph account, so it's not DRM, but be advised that in order to access all of the achievements and some multiplayer modes you may need to create an online account for some of the multiplayer. Multiplayer probably isn't the main reason you'd want to buy this anyway, but it's worth mentioning.Overall, I can't recommend this game enough, it's my all time favorite game,

number of helpful: 40 of 70 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 11, 2014
												Age of Wonders III is an charming game but has too much cut and/or unfinished content to recommend, especially to fans of the older titles in this series, both which were filled to the brim with atmosphere.THE GOOD:- MusicInvigorating tunes that spur you on while you play, great remixes of old tracks while adding in a few new ones as well. Most are of great quality but due to the length of some instances (late-game world map micro-managing or lengthy battle sequences with large armies), the themes can seem to reoccur too often too quickly.- Gameplay (Leader vurnability)While defeat could come easily in Age of Wonder 1 when your leader died to a stray spell, Age of Wonders II made them too persistant with next turn revives and respawning at any city with a Wizard's Tower. Age of wonders 3 perfects this balance by granting the leader some form of revival but at a decent cost. All in all: Leaders are neither vurnable nor near-unkillable like they were in previous games, striking the perfect balance where all tactics can be considered during play to eliminate your opponent.THE BAD:- GraphicsWhile city-scapes during sieges can look amazing and army units are decent enough, there are equal as unpolished or plain bad textures as well. The leaders & heroes are the main offenders here: hair, beards and sometimes armor clipping or looking translucent, clothes or armor clipping through mounts,... Customizing your own leader has been expanded upon graphically, which I can only commend but the sore lack of extensive options makes this but a tiny timewaster rather than anything worthwhile. I confess, this is far more important in an RPG than it is in a TBS, but it looks half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥nonetheless (example: No skin-tone for Dark Elves whilst the High Elves race is a mixture of both Wood Elves & Dark Elves). Furthermore, while some ingame items equipped to these heroes show up on their avatar and thus offers a nice nod to detail, other items do nothing of the sort. In my opinion, either do all or none of the items lest you create the notion you hadn't the time to bother with them all.Some flying units have issues as well when fighting over lava or water. If the unit in question has an idle stance where it lands itself until ordered, it gets submerged nearly completely in said lava or water. Creating another idle animation when fighting over water or lava could have provided a solution here, as of now it just gnaws at the player's experience.- ContentAge of Wonders 1 had 12 playable races, Age of Wonders 2 had 15 playable races (12 in the original, 3 extra in the expansion), Age of Wonders 3 has 6 of these races. Not only a major plunge in what you can play, but all units feel much the same with different skins. Although each races varies slightly from the standard template (Dwarves have 1 extra defense & resistance but cost 10% more gold to recruit, Orcs suffers -1 ranged damage yet gain +1 melee damage, etc...), none feel as diverse as they were in previous games. While some units do have unique abilities (Elf Unicorn Riders pack the Phase-ability, unique to them), their stats are nearly equal apart from their racial modifier! To me, the varied stats seemed to have a far greater impact in previous installments, contributing to each race's unique style. The only units I currently feel that make a unique impact over its peers are the Orc Greatsword and the Elf Gryphon Rider due to enhanced stats or extra abilities.Next comes the story, spoiler tag inserted:Even though they try to take the story into a new direction, this game only contains 6 or 7 missions per campaign to explain it. Aside from being utterly uninspired with an ending that just oozes: BUY OUR EXPANSION SINCE THIS RESOLVES NOTHING; all of these missions fall into the same tedious category of: "Build a base from scratch against overwhelming enemy numbers who rarely do anything and sit there until you grind them piece by piece into a pulp." The last and fifth mission of the Elven campaign are notorious for this in my book. Aside from a few skirmishes into your terrain, they'll just wait until you come to besiege them. A few secrets here and there spruce up the lot, but they are far too minor to sit through hours & hours of same old empire building & grinding the foe to a pulp. Since nearly every mission is played with a different leader as well, don't count on transfering your researched spells over into the next scenario like you did in Age of Wonders 2! In my opinion, endless padding. The only plus was that it forced you to play with many of the classes the game has to offer, daring players to test all it has to offer, albeit not that much. - MultiplayerAs many posts on the Age of Wonder III tech support website indicates, a tremendous amount of players is having issues even making a connection to other players. I had this same issue until I disabled my McAfee software, the ONLY game I must do this for in order to play it online even when adding said game to the exceptions list. Even though the game forwards ports automaticly in the hopes to get a connection going for the owner, I still feel this is a nuissance that could have been avoided or handled in a better way than just stating "Your router must cause the issue, call your providers to sort it out!".When you're finally able to get this mode to work, the only feasible tactic to win the game under an hour is to rush your opponent to oblivion. I've played multiple team sessions and Free-For-Alls, all ended in either two scenario's. A: as stated before, players rushed eachother with their starting stack and hoped to have randomly received a summoning spell at the start of the game in order to crush their foe, quiting if they lost too many units along the way. B: People played passively for an hour and then quit the game due to a lack of intrest. In short: Play with friends so you can extend the game past the hour mark or fight it out until the bitter end. There is nothing satisfying about games ending abruptly because one felt it didn't go his or her way.VERDICT:I wanted this game to be good, I truly wished for this as I am a long-time fan of the series. I adored the previous games but with all the issues & disappointments I've encountered here, I cannot urge others to buy, let alone play it. A few more months to expand the content provided would have made this game a worthy addition but for me in its current state: It falls short.I've probably missed a few things here & there, but I hope my review helped you decide if this game is worth your time & money.

content:
Posted: June 1, 2014
												Age of Wonders 3 is a 4X turn based strategy game, with a fantasy setting. I haven't played the previous games in the series, and I'm not the most knowledgeable gamer when it comes to this genre as a whole. I've played a couple of games each in the Civilization and Total War franchises but not much else. In my non-expert view, AoW3 is a pretty good game, and I've had some fun with it.Most concepts will be familiar to anyone who ever played a similar game. Expand your empire by creating cities, construct buildings to improve things like economy and production, research new technologies, train armies, move them around the world map and then take direct control on the battlefield.AoW3 has a strong emphasis on combat, in fact every victory condition (at least in the campaign mode) is related to conquering your enemies, Total War style. There's no equivalent of Civ's peaceful victory conditions, however if you can create a diplomatic alliance with another faction, you are allowed to win together.This isn't necessarily a complaint, because I like AoW3's battle system. The world map is divided into a hex grid, and each army stack can hold up to 6 units. When you attack, all the units in that hex and the 6 surrounding hexes, will be included in the battle. So the positioning of your armies becomes vital, and with a little tactical planning you can create a numerical advantage before the battle even begins.The battlefield is where the game really comes to life for me, because of the fantasy theme. I love RPGs, so I really enjoyed the use of magic spells and supernatural creatures. There's an amazing variety of units in this game. Of course you've got the standard melee, cavalry and archer units, which function pretty much the same whether they are Human, Elf or Dwarf. But then you can have dragons that fly over castle walls, giants that just bash those walls down, unicorns can teleport behind an enemy, succubus can seduce an enemy to fight for you ... and so much more.Your generals can cast spells to damage or stun the enemy, buff or heal your troops. They can equip loot, better weapons, armour and rings for passive buffs or resistance to elemental damage. They can gain XP and level up where once again, there are dozens of abilities to choose from.The enemy AI is easily the best I've seen in this genre. Playing on normal difficulty, I was frequently punished for my mistakes. If I leave a city undefended, the enemy will capture it. I actually learned the importance of flanking the enemy for bonus damage, by watching the AI constantly doing it to me.This is also the first strategy game that I've played that has a scripted story. Elves and Humans are at war, you can play as either side, and each chapter takes place on a different map. The story branches half way through based on a decision made by the player, and leads to one of three different endings. Dialogue is a mixture of voiced and text. And I must mention that the music is fantastic.It took me 52 hours to complete one side of the campaign. Some of that is because I screwed up the later missions so badly that I had to restart the map and try a different tactic, but still, its long enough to make a full price purchase easily worth it. During all that time I don't recall noticing any bugs (unless you count Goblin Beetle riders ;)).

content:
Posted: January 30, 2016
												TL;DR: If you like a fantasy-themed, combat focused, round based X4 go get it. It's a very good game. The Golden Realms and Eternal Lords DLC are highly recommended as well.When I say this a combat focused X4 I mean it - this game is probably focused mostly on the eXpand and eXterminate aspects of the X4 genre. Don't expect any deep dipomacy or city building aspect, it mainly focuses on expanding your empire and overthrowing your enemy. While the addons add additional victory conditions, still the focus is mainly on combat, however it does this very well with an insane amount of depth.Battles are extremly strategic. Positioning and composition of your units matter a lot. Units can be flanked for extra damage, many units retaliate (fight back in melee) if they are attacked, or they do attacks of oppurnity on enemies that run past them. Ranged attacks deal damage depending on range and line of sight. Many units have active abilities often also reflecting the choice in your class (like dreadnaught class, for example engineers class units can reload other class units like cannons or muskeets that could otherwise only fire every two tactical rounds, all units only available to that class).The whole element setup and unit-ability plays a huge role as well. If you defend your city with all archers (which deal physical damage) vs units that have high protection against physical damage, you'll have a hard time if you win at all. Casting spells here might save the day, since they could give your units elemental damage or lower the enemy resistance.Obviously you want to mix up your units so that you a good chance of winning over attackers. When attacking a walled city, you probably want some way to finish off the defeners on the wall, either with spells or possibly with flying units or with units that can climb the walls. Or you choose to simply destroy the walls and then move in. Instead you use units who don't get a penality when shooting up the walls and simply shoot the defenders down. .Cons:* AI, while probably the best I've faced in a RBS 4X so far, suffers from the same problem that it can get rather predictable after a while * End-game can be boring (usually turns into a steamroll/spam fest)* Diplomacy is very basic* Town management, while substantially improved with Golden Realms expansion, is rather basicPros:* runs very smooth (on my system)* visually fitting for the theme and overall very appealing* story and lore is integrated into the game and the classes/units feel very thematic* good music* game includes character customization for your heros* single player campaign while short is pretty good* random maps have a decent amount of settings to customize* AI is compared to other games very capable and can pose a threat (though of course, for a seasoned player you'll figure AI exploits eventually)* modding toolkit/support* classes play very differently and have their own flavour* races also play somewhat differently and come with their own flavour (and strengths/weaknesses)* specalizations allow you to further customize your playstyle* spell castingFantastic:* the class/race/specalization combinations make things highly varied (in particular to games like civ)* RPG deeply integrated - units can level up, the game contains hero which are fully levelable complete with skills and equipment (which can also be found in encounters on the map as well as crafted in cities)* tactical combat - this makes it possible to have very deep and tactical battles that can take a while. Unit placement, unit abilities, spell, everything matters

number of helpful: 7 of 8 people (88%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 11, 2014
												Pretty much all about the warmongering.Age of Wonders 3 is very much a niche title, even within the 4x game, however, it covers that one niche really well. It's a game about combat, and everything, from the UI, to the city building, to diplomacy itself is entirely in service to the engine of war that this game runs on. Cities are built to build and fund more soldiers. Spells and techs are researched to give an edge in battle or allow you to get more soldiers to bring into battle. Heroes are recruited and trained and killed in the name of war. And they will die, because death comes fast.The game's selection of Races offer little more than stat changes for your units, granting passives and and a few advantages/disadvantages here and there. Elves have better archers, but are weak to poisons. Goblins have poorer stats, but massive innate poison resist. It's not too important, but definately does shift how you play. As elves, you'll snipe from max range often. As draconians, you won't care much about non-lethal incoming damage.Classes, namely leader class, determines far more, from your tech tree to your unique units, taking much of what is traditionally race based in other, less warmongering 4x games. Rogues get access to demons, stealth spells, and plenty of tricks to force enemy cities into open revolt. Theocrats tithe for gold like it's going out of style. Dreadnoughts cover massive areas in fiery death with warmachines that outright immune poison and holy damage, but lack counter-attack ability.Combat is suprisingly quick, due to units being able to destroy eachother in short order. Even levelled heroes are able to be struck down by a few first tier archers focusing fire. As such, mistakes get punished hard.The game has great customization for the genre, letting you tailor your tech tree, your character and diplomacy screen appearance, hero growth, and make custom equipment to fit the situation.In summary: I wholeheartedly suggest picking this game up if you're like me and your games of GalCiv2 or Civ V regularly decend into "If it moves, kill it.". Age of Wonders 3 simply does warmongering so much better, even if it comes at the cost of alternative victory conditions.

content:
Posted: March 31, 2014
												This game is the♥♥♥♥♥♥right there. No need to say it, but it took the best of AoW 1 and AoW 2, mashed it together and improved the rest of the game. The soundtrack is also a nice nostalgia trip for me too.But a few things need some improvement.-Needs incentives for having an alignment, some design decisions are ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. You raze a city. You get evil points for it. You settle the ruins of the city. You gain good points for it. It's a ♥♥♥♥ing city that you pillaged to the ground, wiped out their inhabitants and settled the ruins again with your own people. It shouldn't be more 'beneficial' than outright settling the city with members of your own race. It's like rubbing salt on someone's festering wound. How the ♥♥♥♥ would you gain good points for it? Just rebuilding the ruins of the city after you looted and pillaged that city to the ground? -Late game is a whole cluster♥♥♥♥. Everything plays the same way. Above all else, it was fun and I'm just waiting for the inevitable Necromancer DLC. Been dying to try it out to get a feel of it.It's planned that the game would be a lot more moddable than it is. So I'm looking forward to that!

number of helpful: 8 of 10 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 1, 2014
												    A fantastic sequel that improves upon an already classic game. Anyone who enjoyed the original Age of Wonders installments would be doing themselves a disservice by ignoring this game. Improved combat (balancing, animation, visuals), Improved heroes (fewer objectively correct leveling choices, more interesting abilities), Improved main character (you are actually encouraged to use him as an aggressive unit now), Improved low level units (basic ranged units are actually worth while now, flanking allows low level melee units to maintain some relevance later in the game) and fantastic overland map rich with detail and a fantastic cloth world map ala Elemental/Fallen Enchantress. The fact that Triumph chose to keep hotseat multiplayer in the game means that it will likely have a place on my hard-drive for years to come.    The only things that I feel could be added to the game are more races, classes, units and spells...but who doesn't want that in any game thats enjoyable. Well done Triumph, I look forward to see what advancements you have in store for this very solid foundation.

number of helpful: 8 of 10 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 8, 2015
												I've played a variety of 4X games and I can say, undoubdelty, this is the ONE for me.I like Civ, don't get me wrong, Civ is a pretty amazing game, but it was way too focused on nation interrelations, diplomacy and "player versus player" experience, as in, you'll be battling and dealing with the big AI (the other players in the game) rather than the environment AI (in the case of civ, barbarians)I also played Fallen Enchantress, but the art didn't quite charm me.This game combines what I loved from FE (exploration, variety of AI enemies, more "player versus environment" focused) with an incredibly beautiful artstyle, amazing soundtrack and a much more fleshed out singleplayer campaign. Highly recommended for any fan of strategy games, be it 4X, grand or tactics.

content:
Posted: March 31, 2014
												When I saw this was coming out I was really nervous.  Because Disciples 3 exists, and ubisoft has made heroes unplayable with their terrible launcher ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t.I bought it anyways, because AoW has always been fantastic.  Then I opened it for the first time and...oh god, a login screen.  Fortunately before commiting ritual suicide I noticed a play as guest option.  Okay fine.  There's a launcher, but you -DO NOT HAVE TO USE IT.-  Phew, one bullet dodged, sort of.Get in game, looks nice.  Music is good.  Music...sounds familiar.  Hmmmmmmmm.  Start a campaign.  I'm ecstatic to see they use the same style of opening sequences as the previous games, and they use them to do a quick recap of the previous lore.  This isn't a reboot or anything?  Sweet.  The voice acting is good so far, huge bonus.  So I start a campaign and pretty quickly you get into your first fight.  And then, holy♥♥♥♥♥♥ Battle Macabre starts playing.  It's not exactly the same, but it's damn close.And then 7 hours have passed and you have no idea what happened.The music is really great.The combat is fun, very much what you'd expect from AoW.No disciples 3 ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t.  Launcher service is optional.If you like TBS and/or any previous Age of Wonders then this is a must buy.

number of helpful: 11 of 16 people (69%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 31, 2014
												When I was young I played the original Age of Wonders to death. As i got older I still played it and it became one of my most beloved games. Now while I do have a biased point of view I will tell you this : AOW3 Feels so much like the original is frightening. It seems like Triumph decided to start with the original and flesh out what was good and shave off the bad. I feel that they did a fantastic job making this game exactly what it should be. The overall gameplay makes you think that its a CIV knockoff but after playig it for some time I realized that its just similar, nothing more. I like the overall feel of the game and the only complaint I had was that the screen scrolling seemed quite clunky.I truly think they did a great job making the combat system emulate the original while giving it a unique feel that makes you want more. I'm excited that they kept commander (or leaders) in the game which nearly makes the game a turn based RPG. One of the best additions to this sequel is the ability to create a random map. While random maps are pretty standard now (or should be honestly) it brings a breath of longevity to the game.If you enjoy turn based stragety games that are fun and have dynamic combat this is the game for you. I truly think you'll spend hours enjoying this game and exploring or conquering your own world!

number of helpful: 8 of 10 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 6, 2015
												This entry is a fantastic --albeit different-- return to the series. If you want a turn-based high-fantasy strategy game, look no further than AoW.However, I can say without a flinch that if you wanted to truly enjoy Age of Wonders, you should start with the earlier games. As good as this game is, it's nowhere near earlier instalments. No, this is not nostalgia kicking in, I'm actually playing Age of Wonders: Shadow Magic right now, and it has more races, more units (some will tell you AoW 3 has more units, but they'll omit the fact that a decent portion of them are literal copy-pastes).The old games stick to a recognized lore, so you literally will not see Angel Goblins (I'm not kidding, they're called "exalted".. the struggle is real), Elvish trolls ("Warbreeds"), and other ridiculous units.Bottom of line, this game is great for what it is, an attempt to revive a highly praised franchise, and although it falls short in many ways, it is still a good game for all it's worth. Fans of AoW will definitely like this entry, while newcomers may shy away from the bizarre setup.Plus, the developers are really trying to appease everyone, and they're constantly supporting and updating the game. They can literally cash in and make a new game with all the updates and DLC they've done, but they chose to support this already existing game. Triumph is no big studio, so this says a lot.Thank you Triumph, this is a good game. Although, we're still hoping for an SM-tier entry. :-)

number of helpful: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 24, 2014
												This game is CIV 5 but with magic and more movement. Also has little skirmishes whenever you fight something, unlike CIV (You zoom into a little battle, which is entirely identical to DnD but digital). Less focused on economy and city management, more focused on combat, which is perfect for me. If you liked Civ but wanted more combat, buy this. Graphics are lovely, slightly more optomised than CIV. There are "Heros" which act as leaders, have extra spells and get an inventory in which to store loot (you get loot from raiding tombs, dungeons and ruins. Such as a musket, a staff, armour or a necklace). Theres a leveling system for all units, so fight with them and they increase in potency, which makes a good deal of effect on combat. There are parts of the game that you breese through, and some that you just get wrecked. Unlike Civ, cities dont fight for themselves, you need to put normal units in them, and any sieges against them are fought by them, with a wall being the advantage given to the defenders. All in all, its a great game. £30 is a bit steep, so you might want to wait for a sale, anything over 10% off would seem like a decent deal to me.

number of helpful: 43 of 77 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 23, 2015
												I have mixed feelings on this game.   Ill start by saying that I own all the previous AOW games and have played them through many times and also multiplayer.1. A number of downgraded changes were made from aow 1-2 in the area of gameplay, seemingly in favor of better graphics.2. The sound tracks from the older versions were better, IMO.   Plus the lack of a customizable playlist that existed in all other AOW games bothered me.   I had asked a dev if they could implement the customized playlist like the older games have and they did say they would see if it could be done...3. The change from 8 units to 6 units per army...  I cant say I liked that.   It made the combat less diverse tactical. They ought to have increased to 10.  But this was probably done because of the more intense graphics and in battle animations/particle effects wouldnt allow for good framerates.  More units in a battle would probably make it unplayable except for the best PC's.3. Flying or floating units are no different than any other now.  Basically a unit with wings doesnt actually fly anymore.  I understand why they changed it, but they didnt have to.4. There is a very steep power curve between the different teirs in aow3.  Too steep.  Any lesser units are basically useless later.  In AOW1-2 even a tier 1 unit still had a chance to survive vs a tier 4.  Now? no way.  The power gap is too much, and you only get 6 units per army.  If you could have more it would be economical to bring more cheap units to a battle and only a few expensive ones.  5. The heroes in aow3 are somewhat weaker.  Your armor and resists have a negligible effect.  And your heroes are heavily targeted.  They are most just for show and spellcasting but cant really fight very well.  In aow1-2, your heroes really were heroes.  In this game they are wall flowers...6.  Every time your units get attacked they turn to face the attacker, after the fact. This facing change that happens every time a unit is hit is really dumb.  Your units can be attacked from the rear several times because of it, and it really makes your heroes feel useless when it happens to them and enemies always seem to focus on your heroes too.7. Castle and tower walls are just graphics now.  They are pretty useless for slowing down the attackers and several times I felt that playing defence behind a wall was actually detrimental and did little to stop attacking forces.  In this regard I feel like a good defensive strategy is a moot point.  In aow 1 and 2, seiging a walled city or tower was pretty difficult, as it should be.  You had to build and bring siege weapons in order to get past walls.  There were not many unit types that could climb or fly over walls.  And you needed ranged attacks or your own flying units(or magic/spider webs/druid entangle and other - such diversity that was stripped from aow3...) to deal with flying units. AoW3 just has too may ways for units to circumvent or destroy the walls too quickly and easily. Its like the walls and gates arent even there.  Also in aow1-2 cities had a number of magicaI defenses you could unlock and build.  It really made sieging a city quite an ordeal.  I resorted to using the auto battle instead of torturing myself....8. Magic domains in aow 3 are also another moot point now.  Your leader should not be able to use any magic outside it like it was in aow 1-2.  I feel like this magic domain mechanic is anti AOW, which has always been about wizards and their towers and domains and their armies being powerless outside of them unless the leader or hero was physically present.If you never played an AOW game before, these flaws probably wont be noticable and you might like it.But if your like me, the differences and dumbed down mechanics from aow1-2 will make you not enjoy this game as much as the originals and possibly even regret buyng it.  Ive tried playing through the campaigns twice now, and the story is interesting, but the dumbed down gameplay turns me off and I get tired of it.

number of helpful: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 6
Short description: for the TL.DR people.   Age of Wonders III is a sequel to the series, having not played the previous I can’t compare it to them. Though the game has a bit of Civilization, Heroes: Might and Magic and some RPG like elements.    What I mean by those is that the game lets you create the empire/leader you wish to have those include:ClassSpeciesGenderTraits   These materials help creates your empire and leader on how you wish to conquer each Age of Wonders III world maps that can also be customizable from how many treasures and mobs to how much of kind of terrain. Even if the World Map is mostly a Vulcanic place but you want to whole world to be Frozen you can do that if your traits correspond to being able to make the lands arctic.    If the world is corrupted you can cleanse it which will put you on the Good Alignment making it easier to be friends with people of the same Alignment, but that also means those that are on the Evil Alignment are going to be your enemies of course.Game Story:   At the start of the game you can either go into Singleplayer Story or Singleplayer Skirmish, the latter means you make up a story as the game proceeds with the Empire and Character you’ve created or chose from a preset before starting the Skirmish.    Now the 1st kind has you choosing from 2Vanilla(“The Elven Court” & “The Commonwealth”) stories and 2DLC(“Eternal Lords” & “Golden Realms”) based stories each unique in its own way and each having a story to tell and show you a world of wonders (pun intended)Scale:GreatGoodDecentNot badBadNopeGame: GoodGraphic: GoodSound: GoodAnimation: GoodAI: DecentGameplay: GoodModding: DecentClarifying the scale:- Graphics    Graphically speaking the game is good to be honest, visually aesthetic and pleasing to look at for longer periods of time well I suppose that depends what kind of Empire you chose to be being an Arctic Empire and staring at the white abyss can be rather too much for people that don’t like that look. Then again you wouldn’t be playing with that if you didn’t like it, each kind of Empire has their own unique look depending on how they chose their traits to be. A Druid will have a very green area filled with forests where as a Necromancer will have a very barren and desolate maybe even corrupted land.    The micro-manage battles look very good when using spells or sending soldiers to fight, those same or other magics that are Empire-wide or World-wide will also have a visible effect in some cases that looks nice. - Sound    The sound is only good because I’ve had a few times where my sound was bugging out and that can be annoying, but other than that the sound is great and as a good fidelity when you take an Archer Unit and order it to shoot at a Machine Unit (usually made of metal/wood) you can hear the arrows hitting that metal/wood. What I mean is that it’s not the same sound for every landing attack.- AI    The AI of the game acts corresponding to their traits and alignment and so far, I have had no issues with the AI doing something out of the ordinary like they would in a Civilization game. Now it is only on Decent because there are some aspects of the AI that could’ve been done better, like if a Good Alignment AI is good that I would expect them to cleanse the land a bit more or an Evil Alignment AI would corrupt.    It could of course also be that I haven’t played enough to be able to see that develop and since I’ve always been either an Arctic or Temperate Empire I would’ve reshaped the land per my own traits.- Gameplay     Gameplay wise the game is easy to understand and get into, although I am still having an issue with combat mechanics, but that’s mostly due to my part of not doing much combat in the game. Other than that, the gameplay is well done, research is required to do anything in the game but if you focus like a maniac on knowledge like I’ve always done you learn everything so fast that by the time I am in mid game I have all the spells, buildings etc. that are within my traits.    An awesome mechanic I’ve liked in the game that besides being able to craft your own gear for your heroes/leader you can also do World Quests well they are called Empire but since all Empires participate I find it more appropriate to call them that World Quests.    Each one of those has a goal and a reward the first Empire to complete that goal will receive a reward it can be anything from a Unit to an Empire-wide buff.There are so many more things I could be saying in this clarification of the Gameplay, but I will leave that for discovery, I am just giving a “small preview”.- Modding The area is Decent because I’ve looked at some of the mods in the workshop and they look good, but I’ve never personally tried mods in this game since I’ve still yet to finish all the achievements and stories of the game so before that I will stay away from mods.Conclusion: for the TL.DR people   This game to me at least is a gem in the rough and worth picking up it’s not often I find a game that I like the style of just by looking at it, this one was one of them and I had it on my Wishlist for a while before I decide to say best way to find out if I like it is to try it and I did and I liked it.   If you like(d) Heroes: Might and Magic series, Civilization series and/or you want some RPG elements in your RTS/TBS games like say being able to decide what kind of leader to have or what kind traits you want you Empire to have and can specify then this is something you should at least consider it. Speaking from my own point of view, it was not time wasted it was everything I liked put into one game.

												It's barely even beleivable how good this is, just a masterclass in every category. Get this if you don't have Civ V, or even if you do. content:
Posted: October 3, 2015
												I can't think of many better ways to spend an entire Saturday afternoon.PROS:+ World strategy!+ Fantastic and tactically rewarding battles+ Challenging AI+ Very enjoyable single-player campaigns+ Lots of map customization+ No tedious empire management+ Unique yet balanced races and units+ Varied units and heros that level+ Unit weaknesses and strengths+ Powerful spells and research options+ Wonderful graphics and music!CONS:- Lacks alternate victory conditions (expand and conquer pretty much)- What end game? It can be a chore once in "clean-up mode"CONCLUSION:An overall wonderful gaming experience that so far, hasn't lost it's charm. If you like fantasy and 4x games, then you'll likely enjoy countless hours of ignoring the real world in favor of this one.Cheers!

What I mean is that it’s not the same sound for every landing attack.- AI    The AI of the game acts corresponding to their traits and alignment and so far, I have had no issues with the AI doing something out of the ordinary like they would in a Civilization game. Now it is only on Decent because there are some aspects of the AI that could’ve been done better, like if a Good Alignment AI is good that I would expect them to cleanse the land a bit more or an Evil Alignment AI would corrupt.    It could of course also be that I haven’t played enough to be able to see that develop and since I’ve always been either an Arctic or Temperate Empire I would’ve reshaped the land per my own traits.- Gameplay     Gameplay wise the game is easy to understand and get into, although I am still having an issue with combat mechanics, but that’s mostly due to my part of not doing much combat in the game. Other than that, the gameplay is well done, research is required to do anything in the game but if you focus like a maniac on knowledge like I’ve always done you learn everything so fast that by the time I am in mid game I have all the spells, buildings etc. that are within my traits.    An awesome mechanic I’ve liked in the game that besides being able to craft your own gear for your heroes/leader you can also do World Quests well they are called Empire but since all Empires participate I find it more appropriate to call them that World Quests.    Each one of those has a goal and a reward the first Empire to complete that goal will receive a reward it can be anything from a Unit to an Empire-wide buff.There are so many more things I could be saying in this clarification of the Gameplay, but I will leave that for discovery, I am just giving a “small preview”.- Modding The area is Decent because I’ve looked at some of the mods in the workshop and they look good, but I’ve never personally tried mods in this game since I’ve still yet to finish all the achievements and stories of the game so before that I will stay away from mods.Conclusion: for the TL.DR people   This game to me at least is a gem in the rough and worth picking up it’s not often I find a game that I like the style of just by looking at it, this one was one of them and I had it on my Wishlist for a while before I decide to say best way to find out if I like it is to try it and I did and I liked it.   If you like(d) Heroes: Might and Magic series, Civilization series and/or you want some RPG elements in your RTS/TBS games like say being able to decide what kind of leader to have or what kind traits you want you Empire to have and can specify then this is something you should at least consider it. Speaking from my own point of view, it was not time wasted it was everything I liked put into one game.

												This game is brilliant.  If you're looking for a fantasy 4x with a military/tactics focus, this game takes the cake. 												Domination is the name of the game, and luckily this game does that very well. If you are looking for complex building or research options, vast diplomacy networks and interactions.. then this is not the game for you. But if you are looking for fantastic, highly tactical turn-based combat in a good fantasy setting then Age of Wonders 3 is going to satisfy your needs. The strategic map has great detail and a real sense of atmosphere (the music certainly helps out a lot in this endeavor), and there are plenty of combat maps that have a beautiful layout. Unfortunately, siege maps lack variation (you will be fighting on these the most) but beyond that this game does conquest incredibly well. Classes feel distinct and allow you to focus on your own playstyle, maps offer a lot of freedom and with two decent campaigns, scenarios and a good random map generator there is plenty for you to try out. content:
Posted: December 27, 2016
												Age of Wonders 3 is not a game like Civilizations. They share things in common but the troop lineup is ripped straight from typical RTS games. AoW3 is a turn-based RTS complete with base building, buying stables to produce cavalry, buffing the units with upgrades and tech research (which takes time to build just as it does in an RTS) and spamming your favorite units across the map as early as possible.You'll explore tons of treasure sites, find optimal places to build a new base, and wrack up tons of experience and artifacts for your heroes. In that sense it's a competitive PVE game since optional autobattles and economy management can make the game about who has the stronger army as opposed to the smarter tactics. Units move extremely fast across the map unlike Civ and you can have your enemy's army invisible and at your doorstep without warning. Hope you left some defenders or you just lost your capital.Base rushing, expansion, tech research, build order, unit synergy, all important RTS elements and brought here for your amusement. Spy on the enemy with scouts to find out what he's building then build the perfect counter units that are essentially invincible against that type of enemy. Best part is that if you play for a VERY long time you will eventually get access to every race in the game by conquering neutral cities. So you can design your ideal endgame army and semi-reliably get it every game as long as you explored enough to find the right cities.If you played Heroes of Might and Magic then you know the drill.  Awesome game!

												Pretty alright for what it sets out to do. It's like Heroes of Might & Magic meets Civilization meets a big bag of crack cocaine. Great visuals and aesthetics. Combat is fun; a lot of depth lies in unit choice to compose units but actual combat feels insultingly shallow with most abilities being 'damage enemy' or 'heal ally'. Balance can be fairly topsy-turvy with most strategies being 'spam the ♥♥♥♥ out of your biggest units and butt♥♥♥♥ the enemy'. AI and Diplomacy need serious work -- very, very serious work. When your diplomacy system is actually worse than Civ 5 BNW's, you have an issue. All in all 8/10; you'll get anywhere from 10 to 40 hours out of it.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 24, 2014
												In Short:PROS: -great gameplay -high replayability -very good multiplayer -easy to get into, hard to master -low price -frequent updates (it looks this way so far)-good balance-a lot of customization-nice graphics-beautiful musicCons:-relatively long games (not for the genre)-not that many people playing multiplayer-rather bad tutorial-not the most challenging AI (for veterans of the genre)This game is a steal! I bought my steam digital download version for 75PLN (about $25) and if you look online you can by it this cheap pretty much anywhere in the world. For this price you get a brand new game with 2 campaigns, each with 6 missions + 1 for alternative choices made. I would say this is easily 40 hours of gameplay, at least. Then you also have scenarios and endless possibilities with random map generator.The game is complex, but easier to get into than the likes of Europa Universalis, Total War, or even Civilization series. At the same time it offers plenty to more seasoned TBS and 4X players. It's different than almost anything else on the market. People compare this game to HoM&M, Civ, and Total War, but while it includes elements of all these games, it's still something totally different.If you enjoy 4X games, you should definitely try it. If you like TBSs in general you might want to give it a go. If all HoM&M titles after HoM&M 3 (and maybe 4) disappointed you, buy this game!For anyone who likes Civ, Gal Civ, HoM&M series this should be a definitve buy. People who like Paradox games should also consider it.The random map generator in this game is like nothing I have ever seen before. The number of options is mind blowing. You can customize the number of cities, their size, number of treasures, resource, visit structures, starting army sizes, and much more.There's plenty of strategy involved and enough variety to keep you playing for many hours. 6 classes, 6 races, and 14 specializations to choose from means you get to try out new things almost every game.And finally, the multiplayer. I don't know how 4X games could have existed without simultaneous turns. I used to play some with classic turns and it was a thrill, but it also dragged on way too long and I would never play with strangers for this very reason. Here you can start a small map 1 vs 1 game with smallest starting cities and medium armies and finish it in about half an hour, it that's your cup of tee. You can still play epic large map games with mutiple opponents and save your sessions, in this case too, the simultaneous turns option will vastly speed up the game. I was worried about using this over the classic turns, but it works like a charm, I use it even against the AI, there's hardly any reason not to.Buy this game! Even if you have never played 4X games before. This is a good game for beginners too and at this price it is worth giving it a go. The support for the game is amazing, the forums are very helpful and best of all there is more content to come in the form of dlcs and expansions, which are likely to feature new playable races, new scenarios, and maybe new campaigns

content:
Posted: April 3, 2014
												An excellent tactical wargame. It plays like a combination of Might & Magic and Civilization, however it differs significantly from the both of them.First off: do not be fooled, Civilization fans. If you're looking for a fantasy equivalent of Civilization, this isn't going to perfectly scratch that itch. While it does have highly customizable kingdoms (with races and themes to pick from - steampunk elves and druidic dwarves are both possible, for example), the kingdoms themselves serve no purpose except to produce combat units. There is no need to improve tiles, and while civilization happiness is a factor, it's generally not an issue unless enemy empires start using magic to lower happiness within your cities. The biggest thing that hampers it from being 'fantasy Civ' however, is that there is no tech tree and there are no victory conditions other than to defeat your enemies, or attempt to form an Alliance between them.That said, if you were the sort of Civilization player who preferred scrapping with barbarian tribes and winning the game through domination of your enemies, this game may actually end up being a better alternative. It plays similarly to Civilization V, but it is entirely a wargame. It provides roaming bands of monsters to fight, and small dungeons to explore with your army and recover magical items to equip your heroes with. The independant cities (this game's version of City-States from Civ V) provide quests which can give magical item rewards, and can even reward you with joining your empire, giving you access to unique units such as fey and giants.The game turns into a Might & Magic-esque tactical RPG when in combat, providing a large grid with terrain to utilize for cover and flanking. Might & Magic players should be happy with what is provided here, though they should keep in mind that battlefields are typically much larger than the chessboard-esque M&M battlefields. Army sizes are also typically much smaller, with most engagements having no more than six units on either side. Only city battles can exceed this limit.I highly recommend this game to M&M fans, fans of tactical RPGs, and fans of Civilization who enjoy the Domination victory condition. However, Civ players who enjoy nonviolent victory conditions should look elsewhere.

content:

												A good game to start with! but the DLC? ITS A FANTASTIC GAME! Age of wonders 3 is a 4x game crossed with an rpg. the lead your armys with your hero equiping new gear and leveling up, through dungeons or simply all out war. you can of course take the peaceful approach and build up your empire.WAR IS THE BEST OPTION (in the base game).The dlcs add more options for peace, aswell as new ways to build your economy and eventually be come a deity for a race. or become their worst night mare! Before each game you must choose : race, class, and speciallisations.RACE-like any rpg each races has areas they like to live in and different perks.CLASS-decides your perks, late-game units, spells, and upgrades each class counters another class.SPECIALLISATIONS-you can choose 3, they add different spells and sometimes units-each one has a different affects on playstyles. some encourage being good others evil but most neutral.in terms of empire bulding it IS a bit simple,but dlc DO improve with more options for building your cities. you get more buildings based off of what in in your territory.All in all tho its a great game! sure war will be likely be inevatible, but you can win by becoming a deity of several races and building a beacan of peace. there are options for lots of different playstyles!. Play it now! choose your lord! find your own path! may it be peace or a bloody war-path cutting down cities like they were grass.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 12, 2016
												Undeniably one of the best Turn Based Strategy games and a true sequel to its estabilished franchise while at the same displaying a lot of maturity with its newly introduced mechanics.Age of Wonders 3 takes the best of all its predecessors and builds upon them instead of shoving new gimmicks in hopes of keeping things interesting. Its' reverence towards estabilished concepts is notable, instantly bringing out front what best characterizes the series: Epic battles between powerful personas in a high fantasy world. Those familiar with the series will delight in seeing the familiar towers in elvish cities and the armies of halfling pony riders charging across the fields.Its combat phase is greatly improved by increasing the units' presence in the battlefield with the added Guard stance and flanking abilities, giving the player much control on how his units will play their part on the battles. Even with the humongous number of abilities that each unit has all of them are finely interwoven with the estabilished systems of attack, defense and morale. The reduction of uncertainess that previous games had also opened venues to dozens of other tactics and created a wonderful balance between all units. No one strategy is unbeatable.What shortcomings this game had after launch have been fixed with balance updates and the expansions, all due to carefully listening and considering the feedback given by the community. Triumph Studios sets the example by truly creating and caring for its masterpiece in the fashion all other studios can only hope to be inspired by. They deserve all the recognition they can get.

content:
Posted: May 12, 2014
												Pretty alright for what it sets out to do. It's like Heroes of Might & Magic meets Civilization meets a big bag of crack cocaine. Great visuals and aesthetics. Combat is fun; a lot of depth lies in unit choice to compose units but actual combat feels insultingly shallow with most abilities being 'damage enemy' or 'heal ally'. Empire building is quite fun, the exploration aspect is wonderful, the hero level-up is fairly detailed. The create-a-character could use more options but it's par. The sounds, music, etc is good. Balance can be fairly topsy-turvy with most strategies being 'spam the ♥♥♥♥ out of your biggest units and butt♥♥♥♥ the enemy'. AI and Diplomacy need serious work -- very, very serious work. When your diplomacy system is actually worse than Civ 5 BNW's, you have an issue. All in all 8/10; you'll get anywhere from 10 to 40 hours out of it.

content:
Posted: June 12, 2016
												Undeniably one of the best Turn Based Strategy games and a true sequel to its estabilished franchise while at the same displaying a lot of maturity with its newly introduced mechanics.Age of Wonders 3 takes the best of all its predecessors and builds upon them instead of shoving new gimmicks in hopes of keeping things interesting. Its' reverence towards estabilished concepts is notable, instantly bringing out front what best characterizes the series: Epic battles between powerful personas in a high fantasy world. Those familiar with the series will delight in seeing the familiar towers in elvish cities and the armies of halfling pony riders charging across the fields.Its combat phase is greatly improved by increasing the units' presence in the battlefield with the added Guard stance and flanking abilities, giving the player much control on how his units will play their part on the battles. Even with the humongous number of abilities that each unit has all of them are finely interwoven with the estabilished systems of attack, defense and morale. The reduction of uncertainess that previous games had also opened venues to dozens of other tactics and created a wonderful balance between all units. No one strategy is unbeatable.What shortcomings this game had after launch have been fixed with balance updates and the expansions, all due to carefully listening and considering the feedback given by the community. Triumph Studios sets the example by truly creating and caring for its masterpiece in the fashion all other studios can only hope to be inspired by. They deserve all the recognition they can get.

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 18, 2015
												Age of Wonders III is my favourite strategy game for a couple of simple reasons:1: it has the best tactical combat.2: it has great strategic play, where you need to decide what your priorities are and when to engage.3: the whole is greater than the parts. The strategic and tactical parts of the game complement each other greatly.This game is focused on strategy and combat. Everything relates to that, from empire building to leveling your heroes. But don't be afraid, it may be a lot of combat all the time, but the combat is deep enough to be different every time. The game's classes offer you many distinct flavours on how you run your empire, on what kind of army you build, on how your strategies play out. Some classes are more mobile, some classes are better at annoying others, some classes are better at simply building up. The difference does not lie in whether they have units to wage war with, the difference lies in how strong those units are, how they reinforce your armies, how your spells reinforce your armies and wether the class is better at direct battles or sneaking past the front lines.A bit about empire building: this game is not civilization. The way you develop your cities is not based on what research you unlock and there are NOT a hundred different buildings to choose from. Instead, your building decisions are based on what units you want to unlock, what resources you need more of and how many units you need right NOW. At first, empire building will seem simple compared to other 4x games, but it ties in very well with the other parts of the game.Dislaimer: I am a total fanboy. I've been part of closed beta testing and met the developers.Warning: This game has ruined tactical role playing games for me. It has ruined other strategy game tactical combat for me. I find those boring just because I'm used to AoWIII.

content:
Posted: July 10, 2014
												I played AOW2 frequently in my younger years. Though it has fewer races, there is a greater variety in leaders. So far I'm greatly enjoying the game. Between the Leaders and Races there are 36 combonations to choose from. Thats not even factoring in the spheres of magic.One warning. This game will murder your time. Not in an honorable way either. Most games murder your time face-to-face. Letting you know that it is slipping away. With this game, it waits until your time is asleep then smothers it with a pillow. You never see it coming. You look at the clock and it says 12:00, you look after what you feel is two hours and it still says 12:00. A closer look shows that it went from PM to AM. I bought a copy for my friend so he could experience time travel too.

												I am... Bitterly dissapointed in many aspects of the game, having come from a group that used to LAN this game quite often. Mostly this is because they have overhauled the wizard/player setup and the research tree into abominations (but there are other things, like how armies are 6 stack, instead of 8 from the previous). There are also a few persistant bugs that still need to be fixed (some units on huge maps sometimes don't renew their movement points after turns are set, and a few other somewhat minor things).I've put in some 130+ hours or so on it already, and I see myself putting more into it. The campaign isn't really all that in my opinion, but I never played this series primarily for the campaign. If you can get 3 or more friends (and half a day) to play with you on a small-medium map, this game is great. If you can get them to play multiple sessions, going on a larger map is better.That being said, I can't help but say that while it is only worth getting the game while it is on sale, it IS worth getting eventually. Especially if you can get friends in on it.
