content:
Posted: April 6, 2014
												Having played most fantasy turn based strategy games since Master of Magic, I can honestly say that Age of Wonders III is a worthy addition to the genre.  It looks and sounds great, runs smoothly, and (unlike most of the venerable fantasy TBS,) has an AI that actually shows up and tries to win.  However, if you go into the game with the same attitude that you might have in the older games, you might not have much fun.Age of Wonders III is about conquest and fighting.  Everything you do in this game must drive you to this goal.  You cannot explore the map lazily looking for secrets, build armies of "fluff" because dwarf axemen are cool, or waste your mana terriforming cities when the enemy is at the gates.  In this game you have to constantly be on the lookout for ways to exploit the map, and for enemies to come out of nowhere.  By the end of the game, the surviving empires may be two giant war machines endlessly pumping units at each other from across the map (thankfully, rally points have been added.)  The last battles will, in drawn out cases, consist entirely of massive stacks of the most powerful units.  This may or may not be okay with people.I'll admit, I'm the kind of person who wants his last army to look like something from Lord of the Rings, just a huge mass of swords and bows being thrown at a huge mass of orcs.  Sadly, that will rarely happen, as this huge mass of men would just be slaughtered by a smaller mass of dragons, giants, war machines or those horrible Manticore Riders.  Indeed, I was a bit frustrated when my army of dwarven crossbowmen behind a stone wall was slaughtered by a handful of these units.  I guess what I'm trying to say with this is that this game will not make you feel like you are really leading an army of fantasy creatures in a great war.  Neither does a game of Magic the Gathering, but it sure is fun.On the subject of the AI, if you leave it alone, then you will see it turning into a massive war machine with the aforementioned rallypoints and Tier 4 units slogging across the map.  AI Knight has learned a few things since Age of Wonders II.  While it is still possible to see some tactical blunders (suiciding flyers for example) it puts up a better fight than most without extra help.  Admittedly, I haven't seen if it gets any, but I haven't noticed anything from it that made me call foul.If I have to criticize it, it would be that most games play pretty much the same, requiring a similar strategy from the player to win based on race and class choice, and the layout of the map, while it may throw occaisional curveballs at you, has little to do with how things progress.  But in that criticism I just described many games that are perfectly fine, as is this one (Heroes of Might and Magic series might be the exception there, but look how good the last one of those was...)  The fun in a game like that is to optimize that strategy to perfect it, while someone across the battlefield from you tries to counter it.  The game's AI does not forgive you if you screw up. Really if I wanted to throw out things I'd like, it'd be some degree of city specialization (choose between buildings rather than just build everything everywhere,) more options for creating items and creating/leveling characters, and maybe some map structures that can change the course of the game (special unit recruitment, buffs to city created units such as Master of Magics "Adamantium Deposits") and so on.  Also, with all the terriforming and terrain changing options, I want terrain to mean more to me during the game.  Maybe I'm just not paying attention to it, but right now, I only terriform for a little extra gold from cities and for looks.  Its still cool though, changin the world into a frozen wasteland or a sweltering jungle.  I do miss the Shadow World though, and the Dark Elves, and the Nomads, hell, even the Halflings, but I am sure I'll see them all again.There will be DLC, and I will pay for it.  The game world can only get bigger and better, and Triumph really seems to be putting all their effort into it.tldr: Its very fun.  And competitive.  Its not building an epic empire in a grand story, its all about stomping your enemies into the dirt.  And it ends like Clash of the Titans except with more Titans.  Its not Age of Wonders II, but Age of Wonders II didn't magically disappear or anything.  And you can make a Dwarf Succubus.  Seriously.

content:
Posted: April 6, 2014
												Having played most fantasy turn based strategy games since Master of Magic, I can honestly say that Age of Wonders III is a worthy addition to the genre.  It looks and sounds great, runs smoothly, and (unlike most of the venerable fantasy TBS,) has an AI that actually shows up and tries to win.  However, if you go into the game with the same attitude that you might have in the older games, you might not have much fun.Age of Wonders III is about conquest and fighting.  Everything you do in this game must drive you to this goal.  You cannot explore the map lazily looking for secrets, build armies of "fluff" because dwarf axemen are cool, or waste your mana terriforming cities when the enemy is at the gates.  In this game you have to constantly be on the lookout for ways to exploit the map, and for enemies to come out of nowhere.  By the end of the game, the surviving empires may be two giant war machines endlessly pumping units at each other from across the map (thankfully, rally points have been added.)  The last battles will, in drawn out cases, consist entirely of massive stacks of the most powerful units.  This may or may not be okay with people.I'll admit, I'm the kind of person who wants his last army to look like something from Lord of the Rings, just a huge mass of swords and bows being thrown at a huge mass of orcs.  Sadly, that will rarely happen, as this huge mass of men would just be slaughtered by a smaller mass of dragons, giants, war machines or those horrible Manticore Riders.  Indeed, I was a bit frustrated when my army of dwarven crossbowmen behind a stone wall was slaughtered by a handful of these units.  I guess what I'm trying to say with this is that this game will not make you feel like you are really leading an army of fantasy creatures in a great war.  Neither does a game of Magic the Gathering, but it sure is fun.On the subject of the AI, if you leave it alone, then you will see it turning into a massive war machine with the aforementioned rallypoints and Tier 4 units slogging across the map.  AI Knight has learned a few things since Age of Wonders II.  While it is still possible to see some tactical blunders (suiciding flyers for example) it puts up a better fight than most without extra help.  Admittedly, I haven't seen if it gets any, but I haven't noticed anything from it that made me call foul.If I have to criticize it, it would be that most games play pretty much the same, requiring a similar strategy from the player to win based on race and class choice, and the layout of the map, while it may throw occaisional curveballs at you, has little to do with how things progress.  But in that criticism I just described many games that are perfectly fine, as is this one (Heroes of Might and Magic series might be the exception there, but look how good the last one of those was...)  The fun in a game like that is to optimize that strategy to perfect it, while someone across the battlefield from you tries to counter it.  The game's AI does not forgive you if you screw up. Really if I wanted to throw out things I'd like, it'd be some degree of city specialization (choose between buildings rather than just build everything everywhere,) more options for creating items and creating/leveling characters, and maybe some map structures that can change the course of the game (special unit recruitment, buffs to city created units such as Master of Magics "Adamantium Deposits") and so on.  Also, with all the terriforming and terrain changing options, I want terrain to mean more to me during the game.  Maybe I'm just not paying attention to it, but right now, I only terriform for a little extra gold from cities and for looks.  Its still cool though, changin the world into a frozen wasteland or a sweltering jungle.  I do miss the Shadow World though, and the Dark Elves, and the Nomads, hell, even the Halflings, but I am sure I'll see them all again.There will be DLC, and I will pay for it.  The game world can only get bigger and better, and Triumph really seems to be putting all their effort into it.tldr: Its very fun.  And competitive.  Its not building an epic empire in a grand story, its all about stomping your enemies into the dirt.  And it ends like Clash of the Titans except with more Titans.  Its not Age of Wonders II, but Age of Wonders II didn't magically disappear or anything.  And you can make a Dwarf Succubus.  Seriously.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 8, 2014
												Review as of the Eighth of May, 2014.After about 60-70 hours in total with recorded time and offline time in this four X game, I have to commend it.As with every 4X game, this one has a distinct love of two of them, eXploit and eXterminate. Let's start with that.The command, unlike some other games, namely Fallen Enchantress, which is the main comparrison I'll be making, is rather dull. It takes about 25-70 turns, depending on what's in its domain, to complete the city entirely, and each city has to make that trek and the only real thing that changes it is the Raze, Plunder and Migrate options for each city, which is a nice touch, since each race has its own benefits.  Compared to Fallen Enchantress, though, the cities feel... Dull. It's the same path each time, and once you get all your class specific units, the entire war units tree is useless. One main problem I have with it, and this is a personal quipe, but oh well, is that the cities just suddenly... get taken over. Anything above a city I'm practically yelling at the screen with the general rage when a group of SCOUT units, which literally are so easy to kill that a tier four takes 1 damage to them, takes over your throne city/any other metropolis. That was a major turn off for me.Now, onto the war section. The combat is probably the most fun I've had in a 4X. It's really slick, it carries weight, and the seiges are fun. The general feel of the units are amazing, with specific combinations practically winning seiges and battles. The units all have unique rolls on the battlefield, some are tanks that don't deal much damage, or a "Give them the plague!" units that makes whatever they attack weaker. And one of my favorite, and at the same time least favorite, mechanics is that each battlefield consists of six hexes that each unit on takes part in. But then comes the little problem of top teir units being stacked and being literally impossible in a city to dislodge. And the units that aren't inside the gates on the map spawning on the battlefield suddenly inside it. That irritated me that you couldn't just send an army to fight one another. But, despite the units unique to each faction, I kept feeling the same feeling of "These are rather generic units" at the end of the game, since every end game unit tends to be what you'd expect. They should flesh it out a lot more and add either entire unit customization or just athestic customization. Oh. And heroes are practically useless unless you totally defend them with everything, since they're so low health and defence.The explore and expand elements are generally how it feels in other games, use the explore to get loot and make more of the same generic city over the map. And don't even get me started on how useless the neautral city AI are. They're there for one purpose: Be conquered!All in all, though, I'd say it's an amazing game with its problems that can be fixed with just a smidge of effort, or if a modder is willing, they could always fix it.Overall opinion: For me, personally, I like more diplomancy and less masses of war units everywhere. 8/10. I recommend it, I got my money's worth out of it.

content:
Posted: May 17, 2014
												I give this game a 8 out of 10.The game reminds you strongly of Heroes of Might and Magic.  Your character travels the map, explores locations, and takes controll of resource points.  Combat isn't as developed as HoMM.  Your troops are deployed randomly and your find yourself really missing being able to line up your troops as you see fit.  Also lacks the variety of HoMM's tactical combat options for your units.The game also strongly reminds you of Elemental Fallen enchantress.  You can send out units to colonize and expand your realm.  Building different buildings expands the zone of controll for each city.  It falls a little short of the Elemental comparison with the lack of RPG elements and the variety of items to equip your character with.The storyline for the two campaigns is decent, the single female voice actress does a great job, but you find yourself wishing for a few animated cutscenes to spice things up.  Each mission is more or less the same.  Build up your troops and take out your enemies.  It can get a little stale after about 20 hours though.

content:
Posted: August 25, 2014
												A fantastic outgrowth of the very strong Age of Wonders series of games. If you like Civilization, but would rather be throwing lightning bolts instead of tac nukes, this is the game for you. The strategic elements are designed to offer a lot of player license in success or failure, and there are multiple avenues of growth and focus to fit a player's play-style.The Class system is very fun, allowing players to command an Empire with a very different flavor depending on his or her class.The first expansion was just announced, which ushers in the Halflings to the game, and I'm looking forward to more content that may introduce more and more of the missing (and classic) races from previous games. Well done, Triumph!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 24, 2014
												I never played the original, but I loved Age of Wonders II. So coming into this as a fan of AoW2, my expectations were high, and I honestly wasn't disappointed. I love this game for so many reasons, from leader creation and customization to the way your race tints the special units your class affords you. The game is visually beautiful and fairly well-paced, and the random map generator has always delivered a world I genuinely enjoyed exploring and conquering.AoW3 suits a number of play styles and victory conditions, all of which you can toggle on or off. The battles require thought and planning a little more than raw power. A number of weak units can take down a smaller number of more powerful units if you position everyone correctly and use just the right spells at the right times. I get a genuine sense of pride every time I successfully bring down a powerful enemy army.There are, of course, a few things that could stand to be improved. I'd like more customization options as far as hair is concerned, and there are some lighting issues and minor clipping problems on some of the unit models. However, all of these issues are superficial and very easy to overlook. I don't find they detract from my experience at all.Excellent game if you enjoy fantasy, strategy or 4X games, and an absolutely superb game if you enjoy all three!

content:
Posted: August 8, 2015
												At a younger age I played "Master of Magic" by Microprose. Loved that game and spent countless hours playing it. When Age of Wonders came along, I had a ton of fun with that as well. Shadow magic and Age of Wonders two were also a lot of fun. This one however, I didn't really like. They've taken a step away from the high fantasy setting and tried to incorporate steam punk into the game, which in turn makes it a mish mash of two different settings. They should have gone with the original concept or simply made a steam punk game and call it something else. The previous games did have some hints of steam punk with the dwarven faction, but this time around it's all over the place and magic feels like a secondary thought in a game that's supposedly about magic.The story isn't really that good, just a repetition of previous installments, but not performed as well and kind of boring.The game is to it's core the same as previous games, but the i.e. lack of diversity between the races is gone, now instead it is based on "classes" what type of units you get. It's not a bad game but I was expecting more of a third installment. Magic doesn't feel as useful as previous games, other than perhaps some very late game summons that pretty much instant win the game for you. There's a ton of loot for your heroes, which is quite nice (but feels over the top at times, i.e. there is a spell where you can summon eggs that turn into mounts and I just spammed that spell until I got the best mounts in the game for all my heroes) and heroes are still very useful addition to your armies. I liked the introduction of mounts for heroes, that affected how they move both in the world and tactical map (even gives some stats). The music is as always good, could have used a few more tracks though. While it might seem like I am bashing the game, I'm not, it simply wasn't what I expected it to be. If you enjoyed the previous AoW games you should give it a try, I played through both sides on the original AoW III, but didn't feel like it was worth my time playing the expantions/dlc, I'd rather just give the original games another go.

content:
Posted: November 21, 2015
												This is my favorite game right now.  It has the best of expected stratagy game features, and extends the standard by including features that were missing in other empire building games.You can not only choose your leaders, but you can customize there face, hair, clothes. You can also pick the scene background for there leader screen.  You can also decide on the pose. very sweet.  I like the feelling of entering the buildings on the map.  I really like being able to move the pieces during tacticle battles. The unit banners have the health meter, so I pick on the weakest guy.Naval battles actually take place on the water, and "Embarked" units are standing on boats while they fight.  The research takes place from a spell book, which is cool. The mini map is more custamizable than I was used to. The landscape textures are beautiful.Zooming out on the strategic map and having the map become a "cloth" map with drafted geographic features, makes this seem even more emersive.  It is very similar to the map in the end pages of "The Hobbit".Speaking of fantasy, the realm and genre one has come to expect from fantasy rpgs is well represented.From undead, to will-o-whisps. Mermaids and Krakens; Kobolds, and Dragons.  Treasure, gold, mana, and Hero pick ups.I had gotten fairly good at my usual stratagy war game, so I am humbled at how involved the added calculations and stats, the RPG world encompasses.  Good bad, Creation, destruction; the 4 elements; Arch Druids compared to dreadnaughts, or necromancers.So much fun! So much to "get into"The single most excelent awsome feature is the Modding Support.Import your blender models! Download the Rigged models from the developer! Extend the Resources that are already in the game! Customize the story line.Linked maps in a custom campaign.  Program quests! Build underground worlds! The creation Engine alone is worth every pennie I spent, (My goblin leader is Pennie the Pincher)

content:
Posted: April 20, 2016
												This is a game that makes me look up and look at the clock and realise that 7 hours of my life has just passed by and it is suddenly light outside and oh god I need to sleep before I have to go to work and oh alright then, just one more turn and then I will defintiely go to bed... Stylistically it is a cartoony version of games such as Heroes of Might and Magic where you control a Hero and their own faction of fantasy scamps out to do valiant battle against other assorted fantasy tropes and critters. But under the cheery colourful exterior there is a very good game that, although with limitations, scratches almost all of my fantasy strategy empire building rpg itches. The RPG style Hero levelling and item system is well executed. The empire building is decent. The battles can be pretty fun and sometimes even quite challenging. The diplomacy is about as good as any other 4X game I've played and not as awful as some of them although I have yet to try to win diplomatically and so I am not sure if that is even an option. I have not played AoW 1 or 2 so I have no idea if they are better or worse than this installment but as I said, I think this one is addictive good fun.Now I feel that there is room for improvement. The late game is a bit of a boring grind; as your cities expand they all turn out a bit samey. The AI is not terrible and I have been beaten by it a few times but I wish they would actually do a bit of empire building on its own: they never build roads or forts for example. Perhaps it is better against human players but as I have no friends I have yet to experience that aspect of the game.All in all, if you like your 4X's but feel that CIV V doesn't feature enough ogres, imps or kobold minions then you should defintiely give this title a go. Also the two first expansions are good additions that in my opinion adds a lot of essential content to the vanilla game so maybe wait for a sale to get the bundle. Just a tip.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 6, 2016
												Grading Scale:10 - Masterpiece9 - Amazing8 - Great7 - Good6 - Okay5 - Mediocre4 - Bad3 - Terrible2 - Abomination1 - UnplayableGame: Age of Wonders IIISummary: Turn-based strategy game with some RPG elements and a fantasy setting.Pros:Combat- Refreshing and fun for a turn based strategy game. Although some flaws are evident (will go over it in the "cons" section). Combat takes place in a battlefield that takes into account the type of terrain you were on when combat was initiated. You can move your units around and place them in strategic areas around the field.Character Customization- Able to customize your hero with different hairstyles and certain cosmetic options such as armor and head pieces. RPG Elements- Able to equip your hero with items that are obtained throughout the world. You can also level your hero and have him/her learn new spells and moves. Among these units are mounts which really give your hero a unique feel.Units- Each unit is unique and inspired. Although you cannot customize your units the same way you can your hero, they each have their own unique abilities and appearance.Cons:Limited Victories: Although diplomacy is possible, the style of the game begs for a conquest win. The resources at your disposal for any other type of victories are simply not worth the effort. It's a lot of fun to just stomp through everything with your unique armies.Repetitiveness- After playing for a while. Combat can get a bit tedious to a point where you just find yourself skipping it altogether. Once that happens, the rest of the game just doesn't hold up. Combat is the fun part of this game, not so much the diplomacy.Verdict: Fun turn-based strategy game with a fun twist on combat that suffers from repetitiveness. The hero development, different class system and customization adds for a unique experience everytime you play the game.Score: 7

content:
Posted: April 2, 2014
												Fallen Enchantress, Eat your heart out.This 4X Fantasy game allows for a deep level of customization that captures the creativity of Fallen Enchantress while providing a more aesthetically pleasing, polished experience. Diplomatic and overworld gameplay remains similar to the Civilization series, while not quite as robust. It does make up for it with its level of creative control. Create your own civilization leader from a host of classes and racial combinations. Both your class and race affect the type of units your empire will have access to. If you play a rogue, depend on having stealth units, assassins and the like. Play a dreadnaught? Youll have rifleman and steam tanks. A warlord? How does having a legion of berserkers sound? While you cant directly modify individual units like fallen enchantress, the sheer vareity at your disposal makes that irrelavant.If youre looking for a high fantasy themed civilization style 4X game with RPG elements, look no further.

												Age of Wonders III is one of those games that won't grab you instantly. But if you stick with it and learn the ropes, you'll find yourself playing for hours and telling yourself "just one more turn". The game isn't perfect, but it is one of the deepest 4x fantasy TBS game that I've played in recent years, with its strongest element being the combat system. Easily recommended to any TBS enthusiast out there.

It Rocks!I'm a big fan of the previous incarnations of this game, including the game they "borrowed elements from", ahem, before this series came out. It is a large scale game not unlike a fantasy version of Civilization. The games are also multi-player. Its a fantastic lan game. I used to play with a girlfriend - we would ally and take on the entire rest of the world. So far this version of the game plays very smoothly, has a lot of the original features that made the older games great and the tactical battles are fun.The game is complex. However that is the fun of it. Spending time learning the races and what special units they have. There is a lot to learn but it is definitely fun. Eventually you will find the combinations of abilities and fun units that combine to give you the juggernaut experience you are hoping for.I am so glad I saw this announced a few months ago and pre-ordered. It was great having it show up and I will probably put a dent in Titanfall playing this.

content:
Posted: April 14, 2014
												In this game, the main premise is a large scale rivalry between powerful mages with varying specializations and studies, who bend cities by their will toward good, evil, or whatever.Gameplay is reminiscent mostly of Heroes of Might and Magic, in a good way.  This is a 4X game with an especially strong emphasis on exploration and extermination, with heroes who go questing, conquering, leveling up, and looting for themselves and their empire.  Campaign actions are made on a high-level campaign map.  Battles play out on a lower-level map in a tactical turn-based manner, taking into account the terrain and structures of the tile on the campaign map.  Both maps use hexagonal tiles.  Armies (unit stacks) are composed of up to six units.  In a battle, all adjacent armies participate.  In some ways, this approach to combat feels like a middle ground between Civilization and Total War.Much of the design is reminiscent of Master of Magic.  Cities and units vary according to the class of the player and the race of the inhabitants.  There are six classes (arch druid, dreadnought, rogue, sorceror, theocrat, and warlord) and six races (high elf, human, orc, goblin, dwarf, and draconian).  The variety is good but not dizzying, with a solid array of standard unit types and a handful of specialists available in any city that has the requisite buildings.  Spellcasting plays a major role on the campaign map and in battles.  The spells span a wide spectrum from an assortment that is modest in cost and effect to the immensely powerful and expensive high tier.  Each school of magic (among air, earth, fire, water, creation, and destruction) is distinct, with its own characteristic effects and strategies.  The interplay between questing, empire building, warfare, and spellcasting is fun, engaging, and balanced.Compared to other 4X games, there is a diminished emphasis on exploitation.  Rather, the exploitation here is ultimately focused on serving the exploration and extermination.  You won't find options for cultural, diplomatic, or economic victories here, and the gameplay options are limited likewise.  This is not a game of peace.  [edit: Interestingly, Triumph has hinted that this is an area that they will expand in upcoming updates.]The overall fit and finish is very good, although not without room for improvement.  The UI is strongly reminiscent of Civilization V—a good choice of inspiration.  Some aspects live up to this standard better than others.  There is a Tome of Wonders (akin to Civilopedia), but it's a pain to navigate (no back button?!  among other problems), and some of its pages neglect important information.  Some stats show breakdowns on hover, as they should, but some breakdowns lack desirable detail, while others are simply omitted.  I'm curious to see if any of this improves with ongoing updates.Unlike Civilization and most other games in the 4X genre, a game of Age of Wonders III at normal pace is significantly shorter.  Expect a commitment of three to six afternoons instead of three to six full days.  Considering the pesky existence of real life, this is a very desirable trait.If you like 4X and high fantasy, and you'd like a game that combines the two in a form that's easy to swallow, then this is a great choice.

content:
Posted: April 19, 2014
												Just Another Review.Well so I bought this game because everyone who has played a kings bounty, disciples, heroes of might and magic?, civ and etc type of turn based strategy game will get the itch to play another if they discover they like it.Ive put around 20-30 hours into this game single player only (commonwealth) and I was pleasently suprised. After I wrapped around the controls which for whatever reason seemed backwards (left and right mouse buttons would be vise versa if i made things lol), I got pretty into the game and keep coming back. Although I could say a lot more, I am going to summarize things in bullet form as best i can and I will likely miss some things:Thinks I think that could be improved:-The research tree is still rather baffling if you want to plan ahead or unlock certain things unless you have played a lot. If it was set up like in civilization with some kind of flow chart it would be a lot easier to prioritize.-Combat animations are kinda crumby with the units (i'm just whining nothing that harms the game)-The hero cannot die clause. Warcraft 2 all over again. In the campaign you basically just keep your hero in the back away from harm and cast spells unless you want him focus'ed by the AI and to reload your save. Personally I think the hero's need more durability else they essentially just play a support role for most of the fight, cuz when they die everything stops. You aren't going to siege a city without those wonderful buffs they give all the units in the army pack nor will you go and explore ruins/want to fight if a hero isn't milking exp.-The exp system, it should essentially award everyone in the army attacking or not. Win a battle: gain most exp, lose a battle: hero gets some exp everyone else is dead lol, Run from a battle get no exp (since running could be abused). I essentially just have hero use a ranged ability to kill off whatever i can (safely) as to net more exp.-The AI during sieges, if you have 2 trebuchets you can basically funnel all the enemies through a narrow hole in the wall, ive beat a few "very likely defeat" situations abusing this with a very small army. If the enemy is more numerous then you past a certain extent they should just bum rush you out the gates and cut u off instead of hole up and get picked off.-Spellcasting seems kind of wonky, losing your hero for casting oil skin almost doesnt seem worth it... some spells should perhaps count as your cast and not your hero turn and the more powerful will take both... Things I dont understand yet....:-I still have no idea the use of teraforming whatsoever. Ive never encountered any situation where i would want to change my land type. Nor have unhappy people, nor really see any issues being good/evil.-Why we have so many damn resources, gold is fine for the most part, but mana crystals im always swimming in them early on and for the rest of the scenario.Things that shine:-Battles are really fun when in the open areas with a lot of obstacles around.-The unique units are quite diverse so far from what i see-Game isn't the prettiest but I really like the looks of everything-campaign is enjoyable and each level takes a fair bit of time to complete thoroughly and im just playing on easy mode to speed through~ u get a lot of playtime in this game!-The voice acting is quite good, I love the intro dialogues they are read very very well.If you want my comments on anything be sure to post and ask ill give my 2 cents.Hope this is useful lol

content:
Posted: September 29, 2014
												Should you buy Age of Wonders 3? Yes, but there's a catch.ABOVE AVERAGE for its priceThe game is visually impressive with a lot of love and care taken to make the game the best it could possibly be. The problem is, the game lacks... ambition. The combat is really all there is to the game and while its fulfilling early on, it tends to drag on late game. You'll spend hours clearing the resource points of monsters and enemy camps to build a safe and sprawling empire only to realize that your empire is just to feed your warmachine, nothing else. At which its very easy to proclaim yourself the winner because what reward is there to finishing a solo game?Which leads to the other problem, multiplayer. 4x strategy games are really meant for multiplayer matches. Its a wonderful race to see who can build what faster, stronger, and diplomatic better. However AoW 3 doesn't lend itself well to MP games because of time and lack of any real substantial diplomacy.-time, essentially you either sacrifice time to enjoy the game and its combat the way its meant to be played, or you turn the quick autobattles on and skip over the big tactical portion of the game. Its a lose lose either way.-Diplomacy is lacking because there is no real benefit to peace other than a secure border but, who's to say your peaceful neighbor won't just backstab you? As there is no consequence for breaking your word, no morale penalties, no reduced gold income or productivity, nothing. The flip side is also true, no economical advantages to being at peace :(Despite all that its still a good game and I enjoyed very much of it, its just sad to see so much potential fizzle out.+Graphics, a very rich, visually appealing game+Tactical combat is very satisfying+-Replay value is there, but late game becomes tedious management and busy work... I've yet to finish a single random scenario-No tech tree, research randomness in a strategy game is a bit disappointing-Good luck finding a rewarding mp experience for a game that is by design, not meant for multiplayer-DLC is a bit disapointing

												This game is just getting better and better. At first, I was a bit disappointed but for each expansion added they just added more and more content to the game. More campaigns, more scenarios, more races, new class. It start to feel more and more like Age of Wonders 1 again but with a class system and city building for more controlled expansion. For each patch, for each expansion it just becomes better! It should be a game in every X4 fans collection. To put it on something familiar, add a dose of Heroes 3, add a dose of Civilisation, add a does of roleplaying. You get Age of Wonders III.  A 9 out of 10 game right now for me. But I might be a bit biased, being a long term fan of 15 years with this series. But I recommend it to everyone who enjoy this kind of games.

												I love every game in the AOW series. AOW III is everything that was done right in AOW 1 and AOW2 put together into one game. It is hard to describe its mostly visible as a flicker in certain pieces of terrain like lava or the underground forests. This EXACT same issue was there in AOW2. It makes the game unstable. It is very annoying to see bugs carrying over into sequels. I've this bug on many different computers at this point so talk of graphics cards and drivers being at fault is ridiculous. The same damn bug happens on linux as well as the windows version!But everything else about the game is awesome and it is hands down the best fantasy TBS strategy game I've ever played.

content:
Posted: February 27, 2016
												This game is great whether you're a fan of the series, a fan of strategy games, or just a newcomer to these kind of games. Learning the gameplay might take a tad bit but when you start playing you'll find yourself bargaining time away just so you can play one more turn. The single player is pretty much where most people start, in order to learn the game mechanics and the game does that pretty well, by the time I got to the thrid level I was already building proper armies, upgrading cities, and destroying other empires. The game's AI is smart even on easy and you will find them hitting your weak points if you underestimate them while the hardest difficulty pushes you to use everything in your power to win, also although you can build alliances with the AI it is actually very hard to do so because most of the time they're in it for themselves but then again so are we so peace most of the time will not be in your options. You can also fight the battles yourself on a field but after awhile I just kept using auto battle unless it was a battle that I needed to be won then I took control but do know that one level can take a long time to complete because you'll be managing your cities, planning strategies for the future, or something else which will take time unless you're blitzing all the time. The music really is well made, the graphics are great, the multiplayer is fun and in a nutshell this game is very entertaining

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 16, 2016
												Very good game with alot of content. Especially the random maps are good (with lots of sliders to tune it to your liking incase you would want that), but the campaigns are also decent and there are loose scenario maps. Keep in mind though that while this is tagged as a 4x game, the combat part (turn based) is dominant and leveling up your hero and units is very important too. In short combat and exploration are really important.I highly recommend buying the game with the 2 expansions Golden Realm and Eternal Lords. Not only are new classes, races and specialisations added, some addional gameplay features are added and new ways to win.+ lots of possible combinations by picking your race and your class and spell specialisations. E.g. a sorcerer that summons whole armies, or a necro that has undead armies, or a dreadnought that has many machines. + be dark (plunder villages and kill of whole races), gray or good (e.g. helping villages with quests so they will join your empire or as vassals), based on actions and not race. Do whatever you like. Also several decisions in the storyline that you can make. + rich maps filled neutral ctities, hideouts, dungeons, recources, neutral places that give bonuses to nearby cities, tavern to hire units, etc. etc.  Lots of places to level up and gain loot. Also secundary quests. + The random map generator is one of the best I have ever seen. + lots of units and quite a bit of buildings and upgrades for villages/cities.+ the bigger your empire with a race and the longer you have it, the more race bonuses you will get (you pick between upgrades).+ all units can rank up which give them interesting abilities and add lots of tactics. With your leader and heroes you can pick between quite a bit upgrades/abilities per level up.+ lots of items, spells and abilities.+ less RNG than similar games.+ good backlore.+ moddable and there are mods for it.-/+ can be difficult to turtle or forward base defending tactics, though with some classes and races its more viable.- a map can get tough when you have a bad start (e.g. you lose some starting units or are to slow with leveling them). - still some annoying RNG, but luckily not so much.- minor point: while campaings are decent, I feel that the story could have been more epic. Can't really put my finger on it though, since the backlore (especially with AoW 1 and 2) is pretty expansive.My score: 9. Pro's to the developers for having patched this game many times.

												I love every game in the AOW series. AOW III is everything that was done right in AOW 1 and AOW2 put together into one game. content:
Posted: April 4
												It's a good game. I think it's more fun than Civ 5, but I agree with some of the reviewers that some of the game mechanics don't make sense. A squad with 1 hp still doing full damage and the flanking rules don't work really well. It's better in many ways than AOW: Shadow Magic with the more 4x elements. But there are some problems... The tools for managing lots of cities and armies are lacking. There's a global spell that the enemy can cast that lower all your armies moral so you can't win any battles and everyone leaves you by the time you can cast a disenchant strong enough for it, so that's pretty unbalanced. It's difficult to get used to right-clicking all the time after playing modern games, so it'd be nice to have an option to have that work differently.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 19, 2016
												Fell in love, this game with its expansions is  overly fun and addicting. Got it on sale in my country and soon bought the expansions on steam for normal price and found they are very much worth it.If you like what you see on their promo videos, you will propably like it or love it ;).Game has many so many different  ways to play either solo or with friends: Many different difficulty and size ready campaings with a plot and ready made leaders (though those are not not my cup of thea rlly), many ready made scenarios with a set map or the very highly customizable and to me the oh so addicting random maps with expansion added customizable win conditions, not just rush and crush yer enemy, but call for diplomacy and patience too. On scenario or random maps you can customize your leader from the start, and not just skills, make them look fabulous (or wicked fabulous) too, wich I love, makes me very attached to them  :D!And you can save the looks and start skills of your new leaders to a custom char "base", to choose them later as your chars or enemies again in another game.Char/Class skill developement way feels very exiting to me cause there is an element of chance to what new skills you get to research with time or what you and your heroes get each lvl . With 166 hours played and diff chars I still feel happy to see new skills for main char or heroes, or eagerly await for something to pop up I`d rly like.Class and race options feel like making a big difference in gameplay and make me want to try out more combinations.And fun: you can even play with or against your self= set all or some players to "human" at  random map options and you can take turns with multiple self created chars, of course with ai enemy added if you  so choose.Even wage war on yourself, and use "autocombat" in battle if you want the ai to take over one char to prevent you from cheating any ;) And, if like me you like to take your time  and make a solo all human game to  exlore the random  world "for ages "in one game, choose an extra large map with win conditons either  Unify or Seals , make your all human crazy group to switch turns and either work together or try to snuff each other. Either way, if you left the roaming independents on in your setting, you should  still scout the lands for threats early ( dangerous spawn points that get harder with lvl ) before a herd of bonedragons comes knocking just when you thought your  halfling Metropolis of "Happytown" is doing so good in a happy solo game ... Happened to me ;)Cheers, my two cents!=A Highly recommended game! Feels like it was very lovingly made by the devs :DPS. and modding. So nice to have modding. Currently using visual mods that unlock all outfits and hairs for races and classes, more leader flag /outfit colurs and raise undead turned to a better looking skeletal army :D

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 21, 2015
												In an age of expensive, flashy, superficial games, here is one that stands apart. I never played AoW2, but I played the original and it's one of my favorite classic games, right up there with Age of Empires: Age of Kings, and AoW3 is true to its roots. Newer games tend to shed the characteristics that made their predecessors great in favor of aspects that make good trailers and build extraordinary hype, only to fall flat on release when everybody finds out how shallow they are. Not this one. AoW3 delivers a deep experience that you can approach from a number of different ways: there's campaigns, scenarios, multiplayer--and random map, which is by far the best feature. For The Elder Scrolls II: Daggerfall, Bethesda randomly generated a world the size of Great Britain. Once. AoW3 does that every time you start a new random map. Yeah, they're not really comparable, but the point is made. No two random maps are the same. A single, 8-player, extra large random map will get you your money's worth out of AoW3, then you'll start a new one as a different race, different class, different school of magic, and you'll do it again and it'll be all-new. You'd better quit reading reviews and get started.

content:
Posted: April 10, 2014
												One of the best games of this genre since Heroes of Might and Magic II... seriously amazing!  It follows the same style where you pick a main hero who has a race and a class, with three specialties (Spell Masteries, traits etc).  You build cities and go exploring and BATTLING.  Yeah, the game is all about the combat so if you're looking for something like CIvilization you will be sorely disappointed with this one.  The combat is excellent and strategic.  Units can level up during battles, and eventually, can become quite strong if they've been with you since the beginning of the game.  The game has flanking, attacks of opportunity, line of sight bonuses and penalties (however, no friendly fire with ranged attack, so that's a plus), Overwhelm, Status Effects, Special Movement Types... I don't know what more you could ask for in the combat part. In terms of things that aren't combat like city management, etc... Yeah - it's limited.  Diplomacy leaves me scratching my head and there's no options to make other players necessarily like you, just peace treaties or alliance proposals.  City buildings basically fall into either resource production (for that glorious army you're building) or unit recruitment buiildings so it's easy enough to get into.  It may be rather simple, but that's how Heroes of Might and Magic II was and man if this isn't the spirtual succesor to that game I don't know what is.

content:
Posted: May 23, 2015
												The game is a winner, as far as I have played it so far. I have always been a fan of strategy, whether it be turn-based or real-time, but also have like many other genres too. I have many games that compete for my limited game time, but this one is winning hands-down at the moment. While there are some definite 'Heroes of Might and Magic' parallels, it feels much more holistic. The tactical fighting is great, and just gets better the more I learn about the units and the mechanics. The leveling system for each unit is great, and makes you really try to keep the unit alive, granting better powers and giving each experienced unit a sense of being less 'replaceable' by the next newly produced unit. This means that rather than sending them to their doom just to finish the battle faster, or being too careless or clumsy, you really want to make sure they get involved (to get more xp), but keep them from sacrificing themselves for a worthless cause.The Heroes are great, and with so much customisation as they level up, it leaves you forever wishing you had more points to throw at their skills. This also makes it juicily special when they level up. And, even better is that it can really make a difference to the battles, whether it be the spells that enhance your 'shock troopers' to take and dish-out a heap of punishment, or enhancing your hero so they themselves become a mobile game-changer wherever they tread.The city development is interesting too. It does not boast the most exhaustive list of buildings, but in the early-mid game it promotes the development of a city so that it specialises in one or two troop types. I really like this because it means you can plan your overall strategy with more effectiveness. Including thinking about how to get your slow-moving troops to the enemy - do you build them in the close cities, or build roads between cities, or keep each city more generic and have lower level or lower tiered troops. Lots of delicious approaches.Another big plus is the ability to play offline. Which is great as I often travel. Cloud auto-saves can also help me progress on either my PC or laptop.If you like strategy, and multiple approaches to victory - then this game is for you. Heroes class and race make a difference, and the constant difficult choice of which spells and skills to choose is fantastic. Runs surprisingly well on low specs too.Cons - can't save the game mid-way through a battle, music is not amazing (but who really plays these games for the music).Please enjoy!

content:
Posted: June 27, 2016
												TL;DRAwesome turn based strategy game. Main campaign is frustrating in spots, but very doable on normal difficulty. I've put in over 100 hours already and still love the game.I have been on the look out for a modern replacement of Master of Magic. I can honestly say that this game may be the game that takes Master of Magic's place for me. Only time will tell, but the initial testing seems to point to a yes. The Heroes and items in Master of Magic are still possibly better. The main thing is that there are multiple ways of making a hero in Master of Magic that is for all practical purposes invincible. Some may say that's a bad thing, but I always liked it. Also, the spells in Master of Magic are truly awesome and there are a ton of spells. There are very few bad / useless spells in Master of Magic. And, so long as your heros have mana, they can each cast a spell every turn. The main disappointment for me in Age of Wonders 3 is that you can only cast one spell per turn in combat. The upside, is there are some cool abilities that are essentially spells, but don't count as a spell. Call Lightning, Thunder Storm, Guardian Flames are a few good examples. All in all, I am seriously enjoying the treasure hunting, city smashing, and magic. I may still go back to Master of Magic from time to time, but Age of Wonders 3 is a true contender in the niche that Master of Magic has been the Master of for so long. (The Age of Wonders games before this never captured my attention as much as Age of Wonders 3 and while good, weren't as good as Master of Magic.)

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 23, 2015
												7/10Age of Wonders III combines elements of basic city building with tactical combat and simplistic RPG aspects. The tactical battles are fun and are Age of Wonder's main component. On the downside, the storyline gets tedious as you seem to reset your progress as you move to each map. Instead of following one team of epic heroes from the beginning to the end, you are constantly introduced to new heroes that you need to level up to make them useful in a fight. Following a single team throughout the entire game would have been a more fun and rewarding experience. After completing several scenarios I grew bored with the structure of the game and continuously having to burn through turn after turn just to explore a new map. If you don't mind the tedium, the tactics battles are worth the meandering storyline and slow-paced campaign interface.

												At first I did not know what to make of this game. But I felt intrigued enough to keep playing. Then I slowly started unraveling the intricacies and the secrets and I got absolutely hooked.The biggest draw for me, is the degree of customisation it offers. There are literally dozens of combinations of race/class/specialisation combined with random maps which are quite configurable, and a lot of different tweaks for each game map. One game you might be playing a Frostling Sorcerer with master destruction and rain death (and stun) on your foes, next game a Dwarf Theocrat rising from the caves below the surface to conquer everything, specializing in wild magic with unpredictable results. Then a Tigran Warlord Grey Guard, bashing down all opposition. Then later you might revisit the Frostling sorcerer, but be lucky enough to have a building that makes your Ice Queens practically immortal (if you end up winning the fight) inside your domain. What I'm getting at, is not only are all of these options extremely fun to play around with and figure out interesting and powerful combinations, but they offer a replayability rarely seen in games.Really this game is amazing and you should check it out if you are a fan of Turn Based Strategy games. If only HoMnM games were half this good these days...EDIT 24/11/16 This game is still being updated. Triumph Studios rock!

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 10, 2014
												One of the best games of this genre since Heroes of Might and Magic II... seriously amazing!  It follows the same style where you pick a main hero who has a race and a class, with three specialties (Spell Masteries, traits etc).  You build cities and go exploring and BATTLING.  Yeah, the game is all about the combat so if you're looking for something like CIvilization you will be sorely disappointed with this one.  The combat is excellent and strategic.  Units can level up during battles, and eventually, can become quite strong if they've been with you since the beginning of the game.  The game has flanking, attacks of opportunity, line of sight bonuses and penalties (however, no friendly fire with ranged attack, so that's a plus), Overwhelm, Status Effects, Special Movement Types... I don't know what more you could ask for in the combat part. In terms of things that aren't combat like city management, etc... Yeah - it's limited.  Diplomacy leaves me scratching my head and there's no options to make other players necessarily like you, just peace treaties or alliance proposals.  City buildings basically fall into either resource production (for that glorious army you're building) or unit recruitment buiildings so it's easy enough to get into.  It may be rather simple, but that's how Heroes of Might and Magic II was and man if this isn't the spirtual succesor to that game I don't know what is.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 5, 2015
												Of all 4X games, this is my favourite. I have been a fan of the AoW series since 1999, and believe that this game borrows nicely from its predecessors but also introduces fantastic new features and content. The game is very detailed, with huge amounts of units, spells and abilities (many more than the previous games). The strategic map is beautiful, has many varied features and is always different thanks to the excellent random map generator. The tactical map is much improved, and is similarly pleasing to the eye. Units have the ability to flank, to gang up on stronger units and tie them up; these features improve this mode greatly. The addition of classes (e.g. rogue, Sorcerer) to the existing race based system is something that some people like and others do not. The negatives say that the emphasis is clearly on class and that choice of race doesnt matter. However, the classes arguably make up for this as they bring many different units and spells. Also, Triumph have been adding changes that improve racial diversity. One thing to mention here is that Triumph seem to want to listen to the community. Many gripes about the game when it came out have been addressed. As a company they seem to be passionate about what they do, giving the fans what they want and not being too mercenary in their approach to DLC etc.If I had to say what was wrong with the game, there would be two minor gripes. Firstly, while sieges look visually impressive, they are all virtually the same. Every time you must attack the same shape of city wall and seeing as sieges are so common a battleground, sometimes the game can feel (slightly) monotonous for this reason.Secondly, while multiplayer (player versus player) is exciting, it can be awkward to organise games and can be very time consuming. Basic things like an in lobby chat have been left out. The community often uses house rules like 'no attacking in the first 15 seconds of the turn' and 'do not purposefully attack my stacks of units to take my adjacent stacks out of the fight'. These make perfect sense and are used for nearly all games, but it relies on player honesty. I hope that triumph addresses this in a future patch. The signs are positive as they have implemented a number of positive changes to multiplayer already. I must say that multiplayer is a lot of fun and would recommend it for those that have patience. To sum this game up; it has a rich fantasy setting, looks fantastic, has awesome empire building features and tactical battles, and it is genuinely improving with the additions of new patches and DLC.

content:
Posted: May 31, 2016
												I recommend this game but only just and here is why. First of all, let's start off with the positives about this game. The graphics are excellent and there is a lot of replay value in this game. The storyline is very interesting if these type of RPG games interest you as this is one of those turn-based games with a somewhat unpredictable outcome. So carefull planning is advisable. I like the scenario mode the best as the Draconians is my preferred clan that I like to use that is leaded by Rish Kyan. While I am not going to spoil anything. You will have to play the game yourself to fully experience it. The game also has multiplayer mode when you can play matches against your friends. So that is some of the good parts that this game has but the major downside is with the AI as in my experiences and with two days of not much progress. From what I have learned is that if you upgrade and max out your units. The AI will be much stronger and tougher to beat and in some cases. The AI is not that well balanced from my experiences of playing this game as it is just too aggressive in easy mode for a casual gamer which can be frustrating. All in all. that is the only one major downside to an otherwise a very enjoyable game :).Overall Rating: 7/10.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 9, 2015
												This game is very complex, it doesn't compromise its complexity trying to streamline it (like Civilization: Beyond Earth which I recently played and didn't like). This game, instead, celebrates its complexity by finely balancing it and making everything in the game be worth using, even Tier 1 units which in nearly every other game (including its predecessors) become obsolete by mid-game.The turns play fast, battle auto-resolving works acceptably well and actually simulates the battles instead of making an oddball calculation based on numbers. You have the option to make your heroes survive auto-resolved battles if you win them (to avoid the strong annoyance of the CPU suiciding your heroes), thus relieving you of a lot of unwanted micromanagement.The tactical battles in the game are detailed, very enjoyable, and also optional! —since the auto-resolve feature plays fine—. You can replay auto-resolved battles to learn the game's complex tactical combat by watching the computer (I learned partly that way).The graphics, music and interface of the game are excellent. If you play with low detail graphics you may have Age of Wonders II flashbacks  =)  specially with antialiasing off. You can run this game in moderately old hardware (something other modern games can't).Excellent Turn-Based Strategy Game, a personally refreshing sight after failures like Civilization: Beyond Earth and Heroes VI. Get it on a discount sale if you're hesitant. I'm sure you'll be buying the expansions rather soon  =)( The expansions added new victory conditions and even more variety to an already spicy game. The base victory mode in random scenarios in this game is conquest. Check the reviews )

content:
Posted: April 6, 2015
												In the era, when the huge companies are either streamlining the previous games with usualll tendency to loose anything from the atmosphere of the old best sellers (yes, Heroes, im talking about You...) or even trying to squeeze Your wallets with so called HD feature stripped reedition (Yes, again Heroes of Might and Magic) asking You to pay a full price there it is - something out of the today standards.Despite always being somewhere in the shadow of HoMM series, AoW series is nowhere behind the legacy of turn based fantasy strategic games. And even if it obviously was overshadowed by allmighty Heroes III (which is probably the best game ever for majority of players reading this review - me included) at the times where Age of Wonders 2 was published (even, despite my opinion it was pretty much equally good in some terms), its no longer a case.Heroes series lost all of it glory throughour the years. Age of Wonders, resurrected not so far ago. And in a contrast of really average attempts to recover HoMM franchise, Triumph Studios made it done. This is the game every AoW fan was waiting for, and this is the game all the turn based fantasy strategic games fans should head into now. There is absolutely no other game in the genre with so much detail, fun and polish.Of course, the game has some issues (like multiplayer connection which for no reason tries to establish p2p connection which is kind off archaic method) but developers are constantly updating the game based on our feedback.So if You really enjoyed playin HoMM 3 twenty years ago, and You would love to feel something similar today - go grab it. You'll love it.

content:
Posted: November 1, 2016
												Did you see there are a lot of games like other games made many years ago? It's like Hollywood. No new ideas are better than old ideas, so they keep making movies like the ones 20-40-60 years ago.The thing with those "re-new" movies is that most of them are a pale homage to those great movies we watched and loved (yeap, I'm old).Well, with games is the same. And this here AoW3 happens the same that with another game that was the third instalment in a series that has an "o" as the second of four letters (if you need another clue, the last one is the same as the third).  ;)Lucky for us, this game IS a good homage for that great game. Is it AS good? Hard to say, I didn't play that one in a loooooooong time now, but this one makes an honest effort, and brings back a lot of fond memories. :)Also, it's totally moddable, has 4 campaigns (if you add the DLCs, and you totally should), and it works wonderfully as a port on Linux (which is why I bought it). :)So, if you remember that old "four letters and a 3" game and you liked it, give this one a try. It's worth the money. :)

number of helpful: 6 of 10 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 8, 2014
												As a long time fan of the series I wanted to like this game I really did, but it is simply one large dissapointment. If you take the last game in the series and remove things you get the new game. Smaller droops stacks, less races, less units, less unit types, weaker AI, Less spells, less spellcasting (1 per turn limit), less fantasy. Combined with a poorer less useful interface and you get a vastly sub par game. The troop stacks have been reduced from 8 to 6 removing much of the tactical play. You now place your 6 biggest units in your stack. Flying has been removed as a feature (can be attacked by ground units) and speical abilities are resisted more often. There is no room for oddball troops in your army. Spell casting is 1 per round, even if you have multiple heroes in your army. The interface is far less user friendly? Want click through armies without orders? Can't unless you end your turn, which leads to ending your turn while some units still haven't gone. Want to accept a diplomacy negotiation? You have click 3 screens deep instead of just saying "yes" when someone askes for 100 gold for mana swap. Races now have all the same exact units, class units differ but classes wre wildly unbalanced. This game needs a lot of work in a lot of places. I'd rather play AOW:SM today than this new one. Other than better graphics (which everything else was sacrificed to provide) this game is worse in every way.

number of helpful: 16 of 30 people (53%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 21, 2014
												I'm really torn about this game, because it does so much right and I hate to be negative about a game that's so close to being great. I'm going to hit on the negatives first so that at least I can end on a positive note.Negatives:There is basically no strategic depth. There is absolutely no reason not to use the highest tier units as soon as possible, none of the units really fill a unique role, and in the end there's really just no point in building lower-tier units if higher tiers are available. The strategy boils down to "who can get high-tier units produced the fastest". The Total War series is an example where this was usually done fairly well, though admittedly not anywhere near perfect.The classes aren't very well balanced: Sorcerers are incredibly powerful, since they can summon tier 4 units wherever they are and it costs no gold to do so. It allows them to effectively push forward and defend anywhere at any time. On the opposite end of the spectrum are Theocrats, who have basically nothing worth using in their own trees and must rely entirely on specializations.The specializations aren't very diverse: The elemental ones are all almost exactly parallel with each other (not in relative power, but in the fact that the powers are all the same with reskins and a number or two tweaked), the destruction and creation specializations don't do anything meaningful, and the explorer specialization is entirely useless. Honestly I think I'd've scrapped this entirely. It feels bolted-on. You can completely ignore your specialization and it'll have no effect on your gameplay most of the time.The races all feel exactly the same. I don't know if there are differences outside small hit point variances in the units or not, but if there are any they're very minor. For an example of this done better, see Heroes of Might & Magic (2, 3, or 5, if you want a specific one, basically any but 6 because that game is sadness in game form.)The research tree is an absolute mess: it requires rote memorization to figure out what research leads where. In some cases it's fairly obvious, in others it seems random if you haven't sunk a significant amount of time into the game. This is a really common problem in strategy and tactical games. Sins of a Solar Empire had this done fairly well, as did XCOM's newest incarnations (in different ways, obviously).Tactically there are a few options, but the tactical combat is incredibly and painfully repetitive. The A.I. has been improved some, but still isn't especially good. In truth I don't have a great answer for a game where this was done exceptionally well. In RTS games it usually isn't a problem, since the computer is just made more aggressive with more resources. Turn based games are a tougher nut to crack, though. Shogun 2 was one with a reasonably good A.I., but certainly not an excellent one.Multiplayer games with simultaneous turns are abysmally un-fun. Simultaneous turns in general don't work, with some units freezing in place when attacked by an enemy (when you would normally move away before the enemy could get in close), and generally team-turns would work much better than the way simultaneous turns work now.Now for the good stuff:Each of the classes does play in a unique way. The specializations may not make much difference, but the classes are incredibly varied and have a good blend of niche and flexible abilities.The game looks remarkably good for the most part. It's not graphically brilliant, but the art design was well put together, you have a lot of options for how your main hero will look and nothing looks cheap.While it's a bit of a mixed bag, the spellcasting/ability use in general is generally entertaining and can have a fairly significant effect on the tides of battle.The UI is mostly intuitive, though it too has a few areas that would benefit from clearer labelling.That's what I've got. Hope it helps!

number of helpful: 17 of 32 people (53%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 1, 2014
												A 4x fantasy game that has all the elements you could wish for, allowing it to make a real challenge at being arguably the best in its genre. But does it live up to its sparkle ?If you're old enough to remember Master of Magic, then you will know the precursor game that AoW III has built itself on. If you're not old enough, then AoW is a game of the same family as Warlock, or any of the fantasy mods for Civ. A turn based fantasy game you will spend your time exploring a map, expanding your empire, exploiting resources and finally exterminating your enemies. A 4x to the core. Whilst there have been innumerable takes on this formula, AoW III promises to bring all these things together with a decent rub of polish and just enough depth to really please the 4x audience.And in many ways the game does just that - a nice tactical combat system that brings depth to the strategic map manoeuvres without overstaying its welcome. A diverse and interesting number of resources to exploit. Bucketfuls of different army units and racial types. And so on.But despite all this, and despite it looking great, the game has some flaws. And when you get to playing it, those flaws really start to bite.The first flaw is the simultaneous move implementation. Turn based games can turn into a tedious snore fest if they opt for a me go you go type mechanic. Fortunately in this day and age such things are rare ( with the exception of the woeful coding of Warlock ), but in AoW III the simultaneous movement has a hitch. Everything and everyone moves simultaneously - players, AI kingdoms, independents. And the AI has a beautifully machine like grief play style where it can wait for you to make a single move somewhere, before rolling forward its units to sneak in the back door and take that town from you.Woops.So maybe you shouldn't move out of that town. At all. Ever. A bizarre nervouse mexican stand off ensues where the AI stares you down waiting for you to misclick or even just investigate a passing army before rushing in to capitalise. And it's no good clicking once you've taken that step - particularly if you are playing in a multiplayer network game - as the whole thing then lags and chugs busy processing its own fabulously griefing move whilst your frantic clicks can sit and wait.In practice the simultaneous movement with AIs on the field of play quickly becomes irritating - and it starts to warp play into some neurotic twitch fest. It's not the first game to implement this type of nervous who clicks first simultaneous play, but here, combined with a simplistic "IS IT OK FOR ME TO ATTACK NOW" state AI, it can often prove enormously frustrating.Fortunately simulaneous movement is optional.Non simultaneous movement then goes back to the tedious me go you go turn order. But at least you can go out explore something and be home for tea without the griefing AI kicking your door down mid journey. Well. Mostly.The second flaw to the game is that towns don't have an implicit defence. That is to say, if a town is empty, anyone can just walk in and take it. Sound reasonable ? Sure. What's the problem ? Remember that hair trigger wait for you to move "IS IT OK TO ATTACK NOW" AI ? It's still here. And as soon as you even look like you are leaving somewhere empty or under strength, then with annoying regularity the AI marches an army up. I couldn't swear to it, but the AI also has an uncanny knack to "know" when you have left somewhere light, and proceeds to quickly march from over the horizon to its target goal. Meh.In practice with the AI staring you down waiting for you to set a single foot outside your door, you end up with the gratuitous full army stack just sitting kicking its heels defending a town. FOR THE REST OF THE GAME. You can see why many games just abstract city defence away, as it's a no brainer you want to always defend a city.But maybe you're ok with that. Seeing a stack of troops in every town, and the maintenance of them - the retiring of old redundant units, the creating of new  better ones, and the whines from their heroes as they slowly level up, and the movement difficulties getting around that fat stack is fine. No problem.Third flaw in the game. Unit balance. As you proceed up your tech tree, most units become pretty much worse than useless. In fact, if you are not spamming out your top tier units, then you're probably doing it wrong. And if those low tier units do engage those high tier ones ? Splat. Well ! That's just the march of progress ! That's to be expected ! Except it's kind of broken here. In something like Civ your units in the field will get dragged through the ages with an upgrade - that unit of Warriors you've had kicking around since 4000BC are now some fancy 20th century Infantrymen. And you will no longer be able to produce those ancient warriors. In AoW there is no such handling. Those idiot Tier I guys will still be walking around. Sucking up resources. Bloating out stacks. And you can go right on producing those stick wielding primitives right into the era of "space travel" - the highest tiers. Which is kind of pointless. And irritating. So for all those fancy units, it ends up just a race for the highest tier - with a few exceptions. The subtleties of rock paper scissors are quickly washed away in a My Tank beats EVERYTHING you have.Fourth flaw in the game, and this really does spoil the game, is the nature of the AI. The AI is the worst kind of griefing AI - the kind of player that will happily sit there and repeat play the same chequers move until eternity, just so they stop you winning. It's a sad fact that to placate the human player customer base, an AI has to sometimes take the higher road, the non optimal choice and  break out of that loop of incessant taunting moves. In AoW the AI has no such good sportsmanship tendencies and will happily bounce armies back and forth as you trigger each AI decision tree. Move to the left ? Your enemy to the right will charge. Move to the right ? Your enemy to the left will charge. Quickly go back the other direction ? Your enemies will mirror your move. Rinse and repeat.So the AI is tricky you think. What's the issue ? You're just whining about a hard AI !The AI is not hard particularly. Just annoying. As are the other issues with the game. All of which combines in a perfect storm to produce a game that after a while becomes just plain irritating. You don't have fun. It becomes like managing an annoying spoiled nephew. Until you question why you are even playing the stupid game, and hell doesn't Civ or Warlock give a  much more enjoyable experience ?And there's the problem. AoW has all the right bits, all the right polish and yet... through a few interesting design choices... manages to trip over and face plant to produce an annoying not quite there game.The irritating aspects of the game do shine through - and until recently another annoying ( And pointless ? ) aspect of game play was an AI that would endlessly spam dispells. Sound tactics ? Sure. Annoying griefy play that tends to break any possible use of global spells ? Yes. It's something that you can see hasn't really been thought about how it plays out. It's an AI which is not good at playing humans - it's good at playing itself.If you were being very harsh, you might almost say someone looked at all the requested things for a 4x, mixed them together and baked for half an hour - but without any clue whatsoever as to what *tastes good*.At its best there is a good game somewhere in AoW. At it's worst its an annoying experience with a minor sprinkling of bugs to spice things up a bit.Personally I am still perservering with it - I like the bits that are good, and it can play for a while as a nice game, on the other hand I really hate the bits that fail, they really jar you out of the game and produce a frustrating, lets go play something else type vibe.

content:
Posted: January 6, 2015
												AOW3 is an empire building game/ combat game with a fantasy theme. On paper, it sounds great; but in reality it isnt massively interesting.  The variety in gameplay comes through the tech trees in both what your cities are producing and on the special abilities that you can impose on your empire. But both trees are relatively short and you can reach the end of both a long way before you end a game. Like a lot of empire building games, the more cities you build, the more tedious it becomes. Sadly, the combat is also repetitive - the same maps with the same enemies in the same positions. It takes a short while to get used to, but once you do, you will be applying the same tactics over and over again.In short, there isnt much to recommend the game. Its not terribly programmed, but there just isnt enough depth to keep you interested.

												Firstly, I am a big fan of the Age of Wonders franchise. However, this game was not entertaining compared to the previous titles. Besides better graphics and a new class, the game does not have that much new content to offer. Every match I found to be repetitive and slow. In previous Age of Wonders games I found each conflict to be new and require unique different ways of playing. In this release, I find myself repeating the same tactics over and over. The story in this game is not exciting and I found myself skipping through it in both campaigns. Overall, I give this game a 5/10. Pick up AoW 2 versus this title. You'll save some money and have a better experience. All in all, this game is not worth the buy.
