content:
Posted: April 26, 2014
												I remember playing Age of Wonders 1 and 2 so long ago.  I can't recall how many hours I dumped into those games, especially the second one.  It was the reinvention of Master of Magic, and I loved it.  You get the great world map combined with many fantastic races and tactical combat on separate maps.  I could not have been happier.  It was the fantasy version of Civilization in many respects.When I saw AoW3, I got anxious.  Finally it released, and I got to play it.  It truly has everything to remind me of the previous versions I loved, and then some.  Random Maps, finally.  Relevant units, yay.AoW3 has random maps.  This seems normal, but previously they did not.  So after a while, it becomes mundane with the same strategies and outcomes per scenario.  You can build cities!  Couldn't do that in the old days.  It was all preset and you took what was already there.  Units are relevant now.  In AoW2 the best strategy was to raze every single building and town you took (except your starting city), then destroy the neutral armies that appeared, and farm all the xp and items you could for your starting hero. He becomes nigh invincible, even to tier 3 units, and has absurd movement with flight, so he can just zoom around the map with a scorched earth strategy.  I have not tried to do this in AoW3, but I suspect it would be ineffective.If you liked the previous games in the series, you will still like this one. I cannot say anything bad about it. It is in line with everything I expected it to have. It stays true to the series, and offers some new things. The only thing it doesn't have, is the number of races that the priors had.  No Dark Elves, no Undead, etc... DLC right?  Seems fine.All that being said, I would go 8/10 if you like the genre or the old games.  Personally, it's a 7 for me, and that is just because although I want to enjoy the battles and fight them manually, they become something of a chore to me and I end up auto'ing most of them, even if its a huge super important fight.  I would not have the patience anymore for multiplayer if people do manual fights, yet the prospect of not having the option to manual fight seems to gut a large aspect of the game's draw for me.So I recommend this game overall, but you mind get a little bored with it if you have leaned towards RTS style games since playing AoW2, and maybe that's not worth the cost of the game for you.  Even so, it's a fine product and I am happy to support it, even if I don't play it as much as I thought I would.  (so many good games these days)

content:
Posted: April 28, 2014
												This game is a puzzle. Not a puzzler game - it is a jigsaw of likes and disklikes. It has medicore graphics (both models and effects), sound gets a bit annoying at times and the creator of the UI could learn a lot from authors of those implemented f.e. in Might and Magic Heroes VI. BUT!The research is quite fun. The magic is awesome (and I mean owesome in an old style way; if you played Master of Magic, you'd know what i maen) and the resource system is simple and neat. Also you have bazzilion of skills for your heroes (because when they lvl up, you can experience a point based skill buying system - and it's good IMO) and the number of units in game is sick.The way the map is composed is known from titles such as Civ and other 4X fantasy themed games, BUT it also contains ruins, vaults, ancient burial ground, dragon lairs, mana sources, all sort of "pick me up" goodies and more.Conclusion: at first I hesitated even considering the game worth playing. But now, after some hours into it I'm happy I have it. If there would be a scale to judge the quality of a game, I would give it a strong 78 out of 100. AND if the devs get to work and create some patches fixing the UI and animation glitches - it will be much more.

												Update: As I play it more I must say I think the patches have been critical for the longevity of this game. The 5 stacks of T4 rush was getting a bit annoying. Finally: I must admit I am missing some of the Empire management somewhat more than I thought. Still a great game and better than W2. Tact battles are really neat. More like HoMM than Civ. Cons: Tech tree is very confusing as there is no tree/path to follow. Just a book with stuff. Needs some minor fixes with next hero, city, etc... BUt they got the big things right. Wish diplomacy and Empire management were more fleshed out a tiny bit and alternate path to victory was there (End game spell). Overall a very solid game and look forward to the minor issues being fixed by patches.

There's only one or two end game unit available per game and because theyre strongest, the AI spams this strongest unit available so all you see after a certain point is armies of the same dude.What better strategy than to survive til late game and then spam shadows who each have a 80% damage reduction buff and just bulldoze everyone else?That said, the running around map explorations and leveling your heros and collecting treasures is pretty satisfying.The big big battles involving multiple full-stacked units is too, when you finally decide to stop adventuring and actually ending the game.Would I buy this base game at full price $30 again? Probably not, truth be told, but definitely on discount. And, with the DLCs for sure. The game is jarringly upfront about it being incomplete (smirks at you for only having the base game).I'm going to buy those DLCs now. Can't stand another sight of the cat and necromancers pictures knowing full well I can't play those (yet).

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 5, 2014
												Age of Wonders III is utterly amazing.My view may be skewed due to putting 100+ hours into the original, but for newcomers to the series I highly recommend this title. The game play is 4X (eXplore, eXpand, eXploit, and eXterminate) much like the Civilization or Heroes of Might and Magic series. The game is set in a high fantasy world ripe with monstrous creatures, dungeons and undead armies. When playing a map (either a scenario, the campaign, or a randomly generated map) you start with a leader unit who, in scenarios or random maps, you create yourself and usually a small army based on one of the five races that you can choose with a city or a city building unit to start your empire. Your leader can level up as they defeat enemies with your armies and gain points to put into unique abilities based on their class and their offensive and defensive statistics. These abilities will help bolster the armies that they lead and push you ever closer to victory. The infantry units you command also gain experience and levels up to four but their abilities and stats are predetermined. Also based on the previously mentioned class and the actions you take to solidify an alignment, either good or evil, are the spells that you research along the way which is reminiscent of technology from the Civ franchise.Along your journey you will more than likely run across heroes that will offer to join you, these characters are much like your leader, they level up the same, they gain abilities based on their class, and they are meant to lead armies. The big difference being that if you lose one of these heroes they are gone, much like other units in your army. Your leader will respawn at your throne city, assuming it's still standing, after a few turns but their friends will not. This makes the battles intense and the losses devastating. The battles are turn based on a hex map based on whatever landscape you're occupying and these maps are gorgeous. They really give you a look at the landscapes that your troops are marching through.The class system mentioned above is a change to the series that after experiencing I can say is welcome. There are very distinct ways that each class works from the technology based, steam punkesque Dreadnaught to the classic magic juggernaut that is the Sorcerer. The Theocrat leads through belief and divine retribution with their crusaders, leading holy wars against their heretical enemies while the Rogue leads through deception, riots, and stealth. The Archdruid taps into the power of nature, summoning animal companions and nature elementals to their side while the Warlord rampages their armies with limited use of magic, ruling through blood, and battle.  Overall the game is a very unique and very fun experience. The soundtrack is breathtakingly beautiful with a few songs being a throwback to the original. Clearly I don't write reviews for a living (I know. "Too many commas." "Where's the sentence structure?") but I feel like if I were to Age of Wonders would get a 5/5, 10/10, or 100/100. The only gripe I could make is the lack of a few races from the previous games but that's nothing that an expansion or two won't fix. That, and the fact that I can't buy the collectors edition of the game. But life goes on. I'll be spending hours of mine in the Age of Wonders.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 4, 2014
												Combines the things you love about Civilization, XCOM and Heroes of Might and Magic. For strategy and Fantasy fans, this game is the apex. It doesn't get better than this, ladies and gentlemen. Saddle up for the most fun you can have as a dwarf this side of Mordor! A shining example of 4X strategy. eXplore a gorgeous fantasy world, eXpand your city and the land under your control, eXploit a diplomacy/morale/alignment system to suit your playstyle and eXterminate your opposition in glorious all-out war. Want to send a flamespitting tank against a soaring dragon? you'll lose the tank, but that opportunity is yours to take! A surprisingly deep customization system lets you make a unique hero that affects the units available to you in fun and interesting ways. You WILL have fun playing this game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 4, 2014
												I don't see what all the griping is about.  This is a top notch game!  I have loved AOW since my buddy got in on the beta test when Epic was just a 2bit company.  AOW III could have more in it from Wizards Throne (AOW II) , but I am trusting Triumph to get a good amount of DL content.  This game kills HOMM, and Fallen Enchantress.  It was the first game to utilize the Underworld, and Environmental spell effects.  While they have borrowed a little too much from HOMM and dumb down some of the dimensional combat, it's still a great game, could it be better?  Yes, but it is worth the money.  A Huge map will keep you busy for a few days.  The longer you play, in my estimate the more you will get into the mechanics and the depth of the game.  You can choose your own destiny Evil or Good, it all depends on whether you want to slaughter a bunch of friendly nymphs and ferries or make peace with everyone.  Graphics are good, not great but the game play makes up for everything.  If you enjoy HOMM (Hero's of Might and Magic) or Fallen Enchantress then get this game.  You won't regret it.

content:
Posted: May 30, 2014
												Age of wonders 3 is a turnbased strategygame, with some basebuilding but with a heavy focus on exploration and combat. The look, feel and even some gamemechanics of the game draws heavily upon game like Civilization, Warlock and Heroes of might and magic, wich makes for a easy start into the game, if you are just a bit familiar with these titles. The game offers huge maps to explore, with a lot of sidequest, powerups and "dungeons". The terran does impact things like movement and combatwill of your units/armies, as well as the output of certain cities upgrades and even the area in wich combat takes place. The game offers very different ways of upgrading the skills of your heroes, as well as your spells (combat and world) and it really feels like every decision have an impact on the gameplay.Flaws and bugs are few in numbers and rarely more than an slight irritation and never a deal breaker. Definately worth your time and money, if you're into strategy, rpg and empirebuilding.

												Updated: Eternal LordsNow, after the second expansion, Age of Wonders surpassed Crusaders Kings as the game I had played the most, so I could say it is now a great game.I would say it plays like Magic the gathering, if you throw away all that silliness about cards and instead you are a Powerful Ruler, with scores of fantasy armies to command and fanatasy enemies to conquer!-----At first I didn't like nor disliked this game; I thought it had some neat ideas but that didn't quite worked. I would literally fall asleep playing the game.Maybe I didn't "get" it at first, now that I bought The Golden Realms expansion and tried it again. The game looks a lot more solid. content:
Posted: November 10, 2015
												Fantastic game.  A wonderful game for fantasy turn-based strategy gamers.  A rich fantasy world on the strategy map, plus a rich turn-based tactical combat.  It has a feeling of high quality throughout.  As I write this it is version 1.704 with two expansions, so there has been a lot of polishing.  There is sufficient richness to keep it totally aborbing at both the strategic map and tactical map levels.  I always get the "I want to take one more turn" feeling from this game.  It's like living in a rich fantasy world of the imagination.  I like this type of game more than the strategic map only games such as Fallen Enchantress, Sorcerer King, or Endless Legend.  I respect those games, but I find I spend my time playing this one.  A nice tutorial campaign and a searchable tome of knowledge make this game accessible to new  players such as myself.  A tip of the hat to the developer, Triumph Studios.  I'm won over as a fan of this game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 19, 2016
												Great game for those who like turn based combat with a high fantasy setting.There are many races (human, goblin, elves, etc.) that you can combine with different classes (rouge, socerer, dreadnought, etc.) and then with a specialization (fire, water, creation, destruction, etc.).Each combination requires different strategies and plays very unique.I personally enjoyed playing as an air specialized frostling nacromancer (DLC), where I convert the whole land into ice field, turn enemies into ghouls, and march the land with an army of undead.  There more death the more powerful a nacromancer.The presentation of the game is very good and very polished.The single player campaign is a bit lacking, as the random map mode is where this game shines (similar to Civilization 5).  Unlike Civilization series, Age of Wonders 3 focus on combat in a tatical map.The tatical maps are very detailed and reflect the tiles of the strategic map that the units were on.Units have many abilities.  Player can also have hero units with RPG upgrade elements.There are only very basic diplomacy and empire building, but the battle is where this game produce the most enjoyment.The DLCs are also very wonderful and included new races to play that really expanded the experience of this game.If you like high fantasy settings (dragons, trolls, goblins, dwarves, elves, kights, magic and so on), then do give this game a try.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 24, 2016
												I have been playing alot of RTS and 4X games lately. This one is actually my favorite. The campaign is rather challenging, but the random scenarios are great for having a more relaxed game. I especially love the unit diversity among the races, as well as the various special units you get access to for building capture, as well as summoned units based on class. The hero units are also well done with great variety. Not only would i recommend this game on sale as well as full price, but i would have been willing to pay $60 for it if i knew how good it was. Fortunately no one will have to.I have never played the earlier games in the series, but i will defintly throw money at a 4th Age of Wonders if it is anywhere near this good.

content:
Posted: September 29, 2014
												If you're a fan of the Age of Wonders series you probably already own this. If you don't, what are you waiting for?It's good, don't worry!If you're completely new to this francise however, this choice is a more difficult one. This game is hexbased, turbased, fantasy, strategy game with rpg elements. If you didn't run aways screaming at those words, this game may be for you. The genre itself is a bit niche, but within it's genre, it's very good. It features:-  a very indepth combat system- quite deep city building (though no where near CIV5 standards)- Incredible addictive and timesinking gameplay (very high replayabillity)- Cool graphics- Unique classes (they differ a lot in terms of strategy and gameplay)- continuous updates (golden gates is already out, now we are waiting for the undead to arrive) On the downside however- Steep learningcurve- Difficult AI (which is simultaniously a good thing, the ai is pretty smart)- Uninteresting story (highfanasty qualms, order of quartidoudle, counsil of ziyrlotsofletters blahblah)- slow pacing (one lvl from a campaign will require mutiple hours if not a few days to complete.- the morality system feels iffy and doesn't add much.tl;dr: All in all I think it's a very good game if you're not scared away by long sessions, difficult AI and high fantasy drama

content:
Posted: September 22, 2014
												This game is a wonderful continuation for a long-time fan of Age of Wonders.  It polishes up what was lacking in the previous games while also bringing in welcome changes such as removing forced alignment from players and new spells.However, one of the most glaring issues with this game is that it suffers from you not buying the entire game.  While this isn't a severe problem for this game specifically compared to other games, it will not be as complete as older games.  There are not as much races (you can complete the race splash by buying DLC), not as much content, not as much pre-made scenarios, etc. than the previous games.  It feels like the game was intentionally cut up to serve the players the rest of the content with DLC.If you can live with the DLC, this is a fantastic game to buy.

												This game is great it has alot of cool fetures but hear are a few things i think would make this game even better:-More races, there are so many great fictional races you could have made optional in this game i hope to see more in future dlc. e.g you could make fish like creatures that could be the only race able to inhabit water tiles and a special unit could be cuthullu, mermaids (when touches a ship could ever fead or convert to your side unless a legend is present), you could also make this race weaker on land.-More detailed customisation, to be honest when i got to making my legend i got really disapointed as i was met by around about 3 face types and 3 clothing options for the human race as a male rouge. none of the faces even fit the charcter they all looked like middle aged men that spent their life in the pub, i wanted my guy to look like a young rouge with side swept hair who spent his time going inn to inn looking for some quick gold and hunted his own food.-More Diplomacy, when i made an aligence with an allies enemy i was no longer trusted and i could never win back that trust also it would be nice to convince each side to lay down their arms and be at peace or even make an alligence for the greater good.-Little things, you could make an option in game to send out a Job offer to legends letting you specify what you want (rouge, dreadnaught, warlord e.t.c.) this could cost more if you want, don't dispose of my spells if there is too much just make an extra page, Let the giant race expand and grow and provide more options for them and any other race you guys have done this to. 												Did you or do you love the Heroes Might and Magic games?!Did you or do you love the Disciples games?! (I have heard bade things about Ressurection so ignore that one!)Then you will LOVE this game! Do not fret so much on the people talking so negatively about this game.If you love long hours for one game (I have been playing the second campain mission for days now. Yea its that intense)building or taking over cities to widen your territory for more resources, and intense turn-based battles (or auto-battle), get this game! It has the large maps of Heroes, with the army formations of Disciples--- (6 whatevers per army including heroes and its not quantity like the 'zongz' or 'hordes' in Heroes, only one each unit (althought there can be 1,3, or 6 "people" in one unit formation)and instead of changing like they do in Disciples, they "level up" and get stronger.)--- while adding its own spin. You can make builders and settlers that make roads, cities, forts, and watchtowers. Its own spells and such.Like Heroes you have all kinds of spells you can research and use (although you do not have to build a mage guild). Unlike Heroes you do not "go into" a city, a panel just pops up and you select it. Although the city look does change over time. Sort of like a TW 2 Rome, where little houses spread out around it. So who really wants to read every little detail. You can go watch Youtube vidoes of actaul gameplay right? Games like these arnt for gamers who want a Ryse Rome kind of game. A salute my fellow, slowly take over every inch of the map and clear it out, plus build it all up how you want, gamers! Go Warcraft 1-3 and BFME games XDI will say, at first I regretted buying this. OMG why did I buy this when I can just play my Disciples II and have basically the same thing. HA! Discpiles is (while I have not played the new one from this year (2014..drool....) no where near as intense and LONG (again think Heroes!) as AoW. Granted it is limited. Each race has the exact same building, and each unit while looks, attributes and powers are different, each tier or class (Tier 1 Calvary or Tier 3 Archer) is comparribly the same. If you want a good, intense, in depth fighting game that you can or want to spend huge amount of time ------- (I have put in 17.5 hours as I post this, maybe 2 of which was on the first mission, the rest on the second campain mission AND I am only half way through the map....well the top level anyhow ;) I have barely done anything on the under level. OH I FORGOT! With builders or special units like the giant beetle you can 'dig; through certain walls and explore more, while more or less combining the whole under level....be careful you arnt the only one who can :P)-------- get this game!Even do like me and put it on your wishlist and wait for a sale.Hope this helped. Feel free to ask any questions to me!If you do not know what Heroes is OR Discplis. Go explore and enjoy:) Trust me. You will love it.

content:
Posted: September 28, 2014
												This title reminds me of the Heros of Might and Magic series and has many similarities to it.  Fans of it will likely enjoy Age of Wonders as well.  It improves on the familiar formula with ideas from other strategy games such as cities which expand over time and generate income from resources withing their spheres of infulence.  Unlike Heroes you are able to estlablish new cities on the map as well as fortifications and road networks.  Armies made up completely of flying units are able to cross lakes and mountains and terraforming spells can improve your territory or ruin your enemy's, effecting the morale of cities, which have terrian preferences and dislikes depending on their racial characteristics.  A unified research system unlocks new spells, units, traits, abilities, etc.  Like heroes the map has an overworld and underworld providing difficult stategic oppertunities for surprise attacks and shortcuts.  Unlike Heros, multiple armies in adjactent hexes can participate in the same battle for epic scale combat and seige warfare.  Multiple unique army leaders can band together into a fighting unit along with expendable military units in groupings of up to six, and will fight alongside their troops in battle as cavalry units capable of both ranged and melee attacks as well as spells and special abilities.  Leaders also gain experience and can be improved with increased stats and other perks upon leveling up.  Familiar fantasy races compete in this setting such as Elves, Orcs, Draconians, Dwarves, and Undead, amoung others.  Two campains are available with the game as well as custom maps and multiplayer options.

												I really thought this game was  letdown.  Sorry, Triumph, but what I liked about this game series was the epic-level wizardry, and you've totally dumbed it down.  It really all comes down to the downgrade from domain-level spell to city-level.  Now you cast the same spell over and over, only to have the compy players dispel it randomly around your empire.  The troops are all weaker, too.  Playing daconians?  No red dragons for you.  Your best unit is now... flyers.  Yay.  It's like they cut the best options out and then expect you to be happier with  the stupid bottom tier troops.  Oh, and your wizard (or whatever) is now just another hero.Maybe you'll get some of the old awesomeness back with an expansion or something, but right now, though, if you're looking for an epic sequel.  Look elsewhere.  This is decidedly NOT epic.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 22, 2014
												Short Version: The game looks gorgeous, has tons of replayability with a solid battle AI, and some of the most fun tactial battles of any game I can think of.  If you want fantasy battles look no further.Longer Version: A lot of people compare this game to Fallen Enchantress or Civ, and I think that comparison does very little justice to any of the games involved.  All three games are 4X games in that you can explore, exploit, expand, and exterminate enemies, but have very different focuses.  In general, Civilization games thrive on the first three "x"s but have awful, boring warfare.  Fallen Enchantress is well-rounded, with decent battles and interesting RPG mechanics, but ultimately leaves a lot of the exploitation to be desired.  AoW 3 would be at the extreme opposite Civ: the battles are great, and, nominally, so are the other x's, but there is very little to do with any resource except use it to eXterminate.  The good news is that battles are a lot of fun with dozens of well-balanced, interesting units and lots of great spells.

content:
Posted: September 23, 2014
A great fantasy strategy gameAlthough I think this game doesn't fully capture the "wonders" part of the old Age of Wonders it's a great addition to the modern fantasy strategy genre. This is primarily a quibble on the look of the game based on versions 1 & 2. Particularly in the strategic map, I feel that the new version lacks on a certain visual feedback that the old ones had that made them look more woundrous and magical than the new version does. You may not agree with me on this, and that's fine, it really doesn't affect the gameplay.The hero creation is interesting and varied, and the hero that leads your army has a significant impact on gameplay as the units/spells available vary depending on your choices. There are interesting items you can get, including a variety of mounts. I still wish this part was a bit more fleshed out, but it's still enough to make that part of the game interesting.Large campaign maps take forever and a day to complete, which sounds great but I still have yet to finish one. I've spent very little time in the game's campaign, I usually just play random maps.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 23, 2014
												To those who love games like Final Fantasy Tactics, Tactics Ogre, XCOM, etc..., I would highly recommend this game. It takes the core elements of great tactics style RPGs, and throws them inside a slightly simplified empire building game a la Civilization V.I can acknowledge that the strategic portion of the game lacks some of the depth that can be found in the most hardcore strategy games, but I do not feel this is a flaw. One of the greatest games ever devised, Chess, has only 6 unique pieces, and in its standard style of play, only allows for 1v1 competition. There is a delightfully simple elegance to the units and technologies available in AoWIII (which offer many more choices than Chess). Taken from a purely turn-based strategy game perspective, they would seem shallow compared to the game's peers, but in the context of a deep turn-based tactical RPG (with heroes levelling from 1-30, earning skill points to allocate each level, and spells to research, and gear to equip) it is plenty complex enough.My favorite thing about this game is how amazingly stable my multiplayer experience has been.  My first time launching online multiplayer, it checked my connectivity rating, and told me it was poor due to firewall settings. I clicked a link provided in-game, and in a totally crisp and not buggy fashion, minimized my client and sent me to the company's help page, wherein I was given the neccessary port to forward. I did so, had the game check again, and was good to go. A friend and I have long searched for a good co-operative tactical RPG experience. The best I have yet found was FFT: The Lion War for PSP. It's a shame that a hand-held game system has trumped PC for so long in this niche. XCOM lacks co-op campaign functionality, Eador is horribly buggy and unstable, and the others I've tried are all crumby. In AoWIII, I've found that harmonious combination of enjoyable gameplay and completely (and I mean 8 straight hours of addictive, no crashes or disconnections) stable multiplayer.Watch some videos of this game and decide if it suits your interests, but as for my opinion, I can give this one an A+.

content:
Posted: February 16, 2016
												Where do I start...let me first say this game has definitely bkown away my expectations and what a turn based game should be. I have been a follower of the Heroes of Might and Magic series since the beginning. Developers at the Heroes camp need to take a page out of this book and use it. The biggest thing I like about this game is the option to ally with either a human or AI opponent and then play on whatever map you like. There are no restrictions to this at all. Just like in Civ games where all the options are open and you create the game for how you want to play. Same thing here. Being able to go around the map with your hero and its accompanied army just seeking out riches and enemy armies is so cool. Also your allies can travel with you and go into battle with you. First time I have ever seen that implemented into a game before. Juat imagine taking on a enemy faction along with your buddy online or hotseat taking on whatever came your way. Casting spells and supporting each other. This game does it right. I recommend to anyone this series of games. Plus two huge dlc addons available as well. Can't wait to take anothwr turn!

content:
Posted: April 14, 2016
												If you like games like the Civilization series, or the Heroes of Might & Magic series, and are hankering for a new high-fantasy strategy game to play, do yourself a favor and check this game out! This was my first experience with the Age of Wonders series, I was looking through the Steam store for something new, saw it and decided to give it a go. I didn't expect much given the usual quality of today's games but man was I surprised!Here is my pros and cons list based on my experience playing the base game, I haven't bought the expansion packs yet but I definitely plan to.Pros : - Challenging gameplay that requires you to think ahead, as well as think quickly on your feet.- Good AI.- Wide variety of fantasy creatures to go up against, or enlist in your own army.- Active modding community on the Steam Workshop.- Beautiful visuals.- Large arsenal of spells, abilities, upgrades and equipment that make each Leader feel unique.- Nice soundtrack that does a good job of adding to the immersion.- A character creation system that offers a good deal of customization for this sort of game.- Boatloads of replayability.Cons : - Some units and abilities seem rather imbalanced, but nothing gamebreaking.- Challenge can sometimes ramp up drastically.- Cities could use a bit more diversity, while it is possible to have a city that is specialized in performing a certain role, I haven't yet found that to be necessary and as a result all my cities have pretty much had the same buildings. I think this could have been improved by making a tech-tree for cities so you would have to decide what you want that city's main purpose to be. But, since the game is focused more on armies and combat rather than city building, this isn't a huge deal.- Very few visual changes on your Leaders and Heroes in regard to their equipment, the only items that change your appearance are your mount and your weapon. This is more of a personal desire and not so much something the game did wrong,  it IS a strategy game after all and would require alot of effort to implement. but still, I was a bit let down when I looted a very awesome looking helmet and chest piece only to find that it didn't affect my appearance. Once again, not a huge deal though.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 10, 2016
												Age of Wonders III is an incredibly fun, turn-based strategy game that is formed around its "deep fantasy" theme. Rather than progressing through a series of eras, as other popular turn-based, world-domination strategy games do, this game puts the player in charge of one of many fantasy races and it is the player's job to push their people to victory.One mechanical element that draws me to this game, and one that is fairly unique to AoW3 (as far as I know), is the tactical hex-based combat. Unlike the Civilization series (which I also recommend), AoW3 allows players to take direct control over their armies when they are engaged in combat with enemy forces. Instead of forcing an odds-based animation and resolution of the battle (which is still an option, but not required), the game allows players to enter into a battlefield that is generated based on the terrain types of the embattled hex as well as its special features and those of the neighboring hexes. This provides tactically savvy players the opportunity to achieve satisfying victories in the face of almost guaranteed auto-resolve defeats.Another element of the game that I find quite satisfying is the ability to create your own hero character who serves as your civilization's leader for the duration of the game. There are a significant number of races, classes, and looks based on each of those that players can choose from, and there's even a rudimentary skill selection process for your leader that can help players who want to lead their race by pursuing a certain playstyle during their game. These leader units not only represent your race in diplomatic encounters with other players, but they also serve as actual, usable units on the battlefield that can lead players' forces to gallant victories (or crushing defeats).The base game has a lot to explore for new players, so definitely start with that if you're just trying the game out. Once you get the hang of it, and also develop an inevitable liking for the game, I would highly recommend the DLC that introduces new races and campaigns. This DLC adds to the already numerous choices for leaders, races, and playstyles, and should give players who like the campaigns many more hours of content to play through.

content:
Posted: May 25, 2016
												I must say that my first impression when playing this game was not very positive. It seemed to me that the focus was too heavily on battles, and that the game was forcing every turn the player to do some actions dictated by the progress of the cities, rise of new heroes, etc. I felt a general lack of freedom. But playing again after some time (and a couple of expansions) I have changed my mind. This is a very well done game, and I tend to agree with someone saying that this is one of the best modern successors of the venerable Master of Magic. Extremely good game for those who love fantasy turn-based strategy, with a large variety of troops and spells, and challenging AI players.

Also a little frustrating when my hero doesn't get disjunction to research during a random game but oh well makes for a challenge.

content:
Posted: April 5, 2014
												The game has great promise and is initially fun to play.  The campaigns are kind of fun.  There is no real story behind the campaigns, from what I've seen so far.  The graphics are very good.  However, after several games played through to the end, you will find that they all wind up coming down to the same thing, a bunch of the same types of units slugging it out.The game only has about 2 dozen playable units, but they changed the names slightly (depending on race) and changed the appearance.  Example Dwarf Manticore Rider, Draconian Manticore Rider, Elven Manticore Rider.  They all have almost the same stats, but look different.  The racial differences are too insignificant to make a difference.  The spells and traits, although there are many types, are for the most part not enough to make up for the overwhelming power of Tier IV and above units.  You can use different battle tactics, such as flanking, and get a bonus on your attack.  Currently, wounded units fight at full strength.  Heroes are limited in how many can be acquired in the game, but you can have as many other units as you can afford.The balance is horrible overall.Instead of creating a complex version of Rock, Paper, Scissors, they made it so it is just a bunch of Rocks fighting it out.  The rocks all look different!  But they are still Rocks.Every high quality strategic and tactical game out there is designed in such a way that the units/skills/abilities/spells are either complimentary to one another, or a counter to one another.  These high quality games have tremendous depth because there are so many options in how the game is played.  They understand that there should be strengths and weaknesses to almost all choices.  If, for example, I rushed in with a bunch of tanks I would get chewed up by the anti-tank helocoptors, which are themselves weak to anti-air units, etc.  AOW III does not really do this.  Instead it is a slug fest between the hardest hitting, high hitpoint units.  Basically, it's just a bunch of tanks fighting it out.  Booorrring.I really want to like this game...*Update* I'm still playing it, bugs and all.  Until they balance the game better and offer more depth, I will continue to give it a thumbs down.

content:
Posted: February 27, 2016
												Age of Wonders 3 is an excellent 4X strategy game that is hard to learn, but rewarding to play. Compared to other games of it's type, AW3 offers a much deeper combat system and a wide veriety of strategies and compositions. If you have a lot of spare time, love/are interested in grand strategy titles, and/or like the themes of traitional medieval fantacy, I would highly reccomend this game.Pros:- Excellent turn based combat system that favors strategy over raw stats- Races and Classes feel unique to play and favor sometimes wildly different strategies. Lots of options.- Optional, yet deep, character customization.- The world is fun to explore - and very rewarding. There's always something productive to do.- DLC adds game changing elements that are worth investing in if you enjoy the base game- You CAN add more races into your empire, leading to even more wild compositions- Campaign mode offers a more flavorful world, and each unit has a flavorful story tied to it. World is more immersive.Cons:- Some race/class combinations are much weaker than others.- Tutorial is very bad - game is hard to learn, and harder to understand.- Campaign maps favor rush tatics over late game strategies. Also, unfathomable gaps exist between difficult levels (easy being almost braindead, and normal being infuriatingly hard.)- Barebones diplomacy system. - The base game its all about domination. Mre options are availible with DLC, but I would advise rushing to buy something if you don't know whether or not its right for you.- Cities lack much thematic diversity, are like the diplomatic system are more barebone.- No "just one more turn" button.I give Age of Wonders 3 a 9/10. Its pros outweigh almost all of its cons, and with a more in depth diplomacy system and optional post victory gameplay, it could easily have earned a 10/10 from me.

content:
Posted: May 25, 2016
												Age of Wonders III is in many ways the true successor to Master of Magic. The overworld and spell research sections are very good, with plenty of options for replayability and difficult choices. But where the game really shines is in the tactical battles. The wide variety of units and abilities ensures that there is always a new factor to force you to change your pattern. The is also a multiplayer scene, if after you've finished the (extensive!) single-player campaigns and want to face some real challenges!Last, the sound design and art are top-notch. Those sorts of things are easy to overlook, but they can really make a difference!

content:
Posted: May 26, 2016
												I've always enjoyed the AoW series, having spent enormous amounts of time playing and crafting maps in the previous versions. Alongside with HoMM, AoW made a definite game where exploring the map, killing monsters and conquering cities was greatly enjoyable. The variance between races and magic (somewhat) allowed for different playstyles. In AoW3, this all seems to be expanded to greater degree, with even more variance to the races due to the different hero types.The only thing that I've always felt was lacking was magic. Compared to an another old time classic, Masters of Magic, where you could raise volcanoes, corrupt the land and blight enemy cities, the spell selection seems limited and rather straightforward. Of course, in MoM, one could actually select their wizards starting spell-books from different domains of magic and even expand their library through hard challenges. But besides this single small thing, the series still seems enjoyable.While writing this, I've played the main game and have continued somewhat into the first expansion, where I'm currently stuck. I loathe to downgrade the difficulty from hard, so lets see how long this takes.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 5, 2014
												Age of Wonders III is utterly amazing.My view may be skewed due to putting 100+ hours into the original, but for newcomers to the series I highly recommend this title. The game play is 4X (eXplore, eXpand, eXploit, and eXterminate) much like the Civilization or Heroes of Might and Magic series. The game is set in a high fantasy world ripe with monstrous creatures, dungeons and undead armies. When playing a map (either a scenario, the campaign, or a randomly generated map) you start with a leader unit who, in scenarios or random maps, you create yourself and usually a small army based on one of the five races that you can choose with a city or a city building unit to start your empire. Your leader can level up as they defeat enemies with your armies and gain points to put into unique abilities based on their class and their offensive and defensive statistics. These abilities will help bolster the armies that they lead and push you ever closer to victory. The infantry units you command also gain experience and levels up to four but their abilities and stats are predetermined. Also based on the previously mentioned class and the actions you take to solidify an alignment, either good or evil, are the spells that you research along the way which is reminiscent of technology from the Civ franchise.Along your journey you will more than likely run across heroes that will offer to join you, these characters are much like your leader, they level up the same, they gain abilities based on their class, and they are meant to lead armies. The big difference being that if you lose one of these heroes they are gone, much like other units in your army. Your leader will respawn at your throne city, assuming it's still standing, after a few turns but their friends will not. This makes the battles intense and the losses devastating. The battles are turn based on a hex map based on whatever landscape you're occupying and these maps are gorgeous. They really give you a look at the landscapes that your troops are marching through.The class system mentioned above is a change to the series that after experiencing I can say is welcome. There are very distinct ways that each class works from the technology based, steam punkesque Dreadnaught to the classic magic juggernaut that is the Sorcerer. The Theocrat leads through belief and divine retribution with their crusaders, leading holy wars against their heretical enemies while the Rogue leads through deception, riots, and stealth. The Archdruid taps into the power of nature, summoning animal companions and nature elementals to their side while the Warlord rampages their armies with limited use of magic, ruling through blood, and battle.  Overall the game is a very unique and very fun experience. The soundtrack is breathtakingly beautiful with a few songs being a throwback to the original. Clearly I don't write reviews for a living (I know. "Too many commas." "Where's the sentence structure?") but I feel like if I were to Age of Wonders would get a 5/5, 10/10, or 100/100. The only gripe I could make is the lack of a few races from the previous games but that's nothing that an expansion or two won't fix. That, and the fact that I can't buy the collectors edition of the game. But life goes on. I'll be spending hours of mine in the Age of Wonders.

content:

												This game is a true strategy game, a wonder that combines hex-based strategy with city managment and the growing of heros. The game has a good campaign, although the multiplayer and the skirmishes are better. It also features leader creation, so you can build multiple leaders from any of the playable races in the game.The game also features a class system, which with regards to your heros, means they get skills based on their class. With regards to your leader, they also get skills, but this also determines what types of units you can build.The game has some seriousness to it, be it the evil necromancers, wanting to bring the world to the apocolypse, with the help of undead dragons, reapers, and fallen angels, to the holy theocrats who want to bring peace to the world. The game also has some sillyness to it, tameing fairies and dire penguins, and other ridiculous creatures.I would truly recommend this game, it is sure to bring you hours of fun, both by yourself and with your friends!

												A combination of 4X and a hex based tactics game. This game focuses on fantasty style combat. It is good for people who like to play warmongers in games like civ.Pros:Customization. Do you want to play tree hugging dwarves? Why not? An evil elf cleric. Sure.Battlefield tactics. When armies meet, turns into a turn based tactics game.Simplified magnagment. No tax rates to worry about. City management is important, but not nearly as time intensive as in Civ games.Game options. Want your heroes to be come back if they die? (as long as you win the combat) there is an option for that. Hate underground? Turn it off. Lots of monsters? No monsters? Everyone starts with a large pile of gold, a well developed city, and a huge army? okCreate your own leaders.Cons:Campaigns are boring. 400 hours in and I still haven't bothered to beat them all.A bit of a learning curve. It takes a bit to learn the game. There are lots of units and roaming monsters can get quite powerful if you never destroy thier dens.This game ruined a lot of other 4X games for me. Whenever I start playing those, I always come back to this one.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 22
												For all of you Civilization and Heroes of Might & Magic fans (full disclosure, I used to be a fan of both), this is your game.  I went back and played both HOMM3 and 5, as well as Civ V for comparison.  There is none.  You will never play either again because Age of Wonders III eclipses them by a significant amount.  In every area.  I will go into detail.Age of Wonders III (AOWIII) is a turn-based empire builder with turn-based combat.  Think a total war game (in terms of empire building) but with turn-based RPG combat (rather than real-time combat).  You have heros and gain experience based on your combat success.  This is how your units also level up and get stronger.  AOWIII features the use of magic, items for your heros and the development of your cities.This game is absolutely incredible!  There is a ton of depth and significant replay value.  There are a bunch of different races (all with their own special abilities and shortcomings, Human, High Elf, Draconian, Dwarf, etc.) as well as classes of hero (Sorcerer, Warlord, Theocrat, etc.).  Terrain is hugely important as is morale.  You must research spells, build units or buildings in your cities, explore the world and use diplomacy with those you encounter.  There are dungeons as well as special resource nodes to boost and aid your empire.  You can hire heros and summon monsters and animals.  Spells can be researched and there are a bunch of different paths you can take with these.  Do you want global spells that can affect the map or your towns, or should you focus on combat spells to obliterate your enemies during combat?  The beauty is you can do both.The turn-based combat is really amazing (similar to Endless Legend).  I have fought so many battles and each one is still unique.  Every time I think I have a handle on it, I get destroyed in a battle and must go back to the drawing board.  AOWIII is easy to play but difficult to master.  It can be challenging on the lowest levels and extremely difficult on the higher levels.  The combat is so deep because of the depth of different units and races, incredible variety of heroes in terms of both class and race, and the unique advantages/disadvantages that terrain poses.  Morale of units and heroes also plays a huge role.  Do not ignore this aspect!  Your heroes can ride or fly into battle on mythical creatures.  I highly recommend you give the game a try.  You will not be able to stop.  I keep telling myself, just one more turn...and then it's 2am.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 4, 2014
												So, I played the original Age of Wonders and Age of Wonders 2, as well Shadow Magic, which was a stand alone expansion for Age of Wonders 2, so I was naturally quite interested when I heard Age of Wonders 3 was coming out. Somehow I'd managed to miss that it was even in production until about a month before it was released. Nevertheless, after starting to read about the game, I was a bit wary as some of the changes did not seem positive. However, being a fan of the series as a whole, I had to at least give it a try.So... is Age of Wonders 3 a good game? Well, your answer to that would no doubt be influenced by whether you have played any of the previous games in the series. Having played them, I would say, yes this is a good game but, relative to its time, the game is perhaps not as good as the previous titles in the series. For those of you who don't know, Age of Wonder is a fantasy turn-based strategy, with large amounts of magic, heroes and different races. In Age of Wonders, your leader was a hero and he or she travelled about with your army, gaining levels, exploring ancient ruins and so on. For Age of Wonders 2, your hero became a wizard who spent all his or her time sitting in their tower casting spells. With Age of Wonders 3, the system has gone back to that of the original Age of Wonders (i.e. your leader being an active participant in the world) so in this sense it has been an improvement from 2.Also the graphics are quite good and has a certain fantastical feel about it, I don't know if it's the shades and the hues, but it does feel quite vivid and rich. Also when you zoom out in the world screen, the view changes to a stylised map, as drawn on parchment, think the map of Middle-Earth, which I think looks really good.One of the biggest issues I had with the game prior to getting it was the massive cut the number of races, now there are only six: Goblins, Orcs, Dwarfs, Humans, Draconians and High Elves. This basicaly means many of the races from AoW2 are gone: Dark Elves/Wood Elves (although there is an in-game reason why they no longer exist, basically they kissed and made up and reformed as the High Elves), Frostlings, Halflings, etc. And yes, I would say the lack of races is quite noticable. I've played just 2 levels in one of the campaigns and during that time I've captured and held cities belonging to every single race in the game except for the dwarves. Considering I've only just started the third level, it seems odd that I've nearly played as every single race already. So, yes, I suppose there is certainly much less variation than there was.One of the ways that is suposed to reduce the imact of this lack of variation is by having small settlements belonging to 'minor races' which you can capture and then train units from other races. For example, I captured a fey settlement and was thus able to train various fey units, and construct buildings to improve them, as well as unlock different units that could be trained. I was actually quite surprised how much depth there was in this. You seem to be able to train 5-6 different units, and a fair number of buildings. I was expecting 2-3 different units at most. Nevertheless, they're still less in depth than a city from one of the main six races, and of course you can't build them.Combat is pretty much the same as the previous Age of Wonders games, and the additions with the new 3D engine are nice, for example having units consist of multiple men, the numbers of which go down as the unit gets injured. The system regarding magic spheres is a bit different to the previous titles in the series. Essentially, each hero has three different specialisations and if you're creating your own hero you can pick three from a list. These consist of 6 different areas of magic (water, fire, air, earth, creation and destruction), expander and explorer. Because of this, you can select a minimum of one area of magic and a maximum of three. This influences what you can research and what can subsequently use. When you do create a hero, you get quite a lot of customisation options in terms of apperance. You also have a range of different classes you can select for your hero: dreadnaught, druid, sorcerer, etc. Each of these gives you at least one unique building (which may be upgradable) and unique unit, however apart from that there seems to be little differences between the different classes. Being one class or the other doesn't influence the specialisations you can select for example, and these specialisations seem to have a much greater influence over your character than what class they are.The music in Age of Wonders 3 isn't anything special in my opinion. It's alright, but it's not amazingly noticable and there haven't been any songs I've particularly sat up and particularly enjoyed, compared to Age of Wonders 1 where there were a few songs I particularly liked, such as the March of the Halflings.People have reported having FPS issues, and I get them myself, but for me personally it's mostly fine, just a bit slow but certainly playable. The developers are aware of this and are currently working on fixing it.Also, I have to comend the voice acting in Age of Wonders 3. I've only played one campaign but the voice acting for the main character from whose point of view the stoy is told is actually very good. I admit this review hasn't been the most well structured, but to conclude, I think Age of Wonders 3 is a good game, perhaps a very good game but not an excellent game, and not as good as the previous games in the series and it does have some flaws. It is certainly is screaming out for some kind of expansion/DLC just to add a bit more variation and depth. Even with the minor races you can find and recruit, six major races does seem a bit few but I certainly don't regret buying it.

content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												LIkes:* Unit-by-unit control on an overworld and battle map.  The number of units you manage throughout a single game does not become unwieldy either.* Flexible spell casting system, which can often turn the tides of a battle (or war); in your favor or your opponent's.* Extensive and challenging (in hard difficulty) singleplayer campaigns.* The euphoria when you defeat a numerically or qualitatively superior force through tactics and wit.* Multiple different races and classes, each of which is easy to pick up, but hard to master.Neutral:* City building and resource management is vital, but lacks much in terms of customization.  After you stuff every possible building in a single city, you repeat for other cities.* Research (spells and bonuses) is a nice system (you are unlikely to research everything in a single game), but opaque in terms of what unlocks what.Dislikes:* Multiplayer generally requires auto-combat to go at a reasonable pace (combat holds a global lock on the game state).* Lower tier units become worthless quickly (except, to some extent, archers).  This generally leads to monolithic army compositions later in the game.* Spell disjunction, especially in games with many players, is somewhat annoying; and constantly hampers your ability to do much with spellcasting besides re-casting disjuncted spells.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 20, 2016
												Age of wonders 3 is another installment into the age of wonder series, a fantasy, 4X game with hex grid-turn based combat.Now, normally when i write these reviews, i'd go into depth about the plot or the world or both. But, considering that i spent a significant amount of time playing against AI and some friends in multiplayer, and avoided the single player aspect of it all together, i cannot give you a decent summery beyond saying that the common wealth, a joint group of races, have taken over a large section of the world, there is a court of elves who have not joined, and in the DLC, you can explore new lands with new races, and play as a cold blooded necromancer. Age of wonders functions like any other 4X game to an extent, you are placed on a randomly generated world (customised to your tastes, with a rather extensive range of options) as your chosen hero. Each hero is of a different race, class and has different abilities, each one drastically effecting how your nation will function. You can also make your own custom hero as well. I ended up making a necromancer dark elf called thul'duarn the shadebane, a master of destruction magic and expanding. Your race effects what kinds of units you can make, what type of areas your people like to settle in and what they can build inside cities, it also effects what things increase and decrease your moral. Each city has moral, depending on a number of factors, high moral is good and can lead to festivals, increased production and free money, low moral can lead to rioting and other bad things. Your class determines what kind of spells you can use, the powers your specific hero unit can use and what special units and buildings you can make. your chosen abilities will also determine your spells, unique units and so on.From there, you build up your city, but unlike other 4X games, there is a heavy insentive to go exploring with large armies, because, all around the world there are dungeons, minor factions and free loot to pick up. The dungeons, once cleared, grant bonuses to any city that has it in its borders, the minor factions can be brought into your empire by either doing a few easy quests for them, or just crushing their city with your forces. There are also random map wide events that occur, such as the penguin king and his army of penguins.Like most 4X games you do need to research new tech, you do this with knowledge and mana, though, you can also research new spells for your hero to use. If your hero is taking place in a battle, they can cast it at normal cost, if they are not, you can pay double the mana in order to use it. These spells range anywhere from a simple fireball, to a mass raise army spell, allowing you to summon literally limitless units until the battle is over.Then there is alignment, every character starts off as neutral unless they have taken a specific specialization. From there, you can go evil or good, depending on minor choices you make in game. However, there is no reason to be evil, as it drastically decreases the moral of your people if you go too far down that road, and other nations will outright hate you for it. But on the flip side, there is only a minor penalty for declaring war, so you can happily be the nicest warmonger you want without fear.The main ways to win the game are diplomatically (have everyone agree to become your sworn ally), or via war (kill all the things to win).  Naturally, i went for war every time, because otherwise there is no way to win against human opponents unless they surrender. There is no third or forth option, like a religious victory or a science victory.At the end of the day, Age of Wonders 3 is a 4X game for warmongers, there is literally no better way to win than to swarm your enemies with units, which can get extremely boring after a while, even if the combat is very good. The moral system is nice, but there is one issue, the necromancer class. You see, necromancer controlled cities that have been turned undead are not effected by moral what so ever, meaning they don't have bonuses or penalties to anything, they are just very good at pumping out more undead. Combine this with the fact the necromancer class has access to extremely powerful units in early, mid and late game, and the fact that they have some of the best spells in the game, really breaks it. There is nothing really to concern yourself with in terms of minor details like food and your alignment either, since you are a necromancer.I found the game very fun at first, but after a few matches i really grew tired of the process and found it far too easy, even on harder settings. Its not as deep as some 4X fans might be looking for and its too shallow for new people to be able to experience all the aspects of a 4X game. The only thing i can praise is the soundtrack, just, the pieces vary in quality, alot of them are solidly ok, some bland as paste, others really enjoyable. It makes for good background for a tabletop rpg, but thats it. I wouldn't recommend this to anyone, but i wouldn't tell them to avoid it either, if i could give an ok rating, i would, but thats not possible sadly.I will tell a little story of how my necromancer won his first campaign, if only because it might help you understand how the game goes. So, off in the corner of the large map, my undead city rose from the earth and proceeded to declare the location chosen as "fort bosturd". Right outside my city was a hero, offering to be hired for a handful of coins, despite the fact he was a better necromancer than me. i split my armies up and roamed around the country, doing my necromancer thing, until i encountered a lovely group of faries, instead of running in terror, they greated me nicely and offered to become my allies if i killed a giant, two turns later, i had a giant corpse following me and a new ally. after a bit i turned them into part of my kingdom, and my first act as a new ruler was to convert their city into an undead one...without realizing they can't make the facilities that allow undead cities to grow. the city had a population of zero. i gifted it to my general, he seemed pleased.Jump forward about fifty turns and i had conquered about one third of the map, thanks to my amazing charisma, gleaming repulation as a merciful ruler and the massive undead horde that mindlessly agreed with me. i ran into another nation, ran by a goblin rogue called (insert ♥♥♥♥♥♥ goblin name here) the pretty. Naturally, she was smitten with me, a rotting corpse man, and we became diplomatic friends. I then ignored her and went to capture a city on my borders with my armies, which was a tougher nut to crack than i expected, losing a good number of troops. But i knew next turn i'd have it, until the goblin swooped in, stole the city from underneath me, then told me to ♥♥♥♥ off out of her lands within the next turn. my units all moved out, except for one, whom she destroyed and declared war on me. My armies were rather spread out, but i soon sorted that out, and just as i was about to murder her, she offered peace, and joined my empire, giving me a boost to peace and earning me the good alignment reward.I spread death and plague about for another fifty turns, everyone loving me as i turned them into walking corpses, when the penguin king event happened. in a few turns, i had lost two cities to penguins and was fighting off hordes of them. On that day i swore vengence against the penguin king and all his snowy followers, taking back my cities and cursing how far i had fallen behind in my conquests because of the delay. when i returned to the front, i met evil jesus. the guy who had won the true evil alignment reward, naturally, we did not get on very well, he was a theocrat, and his units could hit mine like trucks. but before he got the chance to, he surrendered to the other AI player. whom swore himself to me after i gifted him two really ♥♥♥♥♥♥ cities. and that was how i won.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 25, 2014
												As fan of the Series since AoW1 the reader of this positive review might think, that I'd just be a good fanboy to a well made series. However after being frustreted with 2 other spinoff of Roundbased Game Series, AoW3 was a very positive surprise for me!Other than in those mentioned other "improved" game experiences, the developers took to heart the initial strengths of the game, and preserved them, while adding new concepts like the neutral cities and the commander classes.And so you can be pretty sure what to get: a solid Age of Wonders experience with various cool new Ideas built in.There are a few minor things I'm not too happy about.For once the actual number of neutral cities is rather low (4, I believe). When I first met those new type of cities, I imagined them being a core concept of the game, with having 8, or even a dozen of them, seeing as the count of playable races shrinked to 6 . I thought the big diversity of units we know from the predecessors just wandered off into neutrality.So I was kind of depressed to see that you mainly got those 4 neutral cities, and the positive "first contact"-experience was just something for the first few maps.Later on however, I realized why the race count went down like that:The race you play is entwined with the class you choose, giving you certain racial units with custom skins, which do have some of the racial benefits, but are actually a boon from your class.This makes the effort to create an ingame race exponentialy as high as in the predecessors, and because of that, I can very well understand the seemingly low number of races.On the positive side however, it adds diversity to the game, since the playstyle is not only about racial pick and magical spheres anymore, but adds a third layer of personalisation through the classes.There are some other minor setbacks from the original series in my point of view: The number of buildings on the map to recruit neutral units has been reduced to 1 (tavern); There are randomized heroes with basic class startups to get, instead of the heroes from AoW2, which kind of grow on to you because of their funny descriptions, and their prepicked own advantages; And also the later stages of the campaign become incredibly hero-dependant due to the leveling commander-heroes and the neutral heroes you transfer from map to map.But enough nitpicking.If you enjoyed the predecessors or are generaly into well-balanced tactical round-based game experiences.. make sure to get this one! The classes and races are very well designed, and the campaigns are bit straightforward storywise, but still diversified and interesting. The few experiences I made with online gaming so far were positive as well.

content:
Posted: November 2, 2016
												I enjoy AoW3 quite a bit, but the more I played it the more stale the AI got for me.  It's not that it's bad per se, just that it's predictable and usually very passive.  Usually they will turtle up in their cities if you are roaming nearby, even if they are a fair bit stronger than you.  This forces a lot of siege warfare, something that I don't think the game does very well.  You can't sit outside their gates and siege them down, you have to fight their forces full strength every time at their walls.  It gets tedious.  There are ways around this (happiness penalties/strategic spells mainly from Rogue) but the AI gets pretty significant boosts to its economy and happiness which makes it kind of moot.  That said, I still think the game is great.  The units are diverse, the asymmetrical balancing is rather good, and a lot of the racial specializations are nice to have.  Things that I'd like to see in the next iteration:- Smarter, less cheesy AI- Proper siege mechanics- More emphasis on skirmishes/raiding- More cultural/racial buildings and the addition of monuments/wonders- Option for fast move in combat with online play

I do highly recommend this game for the amazing and addictive single player game, especially if you're a fan of RPG fantasy, turn-based strategy, tactical combat, exploration, and empire building.

content:
Posted: April 17, 2015
												Age of Wonders III has come a long way since it's release. I'll be honest, I probably never had higher expectations on a computer game since I endorsed both Age of Wonders II and Shadow Magic and played them throughout an entire decade ... so after my first few games with AoW 3 I got a little disappointed. The game felt too fast, the starting race was much less significant than in the previous games and so felt the pick of the magical specilazations. Also I wasn't happy with some combat simplifications like flying units that suddenly had to land, the removal of friendly fire in ranged attacks etc ... Lucky for me (and for most other AoW 3 players I'd say) Triumph Studios wouldn't be Triumph Studios if they didn't listen to their community. With each patch more and more issues the playerbase initially had with the game got fixed with the result that now with it's free 1.5 patch (and the two expansions, if you bought them) the game is very convenient to play and feels very complete content-wise - just right for another ten years of gaming time ;)What you shouldn't expect AoW 3 to be is a civilization clone in a fantasy setting. While in civilization the main focus always has been on the empire building and management (let's say the strategical component) with Age of Wonders it's pretty much the opposite. The tactical combat is complex, demanding and offers tons of possibilities and while I personally wouldn't have sacrificed some of the mentioned combat characteristics of the previous games, Age of Wonders 3 can compensate their absence by introducing the guard mode and flanking system.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 10, 2015
												I'm having a lot of fun with the game. It's one of those games that I got on sale but wouldn't have been upset if I paid full price. 	At first I was a little disappointed, there only seemed to be two campaigns. The high elves and the dwarfs, but you pick up other companions who help you and than you play their part of the campaign.   Example, first you play as a rouge Elf, but you quickly pick up a Draccon. When that part of the campaign is over it starts off as the Draccon in charge, but your high elf is still one of the leaders.	Again I was little disappointed because the first part of the campaign was long, so I figured it was over. Nope! As I said another character steps in and they become the primary champ.	I'm 15 hours plus on the second part of the campaign, I had to restart a few times. It can be a little trial by era but once you learn (and this goes into the actually strategy of the game) you know the most expensive units may not be your best.	Your main champs level up, but only to a certain point per campaign as well as your units but they don't carry over to the next stage of the campaign.  Basically your starting from scratch just your Champs keep their ability points and gear you might find. 	The AI isn't stupid, the game has a auto match feature for annoying little battles which I didn't think I would use. Even if your likely to defeated you can pull off a win if your in a castle and play smart, and use your units properly and cast the right spells. However there are times where you have no chance in hell of winning and your goal becomes to hurt and kill your attacker as much as possible, so you can send in another force and destroy them but having a major champ in the game can cause one big bust which means you have to restart or have a back up save. 	The storyline is rather weak but I'm okay with that, you get a big explanation in the start but your goal isn't always clear. Best advice is build up your money and mana before going to war if no one is attacking you. A lot of the towns you start will be useless besides for their money and mana benefits.  Basically you want to create a choke point and produce your troops from only a few locations. With that said some units take up money and mana every round so plan ahead. You can go through 20 turns with nothing really happening if you don't want it to.

content:
Posted: January 10, 2015
												I'm having a lot of fun with the game. It's one of those games that I got on sale but wouldn't have been upset if I paid full price. 	At first I was a little disappointed, there only seemed to be two campaigns. The high elves and the dwarfs, but you pick up other companions who help you and than you play their part of the campaign.   Example, first you play as a rouge Elf, but you quickly pick up a Draccon. When that part of the campaign is over it starts off as the Draccon in charge, but your high elf is still one of the leaders.	Again I was little disappointed because the first part of the campaign was long, so I figured it was over. Nope! As I said another character steps in and they become the primary champ.	I'm 15 hours plus on the second part of the campaign, I had to restart a few times. It can be a little trial by era but once you learn (and this goes into the actually strategy of the game) you know the most expensive units may not be your best.	Your main champs level up, but only to a certain point per campaign as well as your units but they don't carry over to the next stage of the campaign.  Basically your starting from scratch just your Champs keep their ability points and gear you might find. 	The AI isn't stupid, the game has a auto match feature for annoying little battles which I didn't think I would use. Even if your likely to defeated you can pull off a win if your in a castle and play smart, and use your units properly and cast the right spells. However there are times where you have no chance in hell of winning and your goal becomes to hurt and kill your attacker as much as possible, so you can send in another force and destroy them but having a major champ in the game can cause one big bust which means you have to restart or have a back up save. 	The storyline is rather weak but I'm okay with that, you get a big explanation in the start but your goal isn't always clear. Best advice is build up your money and mana before going to war if no one is attacking you. A lot of the towns you start will be useless besides for their money and mana benefits.  Basically you want to create a choke point and produce your troops from only a few locations. With that said some units take up money and mana every round so plan ahead. You can go through 20 turns with nothing really happening if you don't want it to.

												I enjoyed this game quite a bit but lost intrest fairly quickly.  This game can be quite fun and is a nice mixture of Civilization and Heros of Might and Magic. The moment you start to achieve a lead on your oppents via having the better armies you no longer have challenging wars with other armies which is the most polished part of the game. Instead it becomes a boring affair so I suggest you keep the diffculty settings as high as you can manage.Overall a very good game.

content:
Posted: April 15, 2015
												So far a very good turn-based strategy game and easy for someone who's more than a bit rusty at the genre to get into without much frustration. Some pros and cons so far:Pros: Easy to learn, tutorial pages are fairly informative and not intrusive if you hate having to go through tutorials that either are too long or too detailed...or the reverse. Fantasy setting is fairly straight forward (elves vs. orcs in basic campaign with human scum everywhere) but engaging storytelling and voice acting works wellTurn-based design is very comfortable if you've played this type of game in the pastCons:More than possible to wall yourself in a corner by accident (sort of comes with the turf though)Autosave will occasionally save right before a move you really wish you hadn't taken (so save often)YMV on this but I have found on occasion that I think I'm clicking to attack one troop and get another by accident. Not sure its a game issue or operator error (probably the latter)Anyway so far a 9/10 for me would get 1 more point if the fantasy elements were more exotic and interesting but otherwise quite easy and enjoyable to get into while being challenging to overcome. Will update if further play changes any details in this review (I'm only about 6 hours in to the initial campaign).
