content:
Posted: July 2, 2014
												Although this game will likely become 2014's hidden gem, Age of Wonders 3 is a pretty good take on turn-based strategy games.Regarding empire management, I've noticed that some have commented that when compared to games like Civilization, the empire management is more or less streamlined, and to me, building up my empire wasn't too difficult.I imagine that this is done to give a larger focus on the combat system, where the focus is no longer on the world map, but rather on a smaller tactical map where players command the party or parties they've formed and pit them against each other (either in open terrain or a siege depending on where the defending party is standing on at the time of the attack). I found it enjoyable that the Age of Wonders series brings you to this hex-based tactical view, though the previous games were heavily reliant on a random number generator, which can sometimes have your entire starting party be killed by 2 starting units.Age of Wonders 3 throws the random number generator out the window, meaning that defense/resistance actually reduces physical and magic damage. Additionally, line of sight and range penalties act as damage reductions, rather than giving ranged weapons a chance of missing entirely. Personally, i find that it's really nice that combat is no longer reliant on an in-game RNG, although I'm probably saying that because I've lost an entire party to 2 goblin militia units in Age of Wonders: Shadow Magic.And finally, the initial set-up (I probably should've started from here). Compared to Age of Wonders 1, it's somewhat simplified in the sense that you can't allocate your starting stats (I think this was done to prevent abuse, since you can pretty much start with 2-3 types of elemental melee damage), although this is more or less offset by the ability to choose your leader's race and class, which I felt is pretty fun to play around with.Overall, I find that Age of Wonders 3 is an awesome game for those who enjoy fantasy turn-based strategy games.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 2, 2014
												Before writing this review, I'd looked at some of the negative reviews up and was, to say the least, surprised at some of the criticisms. With that in mind, I'd recommend anyone looking to buy this understand what Age of Wonders is.Despite having taken some obvious Civilization inspirations in the most recent title, Age of Wonders may be a TBS, but not a '4X' title, and never essentially has been. Diplomacy is merely functional, not a true gameplay concern. Exploitation, as far as the 4-X title is concerned, is fairly shallow. Expanding has simple mechanics behind it, leaving most of the game filling the "Explore/Exterminate" gap.Except that doesn't tell the story. This isn't a 4X title.This game stands up to games like Elemental: Fallen Enchantress, Warlock: Master of the Arcane, Eador: Master's of the Broken World and virtually any other fantasy Turn-Based Strategy title in the past 5, 6 or more years and presents in it a wholly more clean, professional, beautiful and, most importantly, long-lasting light. A genuine, long duo of campaigns that are story-driven and contain wide numbers of missions, an in-depth hero/leader customization options, wide variety of 'factions' by mix-and-matching Race and Class 'templates' to your own tastes and fantastic level design leaves this as a game that you can play, again and again and again again, and never grow tired, from what I've seen - much like the Age of Wonders of Old.Of course, with that in mind, if you don't want to spend $40 on a title in this genre, then I do have an alternative recommendation. Buy Age of Wonders: Shadow Magic, or even the Wizards Throne - even the ORIGINAL if you don't mind a more '90s' videogame in this genre, all of them on Steam. They're cheaper, and if you enjoy what those games has to offer you'll love this, as a very, very worthy revival.TO AGE OF WONDERS FANS:Age of Wonders 3 adds in some new mechanics that you may or may not find off-putting, but ultimately it takes a lot of the best features of Age of Wonders 1 and 2/Shadow Magic and combines them, while generally also creating a much more balanced game than the previous two - the unstoppable heroes/leaders and the sheer inability to fight high-tier creatures except with high-tier creatures of your own, most notably. "Weaker" units, as long as they're in number, have more relevance than they used to even later into the game, and the city progression, while not nearly as intuitive, has more specialization options and potential building plans than before. Combat is very similar to Shadow Magic or the Wizards Throne, but more in-depth, including additional mechanics such as how wall climbing is to work, certain non-wall terrain that can be damaged, and a PHENOMENAL "flanking" and "defense" system and a less-exploitable action/move system.I am not far enough into the game to have strong opinions on the campaign, particularly in terms of story; they've changed the themes somewhat from the earlier games, and I'm not convinced the character quality is as high, but it has some nice level design and, at the early levels, gives you a few legitimately different approaches to the same overall goal, and rewards a fair amount of exploration if you choose to take it - much like some of the better Shadow Magic campaign missions.A fantastic, fantastic game, and I urge people to give it, or even the older games in the series, a try. Even Shadow Magic, back about ten years ago, ran rings around the poorly-designed Elemental games of the modern age (Even LOOKED better, somehow) and had a way more satisying spell and combat system than, say, Warlock: Master of the Arcane.

content:
Posted: June 19, 2015
												Great game.  I got this on release and have clocked a lot of hours on it, but I waited to recommend it.I waited because it had a few balance and playability issues otu of the box, which have been adressed with patches and the Dev's listening to the community.Pros- Good division between the classes and races, everyone is good at, and weak at, something.  This makes the choice meaningful.- A style which is both functional and cool looking.- Excellent in-game encyclopedia, much refined over the patches.  Likely inspired by Civ, but not a bad inspiration at that.- Excellent tooltips. Every unit has all its abilities and current stats available at a click, no searching through menus or having to remember who does what.  This lets you focus on stratagy, and not memory tests.- Unit models. Personally I love how there is a version of each class unit for every race, they didn't skimp out on the design budget by making generic models.  Also, Goblin Angels!Cons-The campaigns are not the greatest feats of storytelling. But they do give a good vehicle for the stratagy, and a reason for the objectives.- The first expansion campaign (I haven't played Eternal Lords yet) was frustrating because it was basically a long tutorial for the new features, when I would rather have had all those new features through the campaign.  Except possibly the seals, which make sense at the point they are at (I'm not giving any spoilers here!)- There doesn't seem to be much rhyme or reason to how nuetral factions act towards you.  This may be addressed with the proposed changes to races in Eternal Lords.- The randomly generated maps do produce some wierd anomalies from time to time, but I believe these are being refined.Over all, this game deserves its 80% approval rating, and I heartily recommend it to both fans of the series and other turn-bases stratagy or empire building fans.

content:
Posted: April 1, 2014
												Me and my wife have been strategy fans for quite sometime. We have played just about everything since Xcom UFO Defense (1994). Turn-based strategy games are our preferred taste. We play boardgames quite often here at home and civilization V has been our favorite on the screen for awhile. We have been on the hunt for quite sometime to increase our library of favorites and Age of Wonders III does not disappoint. Do you like to explore, research, upgrade, loot, expand, and to conquer? Age of Wonders III is a "one more turn" welcoming addiction.+ Excellent lore+ Unit information codex is very useful when planning strategies+ useful tooltips on city management, units, building types, and terrain types, and icon information.+ Great visuals (When you zoomout all the way the world turns into a fantasy paper map, nice touch)+ Create your own library of custom Leaders (Play as your own unique leader and create custom leaders for the AI, its your own world)+ LOTS of options (Simultaneous turns, classic turns, auto or manual battles with replay, random map generation, terrain type sliders, allow adjustments to just about every category you can think of.+ Excellent replayability+ HOTSEAT and online multiplayer support+ Great developer support+ Excellent Music Score- Bugs- Online multiplayer requires some firewall tweaking- optimzation a bit rough (unusual slowdowns and gfx issues)

content:
Posted: April 2, 2014
												I'll start with the good news: this really is a worthy successor to the earlier parts of the series, and I definitely recommend it to any fan of turn-based strategy games.That said, it does have a few flaws that need to be addressed.- The alignment system...doesn't work. There's no penalty to playing the good guy, so you'll pretty much always gravitate towards a Pure Good alignment unless you make a deliberate effort to be evil, and since there are distinct penalties for playing the bad guy you end up gimping yourself in the progress.- While the move to 3D certainly improved animation quality, some models (especially flying creatures) are just plain hideous to look at. I have absolutely no idea what they were trying to achieve with the gryphon, for example :P.- The loss of many staple races is a bit of a pain, although the new class-based units do help to put some of the variety back in.- Speaking of that, some things about the race/class system aren't exactly explained very well. Class units of different races do have noticably different stats, which is something you're left to find out for yourself (hint: elves, as usual, do very well with any kind of ranged attack).- And finally, there's a certain amount of interface clunkiness going on. No major showstoppers, but a lot of minor things that'll get a little annoying over time.So...what makes this worth buying despite the flaws I just outlined?- A solid TBS experience with RPG elements.- A fun, if somewhat cliché'd setting.- Amazing music.- Elven musketeers.- The classes really do offer vastly different playstyles. If you try the approach you won with as a Warlord with an Archdruid character, you will probably fail pretty hard.- Character traits make a huge difference in playstyle as well.- Goblin angels.- Random map generator with good fine-tuning options provides long-term replayability.- The series' trademark sense of humor is still around and going strong, particularly in the unit descriptions.All in all, a very solid game despite some flaws, and probably the best of its kind out right now.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 5, 2016
												Let me preface this by saying I love the Age of Wonders series. I played AOW1, AOW2, and AOW:SM a ton back when I was a kid. I am not writing a negative review lightly.I guess I will start off with what AOW3 did right:Continuation of the Age of Wonders story and a revival of the franchise.Nostalgic musical score consisting of AOW1 remixes. I'm not sure if I heard any AOW2/SM music though.Vassal cities. Not having to manually manage my less-important cities is really nice, and it gives another layer of diplomacy besides player-to-player....I'm supposed to write more, right? ...Right?No seriously, that's the extent of what I can consider as good in AOW3. What I listed is self-explanatory, so I will move on to the meat of this review.What I found AOW3 did wrong; why it doesn't feel like Age of Wonders:The absence of trademark spells like Enchant Weapon and Blessing (no not the in-combat only Blessing AOW3 has).The absence of heroes like Winger and Ham, heroes that were present in all three of the previous AOW games.Ripping off Civilization in GUI layout and general gameplay. "Empire upgrades", you mean technology? And whatever happened to researching spells that looked and did amazing stuff?! Hellfire from AOW2/SM, where is it?!Lack of unit and building depth. Archers are king, cities are "finished" when in AOW1/2/SM we would still be in earlygame. Domains are nerfed and cannot overlap each other, they are not so much "magical sphere of influence" as they are borders like in Civ; see below.Very shallow leader/hero design. Unlike the previous games I am finding a problem what I should be doing with my leader and heroes. The leader can't do♥♥♥♥♥♥sitting in town like before in AOW2/SM, and the leader being nerfed like such compared to the wizards in AOW2/SM means the heroes are also nerfed in their utility. Unlike AOW1, their presence isn't all that large either; forget mowing down entire armies singlehandedly, not happening here.Straight off, AOW3 does not feel like a continuation of Age of Wonders 1, 2, and Shadow Magic. Trademark spells and heroes are missing, the way the game flows is changed to be more in the venue of Civ. Honestly, I think AOW3 is more Civilization 5 with a fantasy reskin than Age of Wonders revived.AOW3 lost the unique identity that AOW1/2/SM managed to create, I don't feel that AOW3 distinguishes itself enough from the other strategy games (4X strategy in particular) in the industry like AOW1/2/SM did. If someone told me AOW3 was a Civ5 fantasy mod, I would believe them.What I found AOW3 did wrong; the technical faults:Terrible graphics. There, I said it. Compared to other games of the same genre like Civilization, the graphics are horrible. The image simply isn't sharp, aliasing is everywhere even with anti-aliasing enabled. It feels like I'm playing the game in a smaller resolution than my monitor's native resolution, even though I am not. All the models are also ridiculously low-poly and the textures low-res by today's standards, and I have the options set on high! (I can run ultra with a minor FPS drop, but I don't see any improvement.)Clunky tactical combat. The combat in AOW1/2/SM was one of the highlights of the series. Battles were fun and exciting, especially siege battles involving cities. Casting Hellfire and seeing the city furiously burn was amazing. Not here. Sieges just feel like a chore, and field battles are dominated by archers. Melee units are just meatshield fodder. I find myself preferring auto combat over manual combat. This is Age of Wonders, why does the combat feel so unappealing?!The revamped alignment system. Why in the seven wizards of the cosmos am I "evil" for migrating to my preferred races? For plundering and razing cities? For killing independent guards? None of these acts were even remotely "evil" before on a global level. In fact migrations were strongly encouraged regardless if you were playing a "good" wizard. I see little sense in the way the alignment system was revamped and implemented.Halflings as DLC simply rubs me the wrong way. Halflings were one of the mainstays in the series, and they were axed in the base AOW3 release before seeing a DLC release. Really? I might have gotten it still if the game was enjoyable, but I'm having doubts as this review might suggest.All in all, I am seriously saddened that I just can't bring myself to recommend this game. I really wanted to write a positive review, I adored the Age of Wonders series! Unfortunately, as a loving fan I just cannot bring myself to lie and upvote. If you have never played any of the old Age of Wonders games then you might be able to enjoy this game, but  as a long-time fan I was sorely disappointed.

content:
Posted: April 16, 2015
												After 20 years, Master of Magic finally gets a worthy spiritual successor. If you're into turn-based strategy with a magical twist, get this game. If you loved the original Master of Magic but found several recent games that tried to recapture its (ahem) magic but end up feeling a bit off (I'm looking at you Fallen Enchantress/Warlock Master of the Arcane/Endless Legend), you will not be disappointed by Age of Wonders 3. The thing that I love most about AOW 3 that it shares with Master of Magic is that the tech tree has a lot of real gamechangers. It's not just wussy +10% attack/defense/economy improvements here, no. On one turn you're playing with cookie-cutter pike/archers/cavalry, then on the next turn you research something and suddenly you have FLOATING ELDRITCH HORRORS FROM ANOTHER DIMENSION that can mind-control your enemies and panic the puny mortals that dare attack them. Or you level up your hero and suddenly YOUR ENTIRE UNIT STACK IS NOW INVISIBLE TO THE ENEMY.You don't win battles just because your attack/defense numbers are better than the enemy. You win battles by casting a spell that makes half of the enemy army run away in panic, sending in succubi to seduce the half that remained to fight for you, then use your new mind-controlled minions to kill their former allies. If you're going to play a 4X game set in a magical world, you don't want the game to just replace artillery with fireballs, rifles with bows and tanks with steampunk tanks, you want to see all the craziness that is possible in a magical world. This AOW 3 delivers really, really well.

content:
Posted: April 9, 2015
												I should have reviewed this game long ago.Age of Wonders 3 is an amazing fantasy turn based 4x with rpg elements, and a fantastic array of choices, customization and tactical options.I would sit here and list them all, but I will condense it to afew points.Have you ever played a 4x and wanted to actually be on the battlefield? To have a presence? In AoW 3 you can, as a sovereign you can fight on the battlefield (and revive if killed too) gain levels, and lead a glorious army, or have your heroes do it for you (or fight alongside them) Have you ever wanted to be able to both play a nice, friendly, intercultural hero of the people? Or be the devious evil genociding brutal wizard lord? Both are viable strategies, and have their strengths and weaknesses especially with all the new updates related to alignment, and racial approval/happiness.Do you itch for a game with a varied class selection of rather different yet equal classes? From the ttrategy, tactics, and military might of the warlord, and the sneaky cunning of the rogue to the vast arcane power of the wizard and religious/moral power of the theocrat (and several other classes, alongside the necromancer soon to be released) you have access to a vast array of balanced, interesting, and flavorful classes.Balance is both already good, and improving all the time as the developers follow the approach of Adding content, and adding power rather than simply cutting content, and nerfing to improve balance, orks not strong enough? We aughta give them a new unit option, and a damage buff, not nerf everyone else. It's wonderful, and so very productive.All in all do I feel like I got my money's worth with this purchase? I very much do, I was worried after years without a new game that this game would fail to live up to the nostalgia of AoW Shadow Magic, instead it actually improved upon it's predecessor, and captured my attentions all over again. I'd rate this game 9.5 out of 10, the highest rating of any game in my 450+ title library. If you're a fan of 4x, rpgs, or fantasy and are even remotely considering this title I give you my absolute recommendation.Well what are you waiting for? Buy it! (if you must wait for a sale then fine, but at any price under 30 bucks this game is just too good to pass up you owe it to yourself)

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 30, 2015
												Age of Wonders 3 for me is the best TBS-game on the market. I admit, I am a fan since AoW1 but the game changed quite a bit since then and still I think it's great! At the beginning when watching the first trailers I was concerned that the game might lose clarity gameplaywise due to the newer 3D-graphics but I think Triumph Studios did a perfect job - a good balance between looks and gameplay. Even though it's not a Battlefield 4 hyperrealistic graphicstyle I think it's looking fantastic and it fits. Next I was concerned of the class and race system Triumph introduced with this game. In the older games there weren't classes but tons of races. This time there were only 6 races ( at the beginning. DLCs and expansion bring more races and classes ) and 6 classes. I underestimated the impact of the different classes and races - the mix of each class and race has its own benefits and playstyles. Not only class and race but also specialisations such as Fire Adept, Partisan, Expansionst add a lot of depth to the game. If you think about it there is a lot to explore in the game, a lot to remember when playing as there are loads of little features that sweaten your experience. At last I was concerned about the new border-system for the cities. In the past titles you could conquer whatever you want and no matter how far away from your cities the sites were you gained income. In this title you only gain income from sites that are in your territory which expands around your cities. This on the other hand adds another important factor: Settlement placement. When playing the game I don't feel like missing something out of the older titles. - Well, of course I'd be glad about more variations but this is exactly what the developers are working on at the moment. One DLC has been published just half a year after the release of the main title - hand in hand with big free content-patches - and a big expansion including a new race _and_ a new class is already far developed as far as I can tell. The developers really listen to the community in the AoW3 own forums. They are very active in the forums comparing them to other bigger studios. This is another very big plus for Triumph. I can only recommend this title, the DLC and the upcoming expansion. - Triumph releases weekly dev-blogs on their page to give updates about some of the new features that are being worked on.

Posted: January 30, 2015
												Age of Wonders 3 brings the modest and shy greatness that AoW1 was into the modern world, retaining much of it's old feeling and that of the other prequels, AoW2 and AoW2SM, while sharing some of the best traits with more strongly established franchises and holding a general environment / atmosphere really pleasant to the eye. If you prefer fantasy worlds and a slight touch of RPG elements, this will make you forget Civilization. Age of wonders is much less linear, and what it lacks in management complexity, it makes up with more elaborate combat and exploration.

content:
Posted: November 6, 2016
												I really want to like this game, the AI is very competent and atmosphere is fantastic. But the campaign is designed to frustrate you rather than entertain. The first scenario is a brief  introduction of the basic game mechanism. On the second scenario, the AI just steamroller you, without further explanations, when you still barely have a clue what buildings are and what units do what. There are also very bad game design decisions. In battles there is no deployment phase, and the computer always manage to put your units in the worst possible starting position. Frequently, the AI charges and kill your heroes on the first turn, without giving a chance and if one of your heroes die, it is game over. So the best thing you can do is to hide them behind and hope the computer will not sneak from behind, making the whole purpose of the heroes useless.

												I played one game against the AI on a large map (two, normal and hard I think). Wars were declared on me constantly by my AI opponents, but I was never attacked. Asking for peace was all it took to get peace every time; two or three turns later they would declare war again without fail. Once I got a few tier 4 units I went out looking for trouble and found that my AI opponents had done nothing to expand. Not a single building or unit was produced by the AI empires the entire game.I haven't played since.

content:
Posted: April 4, 2014
												Unfortunately quite a boring game. Number 1 big complain. ALL UNITS and BUILDINGS ARE THE SAME FOR EVERY RACE.Yes. they just renamed it as, dwarf rider, orc rider, human rider, basically the same set of units was used for every race and then given a race specific ability for some tiny insignificant differenceSame as buildings ! ALL BUILDINGS ARE THE SAME FOR EVERY RACE.Omg, horrible. I was really bored. played a random 8 player map with 6 players including me. all A.I were at king level.  Spells were good and had alot of variety. however diplomacy is lacking and there is like nothing to do in the map, because like all units and all buildings, the entire map was populated by basically the same few structures and all monsters were basically the same few types with different names.diplomacy wise, the auto balance is a nice touch. However take note that the crazy A.I will constant trespass on your borders and you will be FLOODED with messages about it. there is no diplomacy option to enfore or follow up on this border thing.overall i have to say it was BORING. Graphics were nice and i encountered only 1 CTD during the whole game.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 1, 2016
												The game is a very fun and great 4x tile, with more of a focus on combat and quicker overall 4x game than a much deeper 4x like civ. Because of this you get cooler rpg systems, great combat (the best selling feature of this game because of the abundance of units, skills that are varied and useful (just always attacking is not the best way to go, I like this), heros, mana/spells, maps that reflect 4x map, and much more), more action, and just overall fun. So maybe not the absolute deepest 4x, but worth it because it has a different focus which makes it unique and different from other 4x. Also with the continued development and expansions, and optional mods the game has gotten way better. So if you pasted it up before, look into it again and see if it is for you. If you like 4x games, this could become one of your favorites! PS (The sales price is awesome at 75%, but I have no regrets buying the game with only the small price cut that I got.)

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 21, 2014
												Just got this game and I don't know who made what first but this is my first time playing a game in the AoW franchise and found it's pretty much the same game as HoMM, although... it's fun. HoMM failed on the fun part their last couple installments and this game delivers. It's a good time. Not to blow my own horn but I think the AI is pretty weak in this, I tried normal difficulty and it was a joke, then 1 up from normal and it still wasn't much of a challlenge. AI would declare war on me, I'd wipe him out without breaking a sweat, I'd try to make peace with the next guy, nope he wants war... he's dead too, etc.Having individual troops in your army rather than stacks of troops like in HoMM is a big improvement. You get more of a feel for how tough your guys are rather than having to always check how big the stack is and do some mental math. Your magic will be strong but not broken and so far I've played 2 classes (Warlord and Sorcerer) and the style of play changes quite a lot so it adds some variety. You get to cast spells both in combat and in the global map and the global spells / disjuction side of the game is very relevant. In combat, your hero can be strong but not that relevant as a fighting unit lategame, but  you'll have spells that make massive impact.As with most TBS games, at the end of the turn the AI helps you control your stuff by prompting you to confirm your orders for your units or give orders to units with none (of course it won't bother you if you "Garrison" the units). But it's kinda reduntant, if I give a unit a move order that takes 5 turns to complete, it won't just automove every turn, it will prompt me to confirm his journey for the next 5 turns. Kinda pointless. Another thing I'd like is to be able to have a town governor or something to build my cities up for me without me having to bother with microing it. Late game, I just wanna manage my armies, not click through the repetative build orders of my 20-30 city empire. I would also like a minister of defence or something so he could worry about  sending my troops out to defend my cities, let me pick what goes in the garrison of border cities  and safe zone cities but don't make me do it myself. hehe. Also the builder unit could use some automation, "go around and make roads to connect my cities" seems a boring task I shouldn't have to micro myself.Okay enough ranting about my pet peeves, overall the game is great and a welcome addition to the turn based strategy genre.I recommend buying if you like this style of game, there's not many out there that are more fun.

content:
Posted: February 20, 2015
												This is a nice addition to the AoW series, with improved graphics etc but I can't help feeling a little disappointed with in (or   perhaps didn;t enjoy it as much as I would have liked.  The main issue is that it gets a little repetitive, whether it is on the world map or the same fights played.... personally I found myself wanting to auto-combat a lot, which on other games such as Heroes of Might and Magic I would't.  The differences between the factions/races are not as different as they were in AoW2, so really doesn't matter too much which side you choose. The jumps between difficulty levels seems a little excessive too.  Don't get me wrong, it is a good game, and those who are new to it or enjoy the AoW series and others such as Heroes of Might and Magic or Kings Bounty will enjoy this too, but  after the first campaign is completed you may think twice about starting the second one so the longevity of this game is affected (in my opinion).  In summary, its a good game but not great!

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 21, 2014
												This game is very entertaining. I am mainly writing to respond to criticisms that the game lacks depth, which initially made me hestitant about the game. The sale price of 19.99 USD tipped the scales in favor of the game (I was also considering Solar Empire and Endless Space). I'm glad the sale was going on because so far this is a great purchase. For a pure 4x game, I could see a lack of depth. However, this game is a hybrid between a 4x and RPG. I find RPGs too shallow to hold my interest, but the RPG elements here add a facet to this game that I haven't seen in other 4x games. The fact that it's unique makes it interesting. True...the research tree is anemic, but I have a lot of fun learning the spells, which have a fresh and dynamic affect on every aspect of the gaming experience. But to me, the RPG-style battle engine is what takes this to the next level. It is somewhat complex and very engaging, and mixed with more traditional 4x aspects, AOW III provides a nice experience that has kept my interest through that crucial first 24 hours. It also helps that the gameplay is smooth and intuitive, and the graphics are beautiful. So far, this is my favorite purchase since Civ V. One note is that I did have a crash. However, this was after a 14-hour session.

content:
Posted: January 9, 2016
												6/10. Will probably reinstall eventually. Graphics reign supreme in this remake. I don't much care for the sound but that is typical for me. The game play is quite annoying at times but it is no different than AOW  and AOWII in that sense. Mainly the randomness is what is annoying. That said it is quite playable even with autocombat being terribad. The sameness of the item/skill set does not encourage long games (once you have a complete set of slots you probably don't care about the rest of the dungeons) and the AI is opportunistic (a + thing) but not hard to predict (a - thing). The indicators of how tough a battle will be are frankly disappointing but I have yet to play a game where the predictors were 100%. The fact is, at a certain point you will probably roll over all the Epic, Mythic and Legendary dungeon battles with ease. Full item slots are a must upgrade for this goal. Mainly, it lacks excitement for me but some things about the game are really solid and if I get a hankering for a Warlords style game again I will likely reinstall. I highly recommend playing with your own leader once you figure out how the system works. There is nothing wrong with the stock PCs but they are a little boring. Sadly part of what makes the game lackluster for me is the small variety in the customizable leader abilities. On the other hand every hero you have becomes somewhat customizable once you level them. The points system for doing so seems a little imbalanced and again the variety seems lacking but I expect they withheld a lot of the innovation for DLCs. So you might want to wait for those if you live for diversity. I got the game on sale and for under $8 it is a must buy if you like Warlords style games.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 11, 2015
												Lots of style, little substance. I've always gravitated towards 4X games, so when Age of Wonders III came out, I was naturally pretty hyped. However, after playing it, there's quite a few flaws I've noticed about the game:- Character customization is extremely limited- Game is a resource hog. My computer's pretty decent and I still got huge lag spikes pretty frequently- It is far, far too easy to steamroll in this game. Once you've captured one city, the rest is just details. - Very, very little variety. A few leader classes and races and that's it. There's not much assortment of monsters, either, even with the expansion. And lastly, the game simply doesn't have any 'soul'. Remember Heroes of Might and Magic III, where each and every artifact had a little story behind it? Or Fall From Heaven 2, where each faction had a long and sordid history? Or even Fallen Enchantress, with a bit of both? Yeah, none of that's here. The game world is pretty much the blandest you could imagine, with a color palette apparently ripped from Fable 2 that just does not jive with the tone the rest of the game tries to set.

												I love this game, and I can't believe it took me so long to get into it. Seriously, I bought this game shortly after it came out, but put it on a back burner because I had a Hearts of Iron 3 campaign going. AoWIII looked complicated, and it is a steep learning curve. The action bar at the bottom right of the screen helps you take all the actions you can during the turn. The game tells you to research a new skill. It tells you to select what to build in each city, etc. It tells you that an army needs movement orders. Next thing you know, two hours have passed. I give it two thumbs way up.

content:
Posted: April 7, 2014
												So far, this game is living up to they hype.  Having a chance to play every race and class, there seem to be perhaps the need for a few minor balancing issues.  Most of the main concerns are already underway in future patch releases.  Minor bugs exist, but nothing game-breaking from what I have seen.  The ONLY downside so far is the inability to connect directly to play with a friend.  Fiddling with the router/port forwarding, etc may be necessary to play across their servers in multiplayer.This game gives more versatility than any of the previous games with the class/race system.  It stays simplified and is quick to pick up if having played previous games.  One new difference is the DOMAIN feature.  It sure saves from scrambling for nodes!For those who have not played any of the previous games in this series, it is a turn-based tactical game.  Multiplayer tends to be slower than single, but with customizable terrains to add to the random map generating, options are endless!

content:
Posted: June 18, 2015
Great fantasy strategy game got even better with patchesRecent patches (June 2015) really improved the gameplay. There are too many changes to list, but you might want to check it out if played the initial game version but not recently.  One paragraph description of AoWTo me, AoWIII is the best of the fantasy strategy genre which includes: Might & Magic, King's Bounty, Warlock, King Arthur, Eador, etc. Gameplay is centered around managing a few heroes which gain strength by leveling, research, and acquiring items. Your heroes can also lead armies and capture cities. Cities allow you to build more units and improve resources. Combat is turn-based on a hex map against a challenging AI. Hero items and experience persist between campaign missions which take awhile to finish.If you liked the previous AoWs, this is a great sequel, similar to what Civ5 is to Civ4. Everything gets better.

It is a pity then, that the whole games strategic potential is reduced to how fast you can mass produce tier four units of which there are very little variety and which can be done rather quickly. And nothing else.

content:
Posted: November 28, 2014
												The Age of Wonders series has always been the torchbearer for Master of Magic. Age of Wonders 3 (which is actually the 4th game in the series) strays from that original template by actually brining very solid balance to all the various factions in the game, making it something you can play in multiplayer without having to set a bunch of houserules ahead of time. It is pretty, the tactical combat is well designed (and by well designed I mean superior leadership can make a huge difference in the outcome) it has a deep strategic game, and there is a huge variety of units. Each class plays very differently from one another, and each class plays off of the various races differently as well. There has been outstanding post launch support, both bug-fixes, and new content.

												The Good:+ Stunning graphics that work well even on slightly older cards+ Excellent soundtrack and score+ Vibrant races that all feel different to play+ A solid single player campaign that engages, feels epic and teaches you what you need to know+ A fantastic battle system that rewards strategic play+ A re-balance on some of the dominant races from the last couple of gamesThe Bad:- The CPUs in the single player campaign have a tendency to turtle, such that it can get a little infuriating- No magical sphere system like in AoW2 & Shadow Magic, something I enjoyed- Manual strategic combat is very time consuming (still fun, but so time consuming!)- Just one more tu-...  oh god, is that the sun?All in all, AoW3 was worth the wait and seems like a fantastic successor to the franchise. number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 13, 2015
												By and large a solid successor to the Age of Wonders series. The combat's been cleaned up to be even more fun, the visuals are nicer, the mechanics more enjoyable and the calculations behind the results more visible, making it far easier to tell what to do to improve your odds and worsen your enemy's. Also features better enemy AI, in my opinion.About the only downside is that a lot of campaign time involves you hauling around sub-heroes that aren't allowed to die, but it's a minor annoyance. You CAN keep them alive, but sometimes you get pinned into situations where all you can do is either cheat, repeatedly reload autosaves hoping for a lucky break OR skip back several turns to your last manual save so you didn't maneuver one of them into an unsaveable situation.It also feels like the spellbook is a lot slimmer for each class(but also like leader class actually matters a lot more this time around, heroes are another system that's vastly improved). I found myself casting spells a lot less than during Shadow Magic... but on the other hand I also found a lot less battles decided by who had the Casting Points left over to spam "affects all enemies"-spells.Mostly the game feels at a bit of a shortage for "mid-range" spells. That is, spells that aren't as battle-changing as Mass Panic, Smoke Screen or the druid's beast summoning, but still have more effect than just outright attacking with your leader(or having them use an ability like Convert or such). At the moment it feels like most of the spells are either AT the level of just attacking/using an ability or they're huge battlefield-affecting stuff.Still, overall, I'd say the game's an improvement on Shadow Magic, which my impression is that most people consider to be the apex of Age of Wonders so far. The expansions are also nice additions.And of course the soundtrack is just to die for. I absolutely love it.Only thing I have absolute criticism for is the voice-overs between campaign missions. They're just not very well done, though the writing's fine.

												Civilization V meets Heroes of Might & Magic is how I would best describe this game.The fantasy setting is hardly original but the game is gorgeously presented with an easy to use interface, lovely artwork and graphics (anti-aliasing is poor but you can force MSAA+SGSSAA via the driver if you have an NVIDIA graphics card) and a wonderfully atmospheric musical score that fits the game perfectly.Thankfully, the game plays as good as it looks and sounds as well. 												The 4th Age of Wonders is awesome. A gorgeous Fantasy 4X - Hex-grid world much like "Civilisation 5" but with "Heroes of Might and Magic" combat (except heros participate & units don't weaken, they are full strength until dead). So AOW3 is also similar to "Warlock:Master of the Arcane" 1 & 2, except for the combat of course, also AOW3 has more depth. content:
Posted: April 13, 2016
												AOW 3 is a very addictive turn-based X4 game set in a fantasy world, which  has procedurally generated maps for skirmishes and a few campaigns and scenarios. Each match you'll take command of a faction, defined by your leader's race and class. There are 9 different races and 8 different classes, each very unique, and any combination of them can be formed. Furthermore, you can choose up to 3 specializations for your leader, allowing for a ridiculous amount of possibilities. The game focuses a lot on turn-based combat and exploration, akin to HOMM, but improves upon it on several fronts. Pros:- HUGE number of unique units, heroes and spells- Great fantasy setting- Diplomacy is functional but unnecessary- Combat and game mechanics are easy to grasp, but deep and complex. All this complexity is hidden in a user-friendly interface, so there is no need to panic.- Many treasures to unlock through exploration and combat- Resource structures on your city domain often adds unique, important bonuses to economy or military.- RPG elements such as leader customization and progression through combat experience. Each unit also levels up and may gain new abilities.- Factions are very balanced overall- AI is way above average. Not perfect, but very good compared to other games- The world is beautiful and detailed. Graphics are very good.Cons:- Multiplayer isn't so good. It lacks dynamism.- Higher difficulty AI receives resource bonuses rather than greater skill.- Some elements of the interface could be improved, such as managing your active spells.- Procedural map generators often create odd maps, with several different biomes not spread out in a logical way. You have snow biomes close to tropical ones followed by temperate regions, for instance.- Map editor is pretty complicated to use.9/10

content:
Posted: July 17, 2014
												It was a hard decision between this and getting Endless Legend. But I decided to get his and I have to say, I don't feel bad. Endless Legend seems to put more focus into the campign map, which there is nothing wrong with, and I like the way their map is made and layed out into provinces / territories and all of that, but than this game, THIS GAME ROCKS!People complain about it being to balanced, but wtf do you want? One side to totally smash every other side, WELL GUESS WHAT GENIUS? EVERYONE WOULD PICK DWARVES EVERYROUND IF THAT WERE THE CASE! I am glad that the devs decided to balance it out evenly for the factions! I don't want to be a midget after all! No offence to midgets. Instead the game gives you different classes to choose from, so you could an Elven Engineer. Completely unlikely to happen in Dungeons and Dragons but who gives a darn? You can customize your character, heck you can customize the enemy!Also a great feature is the battles, unlike in Civ or any of those games when your army attacks an enemy army you actually control individual units in a kinda like Total War but still Turn Based battle. The map can be customized ALOT. You can even make your own Map / Scenario, AND YOU CAN SCRIPT ANYTHING IN THAT MAP USING LUA! Awesome right?You also have cool units called heros that you can recruit / hire when they pop at your door. Think of like a mix of Mount and Blades / Warcraft / Civilization.The graphics are GREAT for a Turn Based game, the only other two I know of would be Civ V which uses sprites I think and Endless Legend. Endless Legend is more unique story (COMES FROM THE ENDLESS FRANCHISE WHICH EACH GAME FOLLOWS SAME UNIVERSE) and has better campign map but doesnt have battles. Of the three Endless Legend and Age of Wonders from what I can tell are about equally as good depending on your personal preferance. Also to wrap things up I have to mention that lots of people say "All you do is fight, fight, fight." Which is true but they are adding a new win condition in a Free DLC or something (Maybe an update) that allows a non PVP victory, even though chances are, you still will go to war at some point. Thats realistic though, cause when have people stopped fighting??So all in all, GREAT GAME! If you disagree please feel free to comment, just don't troll guys.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 21, 2014
												Just got this game and I don't know who made what first but this is my first time playing a game in the AoW franchise and found it's pretty much the same game as HoMM, although... it's fun. HoMM failed on the fun part their last couple installments and this game delivers. It's a good time. Not to blow my own horn but I think the AI is pretty weak in this, I tried normal difficulty and it was a joke, then 1 up from normal and it still wasn't much of a challlenge. AI would declare war on me, I'd wipe him out without breaking a sweat, I'd try to make peace with the next guy, nope he wants war... he's dead too, etc.Having individual troops in your army rather than stacks of troops like in HoMM is a big improvement. You get more of a feel for how tough your guys are rather than having to always check how big the stack is and do some mental math. Your magic will be strong but not broken and so far I've played 2 classes (Warlord and Sorcerer) and the style of play changes quite a lot so it adds some variety. You get to cast spells both in combat and in the global map and the global spells / disjuction side of the game is very relevant. In combat, your hero can be strong but not that relevant as a fighting unit lategame, but  you'll have spells that make massive impact.As with most TBS games, at the end of the turn the AI helps you control your stuff by prompting you to confirm your orders for your units or give orders to units with none (of course it won't bother you if you "Garrison" the units). But it's kinda reduntant, if I give a unit a move order that takes 5 turns to complete, it won't just automove every turn, it will prompt me to confirm his journey for the next 5 turns. Kinda pointless. Another thing I'd like is to be able to have a town governor or something to build my cities up for me without me having to bother with microing it. Late game, I just wanna manage my armies, not click through the repetative build orders of my 20-30 city empire. I would also like a minister of defence or something so he could worry about  sending my troops out to defend my cities, let me pick what goes in the garrison of border cities  and safe zone cities but don't make me do it myself. hehe. Also the builder unit could use some automation, "go around and make roads to connect my cities" seems a boring task I shouldn't have to micro myself.Okay enough ranting about my pet peeves, overall the game is great and a welcome addition to the turn based strategy genre.I recommend buying if you like this style of game, there's not many out there that are more fun.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 12, 2015
												Have you ever thought that Civilization needed more personality than some pompous know it all from the annals of history strutting around on a horse or something?  Well look no farther as we delve into a world filled with magical creatures such as Dragons, Griffins, Goblins, Orcs, and Succubi...Sweet sweet succubi...Ahem...where was I?Oh yes, the game!  A turn based strategy that does it's best to capture the feel of Civilization with a couple of added bonuses.  Whenever you get into a battle, you end up in a turn based battle scenario with each of your units crying for attention and wanting to kick some♥♥♥♥♥  While it may seem like a standard "Click unit, click enemy, repeat" type of battle method, there are subtle nuances that keep everything in check.  Such as positioning, obstruction for arrows and spells, morale and overall health of a unit that affects their damage output as the battle progresses.  Each race has their own racial bonuses to add to the pile, couple that with your class as well and you have a ton of possibilities as to how your units will fare depending on a situation.  There's enough choice and consequence here to make each game unique.  Speaking of units, let's talk about the big one.  Your hero, head honcho, leader, dictator and ruler of the overworld.  A custom created character (Or pre-made cause you're boring and no one likes you) that can and probably should be your most powerful unit late game.  They are just one of many heroes that you can hire and use to lead your armies, although your hero has the benefit of respawning after several turns if they are killed, unlike hired heroes.  There are a few gripes, such as the low singular army count, as in you can only have 5 units in one army meaning that no battle feels as big as it should without several individual armies backing you up.  The game, at least for me, has a tendency to be bogged down with latency issues.  Clicking and waiting several seconds for the character to pick up on the fact that I'm smacking his or her head in a general direction.  Also, my biggest complaint about the game has to be the multiplayer matchmaking using a P2P (Peer to Peer) network model that requires individual computers to connect to each other.  Understandable from a business perspective, allowing them to shirk off having to run servers, but painfully obnoxious when it comes to the layman just trying to get together with his buds and having to literally turn off his firewall just to connect to anyone. Virus's ho, right? All in all though, the game is generally fun to play if somewhat slower paced than many people are probably hoping for.  The customization of units and the leader of your faction lends to it some sense of personality and attachment as your Orc Dreadnought leads several landships into battle. If you are playing single player, then the mutliplayer connection issues are non-existent.  The latency issues might rear their head even in single play, but being that it's turn based isn't too much of a problem.  If you liked turn based games with RPG mechanics mixed in, you'll like AoW III.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 21, 2014
												This game is very entertaining. I am mainly writing to respond to criticisms that the game lacks depth, which initially made me hestitant about the game. The sale price of 19.99 USD tipped the scales in favor of the game (I was also considering Solar Empire and Endless Space). I'm glad the sale was going on because so far this is a great purchase. For a pure 4x game, I could see a lack of depth. However, this game is a hybrid between a 4x and RPG. I find RPGs too shallow to hold my interest, but the RPG elements here add a facet to this game that I haven't seen in other 4x games. The fact that it's unique makes it interesting. True...the research tree is anemic, but I have a lot of fun learning the spells, which have a fresh and dynamic affect on every aspect of the gaming experience. But to me, the RPG-style battle engine is what takes this to the next level. It is somewhat complex and very engaging, and mixed with more traditional 4x aspects, AOW III provides a nice experience that has kept my interest through that crucial first 24 hours. It also helps that the gameplay is smooth and intuitive, and the graphics are beautiful. So far, this is my favorite purchase since Civ V. One note is that I did have a crash. However, this was after a 14-hour session.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 9, 2016
												6/10. Will probably reinstall eventually. Graphics reign supreme in this remake. I don't much care for the sound but that is typical for me. The game play is quite annoying at times but it is no different than AOW  and AOWII in that sense. Mainly the randomness is what is annoying. That said it is quite playable even with autocombat being terribad. The sameness of the item/skill set does not encourage long games (once you have a complete set of slots you probably don't care about the rest of the dungeons) and the AI is opportunistic (a + thing) but not hard to predict (a - thing). The indicators of how tough a battle will be are frankly disappointing but I have yet to play a game where the predictors were 100%. The fact is, at a certain point you will probably roll over all the Epic, Mythic and Legendary dungeon battles with ease. Full item slots are a must upgrade for this goal. Mainly, it lacks excitement for me but some things about the game are really solid and if I get a hankering for a Warlords style game again I will likely reinstall. I highly recommend playing with your own leader once you figure out how the system works. There is nothing wrong with the stock PCs but they are a little boring. Sadly part of what makes the game lackluster for me is the small variety in the customizable leader abilities. On the other hand every hero you have becomes somewhat customizable once you level them. The points system for doing so seems a little imbalanced and again the variety seems lacking but I expect they withheld a lot of the innovation for DLCs. So you might want to wait for those if you live for diversity. I got the game on sale and for under $8 it is a must buy if you like Warlords style games.

content:
Posted: February 11, 2015
												Lots of style, little substance. I've always gravitated towards 4X games, so when Age of Wonders III came out, I was naturally pretty hyped. However, after playing it, there's quite a few flaws I've noticed about the game:- Character customization is extremely limited- Game is a resource hog. My computer's pretty decent and I still got huge lag spikes pretty frequently- It is far, far too easy to steamroll in this game. Once you've captured one city, the rest is just details. - Very, very little variety. A few leader classes and races and that's it. There's not much assortment of monsters, either, even with the expansion. And lastly, the game simply doesn't have any 'soul'. Remember Heroes of Might and Magic III, where each and every artifact had a little story behind it? Or Fall From Heaven 2, where each faction had a long and sordid history? Or even Fallen Enchantress, with a bit of both? Yeah, none of that's here. The game world is pretty much the blandest you could imagine, with a color palette apparently ripped from Fable 2 that just does not jive with the tone the rest of the game tries to set.

												I love this game, and I can't believe it took me so long to get into it. Seriously, I bought this game shortly after it came out, but put it on a back burner because I had a Hearts of Iron 3 campaign going. AoWIII looked complicated, and it is a steep learning curve. The action bar at the bottom right of the screen helps you take all the actions you can during the turn. The game tells you to research a new skill. It tells you to select what to build in each city, etc. It tells you that an army needs movement orders. Next thing you know, two hours have passed. I give it two thumbs way up.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 8, 2015
												I am a huge fan of turn-based strategy games and turn-based RPGs. If you like any games that fit that mold, I'd highly recommend Age of Wonders 3. Update: Eternal Lords is an must-have expansion to this game. It adds far more features and greatly improves the core game regardless of the faction/leader/race that you choose. Highly recommended still!One of the critical mistakes that professional reviewers have piled on this game is that they compared this to Civilization 5. I would really disagree with that approach, and I'd recommend that they compare this to Heroes of Might and Magic and/or King's Bounty the Legend. I feel that Age of Wonders 3 gives FAR more replay value and is incredibly well thought out, especially when compared to the sixth entry of the Heroes series. Diplomacy is second-hand, as the majority of the game is built around the excellent tactical combat. Your goal in this game is to win through total-war and that purity of focus does not get old because of the sheer variety of magic, units and scenarios.I have played all of the previous Age of Wonders games, and after having been spoiled by this game (and the Golden Realms expansion), I don't think that I can return to them (despite them being incredible games in their own right!).

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 7, 2014
												I've been so excited for this ever since I got a whiff of a hint of this title being under development. I've been a massive fan of the AoW series for years.This game does alot of things right, it's beautiful, it flows well, it's easy to pick up, but difficult to master. Just a personal thing for me though that has kind of ruined it...the unit groups. Previous games had single units put together into parties of 8, where anywhere up to 56 units in a single fight, which is epic when playing with friends. True, the battles tended to be rather long in multiplayer, but the single player was thorough pleasure. The shortening of the parties to a limit of 6 has kind of killed the careful planning that I use to enjoy. I know I should judge this game based on it's own value, but since it IS Age of wonders 3, it feels like a step backwards...

content:

												Things I like:- A ton of options when creating a custom game.- Several game modes to pick from.- Underground maps.- Good information in tooltips when creating games makes it easy the first time.- Every levelup for your hero gives several options for improvements of various stats and new abilities.- Just one more turn...Things I don't like:- In combat, when you consider making an attack, the game won't tell you if you will get flanked.- Auto-save is done at the end of your turn. This means if you die and load an auto-save, any mistake has already been done. You also can't decide how often auto-saves are done.- Resurrecting dead heroes require that you research and cast a spell. Because of this, losing a hero can easily be a major consern,- Failed quests dont disappear from the quest log. What do I need to see them for?- I can't find any overview of "Empire Upgrades"

BUT.This game is hard as hell, you will build up a nice city, raise some troops, gather heroes, venture into dungeons and bandit hideouts devestating the enemy. You will feel like someone kinda powerful. But then there is that moment when you meet another faction, concider yourself lucky when that faction want's to live in peace, otherwise they will throw hordes of enemies at your walls and that might just it. And if you had been very busy expanding, expect revolts, civil war and desertions.This only accounts for players who are not really experienced in heavy strategy like me, I know there are ways to be beast at this game but whatever forum entry I've read about it has that one message saying: "There is only one way to play this game" and I dont know about you but...I kinda like to play a game the way I want. I will wait for the next DLC and try the new races, but the harshness of this game killed it for me.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 2, 2014
												Definitely a fun hex-based, turn-based, fantasty,type...thing.A very fun experience overall, although there are some changes which I am not too fond of. Still prefer this series over the Heroes and Might and Magic series. A. Combat. the combat is great in that you still have the massive amount of soldiers all fighting each other with individual abilities and stats. The cons (for me) are that: range attacks seem to have been simplified, at long ranges your shots plain out do less damage, when there is obstructions the damage goes down. I have yet to experience a missed attack or an attack hitting a unit or object obstructing the projectile path. Another thing is that the game has switched from the old squad of single units (like a party of heroes almost) to every unit being a small group of units in civ, this appears to be mostly visual and does affect the damage too much when most of that unit/group dies but I don't like it (although that's just my problem and probably doesn't bother anyone else). Debuffs are almost a necessity because there are some units you will come across that are just plain out overpowered (one unit in the game can pretty much kill off an entire party of units in one hit). All hero units have individual skillsets now, items are nice (flying mounts and rare mounts look amazing). B. Civ management. Civs are pretty simple as always, build cities, simple buildings and tile management is non-existent, just get it into your border and it's yours. The Magic research tree is now the overall tech tree, this means you make the choice between researching tech upgrades and researching new spells, odd but it works since the older games only really had you research a few key spells and then not care about the rest. C. Visuals/Audio. Everything looks great, background tracks are amazing. D. Story, it's alright from what I've seen but it's not the most captivating experience. It makes everything a bit more interesting but the campaigns are more of a do this objective because reasons, rather than getting you motivated by the story.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 26
												You know how in most fantasy games the lore of the world consists of truly grand historical events, and yet they are often told through exposition dumps and feel completely abstract and irrelevant? Well, in Age of Wonders 3 history happens here and now, and you are the one making it.Don't expect it to be a 4X game though, it's much more similar to Heroes of Might and Magic III or even King's Bounty. The game takes place on separate maps (pre-designed, randomly generated or user-created) and the story campaigns are focused on individual characters and their heroic exploits. Expect to fight a lot, because combat is the meat of this game. It's incredibly deep, with dozens (probably hundreds) of units, spells, abilities and synnergies between them. But what makes it really special is how magic works. I think this game might have every type of spell ever conceived by a fantasy author. Seriously. Making too much mana and not enough gold? Cast a persistent spell that literally makes it rain money upon your city. Having trouble sieging an outpost with stone walls? Cast some climbing vines that will slowly corrode them turn by turn. Or maybe just infest the city with a plague of insects. You can summon entire armies of gargantuan creatures instead of producing units the old-fashioned way. It's ridiculous. There's a crazy amount of possibilities. And then there's two expansions, both of which probably have more content than the entire Heroes VII. And then there are mods.However, most of these things you will have to find out for yourself. The tutorial doesn't do a good job of explaining core mechanics of the game. And while experimenting with magic and army compositions is great fun, some aspects of empire management could have been explained a bit better.So if you're looking for a standard 4X game, you won't find it here. But if you're looking for deep tactical combat, powerful spells and fantasy adventures, this is one of the most impressive strategy games to come out in recent years.

content:
Posted: April 18, 2014
												The 4th Age of Wonders is awesome. A gorgeous Fantasy 4X - Hex-grid world much like "Civilisation 5" but with "Heroes of Might and Magic" combat (except heros participate & units don't weaken, they are full strength until dead). So AOW3 is also similar to "Warlock:Master of the Arcane" 1 & 2, except for the combat of course, also AOW3 has more depth. Pro- Great graphics- great unit variety including evil penguins and other strange units- variety of spells & status effects- you don't skip battles because they are fun- editor- several unit stacks joining for bigger battles- Veterans of 4X and TBS will love AOW3- hero leveling, items and the different mounts (with models)- diplomacy - a basic system but it does have oneCon- City/Empire management needs improving: I wish AOW3 had the steamline features of Civilisations 4 & 5 (eg, next town button or an AI City manager)- City management is not complex unlike rest of the game and the genre.- doesn't explain all concepts.- enemy sniping your heroes for instant Game Fail is really annoying - use care and save scum.- just one more turn....- AOW3's "civ-o-pedia" is good but it is no civ-o-pedia.AOW3 will blow away Sid Meier's Civilisations with a good expansion pack.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 19, 2014
												I had a lot of hope for this game. I had a lot of disapointment with this game. Everything in the game is at best "ok". There is no real progression tree telling you what you need to research to get what, or how far through the research you were. The range on ranged weapons is ridiculously small and the penalty for the range was even more ridiculous. Apparently no one on the development team has ever spoken with or researched historical bow range increments.The melee combat is pretty stupid with the implementation of flanking. Apparently if an enemy is approaching you, and outside of one step away, your unit would never think to watch them closing in on you, and thus should be be able to annhialate you. If you were actively engaged with an enemy, this makes sense. When you aren't engaged? The development team shows just as much initiative in considering melee combat as they did with ranged.The magic use in tactical and strategic combat ranges from flavorless to boring to pointless. There are uses for magic other than nailing a ranged attack on an enemy, but most of them are not any more effective, so there isn't a point in doing so most of the time. The replayability factor in this game is non-existant. It's not a terrible game, it's just not engaging, exciting, or really entertaining. It's blah in practically every way, and a huge disapointment.

content:
Posted: June 28, 2014
												Don't waste your time if you have any interest in city building.  The only way to succeed in AoW3 is to rush at the first turn.  There is no economy, there is no cultural development, and there is no questing with your hero characters.  This game is all about zerging with Tier 1 units.  If you choose to spend time developing your cities, prepared to be overwhelmed by your 3-4 enemy NPCs (not counting Independent colonies).  Choose to defend your city?  That's a waste of your time.I really tried hard to like this game, but I couldn't do it.  This is not turn-based strategy, it is a zerg fest plain and simple.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 13, 2016
												AOW 3 is a very addictive turn-based X4 game set in a fantasy world, which  has procedurally generated maps for skirmishes and a few campaigns and scenarios. Each match you'll take command of a faction, defined by your leader's race and class. There are 9 different races and 8 different classes, each very unique, and any combination of them can be formed. Furthermore, you can choose up to 3 specializations for your leader, allowing for a ridiculous amount of possibilities. The game focuses a lot on turn-based combat and exploration, akin to HOMM, but improves upon it on several fronts. Pros:- HUGE number of unique units, heroes and spells- Great fantasy setting- Diplomacy is functional but unnecessary- Combat and game mechanics are easy to grasp, but deep and complex. All this complexity is hidden in a user-friendly interface, so there is no need to panic.- Many treasures to unlock through exploration and combat- Resource structures on your city domain often adds unique, important bonuses to economy or military.- RPG elements such as leader customization and progression through combat experience. Each unit also levels up and may gain new abilities.- Factions are very balanced overall- AI is way above average. Not perfect, but very good compared to other games- The world is beautiful and detailed. Graphics are very good.Cons:- Multiplayer isn't so good. It lacks dynamism.- Higher difficulty AI receives resource bonuses rather than greater skill.- Some elements of the interface could be improved, such as managing your active spells.- Procedural map generators often create odd maps, with several different biomes not spread out in a logical way. You have snow biomes close to tropical ones followed by temperate regions, for instance.- Map editor is pretty complicated to use.9/10

Since a lot of great reviews are out there, I'll just reaffirm the ones that state this game focuses more on action and less on managemet. The city management system is fairly shallow, but deep enough to keep it interesting. The combat however is superb and the level of detail for both character design and animation is just astounding. The reverse of Endless Legend, which is much deeper with management but a fairly shallow combat system.I do love the AoW3 campaign though, great concept incorporating single player RPG's into a turn based strategy sim, I dig it.If you like turn based games and fantasy, there's no way you can't like this game. It might not blow your socks off, but it is more than worth its asking price (especially if on sale). Highly recommended.8.5/10  would command troll army again

												This is my second time writing a review of this game. When it first came out it was horribly unbalanced and the AI cheesed hardcore to compensate for poor AI. I don't notice any AI improvement, and the high level unit spam continues still, although everyone said it was fixed. The AI does have its moments, in tactical combat the cannons line up shots nicley, for example. I was able to progress since the big update, but the AI spam, makes the game repetitive and tedious.The graphics are good, music is ok, not as good as past games. The game feels a bit slow and clunky, but my machine is a few years old. The single player game offers challenge to the seasoned AoW player. Players new to the genre will suffer. This game still does suffer from a common issue; easy is too easy and normal is too hard. The AI starts off with much more resouses you have and sends high level armies to attack you non stop, eventually you can just find your self in dead end games where you basically have to give up and start over. Setting the difficulty down is no solution as easy is no challenge and no fun. Ultimately, I’m mildy satisfied. Worth a play if you have nothing better to do and a lot of patience. 4/10

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 4, 2015
												I whole-heartedly recommend Age of Wonders III to everyone who likes turn-based strategy.It is a sequel to a game series that manages to hit that sweet spot every sequel wants to hit: To introduce enough new content and mechanics to be its own game, while managing to keep up the feeling of the original.And it's just as addicting, too. You can play either via network (Internet or local), or the good old hot-seat mode. Just remember to ask your friends to bring a sleeping bag when starting a hotseat game on a huge map, because you might be busy for a week. There are campaigns of different difficulty for a smooth learning curve, and they also provide you with an interesting story in which your choices matter (Not every choice, of course, but there are points where you can choose which direction the story takes).The game is a good way to start with TBS games, not only because of the good tutorial provided by the first campaign map, but also the helpful UI. At the beginning of your turn, it shows you everything that happened as messages on the side of the screen, and provides you with a button that tells you which issue to deal with next. That might be considered a bit mothering, but it certainly helps to prevent you from forgetting to order a new building in one of your cities, which can easily slip your mind in an empire of twenty metropolises.There are a few things that I have issue with, most notably some balance choices, but the devs are active, and listening to the community, so that will only improve over time. As long as there's people willing to buy the game, they will continue to deliver, and not only small balance patches, but also large dlcs with new factions, classes and campaigns.

content:
Posted: November 29, 2014
												For all the hex-grid 4X lovers out there, this game is for you.Think of Civilization 5 with a fantasy theme but add RPG stats and skills to your civ's leader, then they become a controllable hero unit on the map, AND units can stack into armies.THEN whenever you fight in combat, zoom in to an expanded version of the hex on the map, and its a-whole-nother hex grid to fight over complete with varying terrain, elevation, climate, and occasionally besieging a city or fort's walls!And then there's the massive depth to each unit. Not just the heroes, but each individual military unit will have their own RPG-style stats with strengths and weaknesses and even crazier promotions than you could possibly imagine (my favorite so far is getting a flying, flame-breathing dragon mount for my leader and handing the horse off to another general)In the war of 4X, I've seen a lot of games rise to the occasion, and a lot more of them fall flat but this one takes the cake.

content:
Posted: April 12, 2015
Let me preface this review by saying that I don't have a lot of experience in this genre outside of the civilization series which I have played since Civ 3.With that said, I absolutely love and adore this game. In short;Pros; Great gameplay. High replayability. Very interesting tactical combat. Very good MP. Easy to get into. A -lot- of customization. Fantastic graphics and beautiful music.Cons; Can turn out to have very long games. Unfortunately not that many people in MP. A lacking tutorial. And the AI is relatively easy.Age of Wonders, in a nutshell, is a series that combines the best aspects of a Civilization game, with the best aspects of a fantasy RPG, in the same vein as games like Dominions or Might & Magic. Great empire management combined with a deep and complex tactical combat system makes this game a must have for fans of Heroes of Might and Magic and Fallen Enchantress or Warlock. It stands out in portraying a highly detailed and breathing fantasy world, it's lethal and thrilling combat and enchanting music score. The sheer number of units, abilities, spells and maps (thanks to a random map generator) makes this a game that will be played for years, decades.And there is just so much to do each turn in this game, so many armies to manage and cities to build. The gorgeous world is waiting to be explored and the various monsters are ready to do battle. All of this is paired with truly wonderful tactical combat. There are just so many different ways to approach combat that it's dizzying.I would recommend this game to anyone. If you're a fan of the series, definitely check it out. If you're not a fan, go ahead and check it out anyway.

Posted: January 25, 2015
												A game with great ideas and competent design, but broken by simple details that shouldn't ever be this much of a problem. I'll say first that I haven't played this game a lot.  I played on a couple of maps and some of the campaign but even in that time I saw virtually everything I needed to see.  The game is fantastically designed in terms of artwork, battle system and even map design.  My first impression was extremely good.  Unfortunately, it all falls apart due to basic things like unit variety, balancing and pacing.  The devs did such a terrible job designing, differentiating and balancing their units that all the things the game does right ends up being worthless.  High tier units are way too easy to acquire, cost way too little, and are soooo much better than all of the lower tier units that you never want to/should build anything else than full stacks of whatever your faction's T4 unit is.  It's dumb and it would be so easy to fix.  That makes it all the more frustrating.
