content:
Posted: June 4, 2014
												I'm saying no for two reasons: cost and depth, but take out the cost issue and I say yes.AoW II is a pretty fun game.  It's your good 'ol 4x with no twists.  It has just enough customizability in it to make it warm n fuzzy. It does have any real crazy bug issues and It's pretty enough.Maybe that's why I'm so meh about this game?  It meets just "enough" of an expectation that I can't really call it out on anything.  But then there is the combat which is fun.  It has some real tactical depth to it, but even then... well... the game gives you the option to just let it run the combat... which it does very effectively... so after a while I just stopped running the combats and just auto-ran all of em.I think the biggest and most actual criticism I have (after the cost fo the game of course) is that there is no real depth to a long game.  For example, Civ 5 or even Fallen Enchantress have some crazy crazy deep game to them.  Civ 5 is just long.  By the time you get to the end of the tech tree the outcome of the game has usually been decided because you're usually playing against a difficulty rating... not a civ.  In Fallen Enchantress there is an entirely "other level" of deep game based on♥♥♥♥♥♥that's out in the world that is so ♥♥♥♥ing hard to kill or overcome that you have to be scared of those places or creatures because if you aren't, then they will ♥♥♥♥ing ruin you.  Imagine monsters walking around the world that don't necessarily care that you're there until you get in their way... like the Spirit of the Forest in Princess Mononoke.  Litterally gods walking about the world.  You have to gear up and prepair to even make an attempt on something like that... and it takes a while... and it leaves you with a sense of accomplishment when finally completed.  AoW II has no "other level" of scary in it and certainly no depth of field for it's AI.  At least with CIV 5 there are differences in HOW the different civilizations will approach destroying you.  In AoW II it's like being swarmed by a hoard of really angry bees.  Why are they attacking you?  No ♥♥♥♥ing reason at all... they just ARE.So that's that.  Would this game get a thumbs up if it were MORE interesting in a lot of it's aspects than just "enough" depth of customization or just "enough" of 4x or if it's different civilizations weren't exactly the same just named differently?  Yes.  And I feel like the makers of this game knew they were making a game that was, in fact, only just "enough"... that's why it's $40 rather than $50 or $60.  In the end it's a shallow and pretty game with some decent music that costs too much.  Buy it when it's on sale.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 24, 2014
												As an old fan of Master of Magic, Age of Wonders: Shadow Magic and the Fall From Heaven Civ4-mod, my hope when purchasing this was that it would replace the current game, my small group of hardcore "slow" strategy gamers played against eachother. Especially the promise that a Play by Email function would be included, made all of us pre-buy it before it came out.So what did we get?We got an absolutely stunning turn-based game, that takes a lot of the best that all games before it had. It has this feeling of immersion that makes you want to play again and again.Notice that I say "a lot of the best", because it is not perfect... Yet. I'll tell you a bit about why it will be.Multi-player.The online multiplayer is easy and very solid, compared to most other games. Of course, since it takes a lot of time to play a Age of Wonders III game, having several people being connected for days will eventually experience drop-outs. Getting back up unfortunately requires a full re-load and reconnect, but nothing is lost when it happens.Triumph has been promising us a Play be Email function since before the game came out, and it should be very close to release. When it does, multi-player games will explode in number. And to top it off, Triumph has already described some details that might make this the easiest to use PBEM function ever. You always have problems with who has the turn, but Triumph might be able to fix that problem, which I believe would be first and best in gaming history. It would be... Perfect.Tactical combatNot much to say. It has never been done better. Every tactical battle can be approached differently, and the troops you bring to the combat changes everything. Oh, and sound and video is beautiful and interesting. AOWIII tactical is just... Perfect.Depth and contentWhen the game released, although it was beautiful and the engine worked very well, felt like a dumbed-down version of AOW: Shadow Magic. Fewer races, the items on the map felt the same, and every game played more or less the same with an off-balanced strategy, that could win all games, so everyone did just that. But it's Triumph, guys!: For every patch, DLC, upgrade and whatever they decide to call it, the game has become richer and funnier to play. The new game function of having treasure sites making specific troops types better (like a mithril source in Master of Magic) makes every city a possible specialist city to be nurtured and defended. With new races, classes, treasure huts, and stuff springing up continually, this game seems like a friendship that grows for every expansion. With the ideas already on Triumphs existing idea list, when it comes to depth and content, all these guys have to do is show up for work, and this game will be... Perfect.ReplaybilityLet's face it. Every game gets old at some point. Only a few games stand out and goes into history as "the game we played for ages". What was it that made Shadow Magic better than AOW vanilla, Fall from Heaven better than Civ 4 vanilla? Every game played out differently. Why is it that most people only plays CIV5 and CIV:Beyond Earth for a few weeks and then move on? Because every game basically plays out the same. AOWIII is at risk here. The classes of AOWIII is the distinguishing part that does not make every game bland, but will it be enough? Fall from Heaven changed CIV4 with the interesting notion of going from "research everything" to "You can only afford one way through the research tree, so choose the path that plays well with what you have found in this particular game". And it changed everything. The research tree of AOWIII has few differences based on magical affinity, but a Tier II summon basically does the same, cost the same, and appear at the same time. There's not that much strategy, and you will typically choose the same spell strategy every time. Cities are almost entirely the same, races don't alter things much. A bit has already been done there, giving the races racial traits. For instance, the bard is equipped with a bow. But a High Elf Bard now has a Longbow, which makes all the difference. But the other races? It's much the same. All cities function, all cities gives basically the same amount of resources. In Shadow Magic, I found myself changing populations several times a game: Only two races could grow the essential crops in shadow world, so better make it one of those. Some races had alignments that made them impossible to hold unless you did something, Cities could be physically moved away from a lost area, if you repopulated it with nomads. Elf cities hid themselves behind trees. You had choices. In AOWIII every race will join you without too much trouble and the cities are basically the same. Alignment doesn't really play a role, although the mechanic is there.The general feeling is a well-known one: The new school game developers are scared about alienating the impatient youths that nothing in the game must be frustrating. Only problem is, turnbased games are too slow to hold impatient players anyways, so trying to cater for everyone just makes the game bland, instead of making possibilities soar. If you have ever played 100+ multiplayer rounds of the same game, you know that when you stop being able to surprise your opponents, you are ready to move on.If, however, the developers should go all in on making things feel... different... then this game already has everything needed in place. In fact, with increased replayability, some of it already in the pipeline, this game has the potential to go from great to... absolutely perfect.I absolutely recommend this game to every turn-based strategy gamer out there.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2014
												This game is pretty underwhelming.  It seems like it could offer a decent amount of gameplay - time wise - but I'm finding it quite stale and uninspiring.  It certainly doesn't give a person that "just one more turn" type of feeling.If you enjoyed Heroes of Might and Magic you will probably enjoy this game ( I know there's probably countless comparisons in these review pages, but it's true, it's a HoMM clone just with more utility and production from your towns). Think of it as HoMM meets Civ: combat and exploration, and even the way your hero is presented, is total HoMM, but in this game you get the choice of where to place your towns and manage your production.  Your heroes also are bit more customizable in terms of spell research and how to spend upgrade points.And it's unnecessarily challenging too.  I set it to easy just so I could breeze through, explore the story, and get a feel for it, but the fights usually result in large casualties.  This forces you to stay still and keep building/replenishing your forces.  Then, while you're at the front lines - holding what you THINK is a choke point - the enemy will come down the river, flank you, overwhelm the defenses and take out your capital, forcing you to march aaaaalll the way back to face them, during which time they conquer your choke point and whatever else they can get before you counter attack that too.  In short: production has to be a unit spam/zerg for either saturated defenses or replenishing offense.But really, overall, a game should be FUN above all else and I find this game is just really...."meh".  I'm probably going to play through it all - eventually - but only when I'm super bored.  It's going to be sitting on my desktop for awhile.  Glad I only paid $13 for it.  There's (probably) a lot of game time value, but I'm certainly not finding it to have entertainment value.3/10

												I had hopes for this game and did some homework on it to try to determine if it was worth paying full retail, and turns out it isn't. Graphically the game looks fine. I'm not one to gush about graphics; gameplay is king for me. The game also seemed to run o.k.The main issue I seem to be having is the tactical combat. Just a few niggly bits jump out immediately and, frankly, I don't want to keep playing. This is quite disappointing.You start combats just a few steps from the edge of the map, making tactical retreats nearly impossible. Pretty much every engagement is only a simple turn or two away from melee. This nearly nullifies missile unit's tactical options. Since you are fairly limited on number of units to begin with, this is pretty major.Balance seems off. As an example, I ganged up on an assasin unit that is seen in the second battle of the starter campaign. I whittled the unit down to a single health point of 36 (1/36). Next turn, the unit assassinated my hero, and the game was over. Second turn into an easy game. I can see this being a selling point for many but turns out that you should be managing unique saves of every turn unless you want to replay the last several turns since the last save every time some game balance issue results in the end of the game.Why not just use the auto save? Because during the same game, I had a full stack placed on my second town and my main army was marching. Suddenly a two stack attack landed on my town. Defeat, with the death of a hero that must survive. Game over on easy for the second time in 30 minutes. Auto save has my other army more than a turn away and unable to help. So, I must revert to a previous save and replay several battles and tutorial elements.The game is o.k., or would be if it was priced like and indie title at about $10 or $15. But for $40 I don't think the balance is there. Perhaps some of my concerns will be addressed. Perhaps it's just not for me. Either way, I felt compelled to share my thoughts.

content:
Posted: June 28, 2014
												Don't waste your time if you have any interest in city building.  The only way to succeed in AoW3 is to rush at the first turn.  There is no economy, there is no cultural development, and there is no questing with your hero characters.  This game is all about zerging with Tier 1 units.  If you choose to spend time developing your cities, prepared to be overwhelmed by your 3-4 enemy NPCs (not counting Independent colonies).  Choose to defend your city?  That's a waste of your time.I really tried hard to like this game, but I couldn't do it.  This is not turn-based strategy, it is a zerg fest plain and simple.

number of helpful: 9 of 18 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 13, 2014
												This is my second time writing a review of this game. When it first came out it was horribly unbalanced and the AI cheesed hardcore to compensate for poor AI. I don't notice any AI improvement, and the high level unit spam continues still, although everyone said it was fixed. The AI does have its moments, in tactical combat the cannons line up shots nicley, for example. I was able to progress since the big update, but the AI spam, makes the game repetitive and tedious.The graphics are good, music is ok, not as good as past games. The game feels a bit slow and clunky, but my machine is a few years old. The single player game offers challenge to the seasoned AoW player. Players new to the genre will suffer. This game still does suffer from a common issue; easy is too easy and normal is too hard. The AI starts off with much more resouses you have and sends high level armies to attack you non stop, eventually you can just find your self in dead end games where you basically have to give up and start over. Setting the difficulty down is no solution as easy is no challenge and no fun. Ultimately, I’m mildy satisfied. Worth a play if you have nothing better to do and a lot of patience. 4/10

content:
Posted: May 26, 2016
												Its a shame this game has so many problems. It's like Civilization except fantasy. But the units are all very unbalanced, the campaign difficulty is absurd at times, and while the tactical turn based battle are a nice concept, it's not done well at all. Too often, open field battles are way too easy, and on the opposite end siege battles are way too hard. You'll often lose whole armies to a handful of defenders in the campaign because they have one or two uber upper tiered units with some dumb ability that will flat out erradicate your army.Heroes have spells which are spammable to no end, especially if you constantly tech up your mana and spell pools. AI will of course go out of their way to mess with you, attacking undefended locations that they should theoretically not even know exist, a surefire sign of a cheating AI.Many times when you win, you'll feel it was undeserved, and when you lose, you'll feel cheated by a game seemingly not playing by its own rules.If you're a Civilization styled Strategy fanatic, yeah you might like it. But if you're like me and like these types of games to relax, this game caused me way too much stress during my relaxation time for me to reccomend it. Buy it on sale if at all.

content:
Posted: July 20, 2015
												as a long time fan of the series (playing all 4 of the games, counting shadow magic) I have to say when i heard that they were reviving my favorite stragegy game series (civ very close behind) i was stoked, and it looked cool but when i saw the trailers i knew this would be a big big ♥♥♥♥up. i love these games to death but Aoe3 is a failure. The game only has basic remnents of the past games feeling like a whole new game from a different series, and while alot of ppl like the fact that its similar to the new strategy games, and is way different than the others, but its not good. or better not even close, i would rate all the others ones 8-9-10s (not in any order but Shadow magic was my fav). The fact that this game is basically a copy of civ 5 hurts alot. While i love civ 5 this is not the game that i would play. In fact i just wouldnt play this game. The devs took 30 steps back this this "forward title" this game is more shallow than any strat game ive ever played, the fantasy that was so amazing in the others, just isnt here, the units are dull and boring, the combat is a mess from the much simpler old style (from you guessed it, the predicessors), and the leaders are dull and boring, none of them have charater like they did in the last game. Its just a joke. final verdict is a 6/10 its playable but its not good, if you want a fantasy strat game i suggest endless legend, this is a worse endless legend  with civ 5 in the mixing pan. if your a fan of the old games im sorry your not gonna find it in this mess of a game. no story, no depth no fun. Yea im sad too Rest in Peace Age of Wonders, you filled me with so much joy and love, it was great while it lasted peace guys

content:
Posted: June 25, 2014
												Tatical Combat is the worst i ever seen in a Turn-based Strategy game!When someone try to tell you that this game has a nice tatical combat system, than he is a turn-based-strategy noob or just a god damn liar!The units in an army don't have any initative, instead all units in one army make there move! So you can move your whole units before the enemy is able to do anything...When you are finished then it is the enemys armys turn... And guess what... he also can move all his troops in one turn. And then its your turn again... and so on...The first army that will get in range of the enemy army will be completly crushed by the other army, because the other army can attack the first army with all of it troops, before the first army get a chance to fight back...WHAT A F***ING JOKE!I don't know which dev had the idea to implement such a poor tatical combat system, but from my point of view it is a completly gamebreaking mechanism. And i never has seen such a bad combat system in over 20 years of playing turn-based strategies!If you got game like heroes of might and magic or fallen enchantress just stay with them.They have a alot better tatical combat design than this pile of BS.Beside from that, the controls and handling mechanism of the game is not very polished and a little bit anoying.If you really want this game than wait till it cost 5-10 bucks and don't make the same mistake like i did by wasting 20 bucks in it.

content:
Posted: April 1, 2014
												At first I thought this is a good game, but after a few hours in I realized I was just fooling myself, it's a bad game.* After killing 11 out of 12 soldiers in a squad it still does the same damage as if nothing changed,* Heroes customization has too many useless traits, and even level 10 heroes aren't that powerful.* You can only cast 1 spell per combat round, even if you have 2 or 3 casting heroes. plain stupid. * Casting global enchantments is pointless, whatever you cast is immediately dispelled the following round.* Heroes only give their bonuses if they are leaders, so you can't stack two heroes in an army. why?!* All races have the same buildings.* There is almost no different between the units of each race (race 1-  priest shots fire, race2 - exact same priest, but it shots poison etc...), choosing a race is almost purly about aesthetics.* It takes ages to clear a map, and 75% of that time is spent waiting on your cities to produce enough units to take down the 3 army stacks the computer has holed up in his castle. really really boring.* Not enough ruins and such to explore, you barely get 2 items per game.* Strategic battle starting positions are insane. units start out all over the place.I can go on for ages, this is a bad game, they did not think this through, this is a big disappointment!

content:
Posted: November 1, 2016
												So far, this game is a treat. Combined with some of its expansions and balancing mods (all available on Steam), the possibilities for interesting gameplay are vast, both tactically and strategically. It's easy to learn and hard to master, so I recommend practicing your strategies on lower difficulties before diving into hardcore war gaming. I know I'm going to put a lot more hours into this game, there's just so much to see and do.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 4, 2015
												The game before this one(AOW:SM) is the greatest fantasy turn based strategy game ever.This one does not hold up, it has some of the same bugs and they changed the rules to make it less playable. I was able to beat it like the last one, but I belong to the cult of the random map(check my achievments) and played it 12 players all king at king level with everything on fast and I was able to find a good place to fester(more about that) just like in the last one but there are major differences. Now there are some very good things about this game as well. Also I played a draconian earth specialist drednaut. The lack of carriers.I mean units that can carry other units like the airships in AOW:SM, or the steam tank. It was very handy to use carriers to put a city in a hard to reach place by transporting a settler. Now it has to be a place that you can get to normally, BTW anyone know of a way to have a hero give its unit lava walking?  I was unable to and just gave up,.The magic item creation system using points. This just makes no sense, I mean why limit the total number of magic items you can create? It just takes away from the fun of the game. That was half the fun, once you got a bunch of items and figured out how you wanted them on your heros you will fill in the holes with stuff you would make yourself. It wasnt as powerful as the stuff you would find but that was ok, magic items are magic items. That champion levels are unlimited. I am normally not against things being unlimited, but this really can unbalence the game. Infact its how I won the game, in the old game I would use dragons or dread reapers all magiced and veteraned up as machines of destruction, nothing could stand in their way.  I might lose one in a really tough battle but I always had one to replace it. But there was a limit, once you got 255 experience points on  a unit it was maxed out. Now I have had units at champion level 60+, mostly earth elementals. they start having hundreds of hit points and the only way to get rid of them is banish them and that doesnt always work. Now this is against the ai, but its a perfect way to make a very sharp stick, take  18 earth elementals, march them past a city or two and  take a city a little bit behind the lines. replace any loses and leave them in a triangle formation in the city(3x6) and just wait. It wont take long and the AI will start attacking it with everything its got, keep replacing loses and getting more and more experience points. Once they are above champion level 10 I would be surprised if you had replace one. Also always do autocombat, the ai never seems to use banish during autocombat. And when you get one above level 40-50 you can do something like station it with a bunch of nubes at a tunnel enterance and not worry about holding it.And a unit of 6 high level(over 40) earth elementals can hold a city no matter what, I have seen them be surrounded by 36 units and most of them were juggernauts and not lose a single unit, not even have a unit with any real damage.  I would just use cities like that as farms to raise really high level earth elementals which I then used to win the game with. If I had figured out about earth elementals earlier it wouldnt have taken me like 1300 turns. I have my last save game before I won if anyone wants it. That you can only cast one spell per turn including your heros. I admit that it does slow down the play some and I am not 100% agianst it, but I miss being able to cast a spell and have a hero follow it up with one of their own. The same bugs, save game, takes forever with too many units. game will start to crash alot after turn 1000 on a huge map. I swear this game has some of the same bugs as the last one, its like they reused the same code for alot of things. Sometimes if you run the game for a really long time it loses the ability to write to the disk properly. if when you go to save a game and you dont see an autosave even if its turned on then thats sign thats are messed up. There is a work around, save to the cloud which works fine, exit and restart and load the game from the cloud. Also even on a powerful machine when its on a huge map with lots of players and with lots of armies,  each turn can take almost 10 minutes sometimes . Plus after turn 1000 the game starts crashing, and I usally have to go back to the autosave and I am fine. After awhile its crashes like every turn or so. I have a save game I can send you if you want to see. I like the class system, the new units, extra hero level, how the new heros work, alot of the new game play and the graphics. The graphics are really nice. I wish someone would make a mod for AOW3 that addresed these problems, it probably would be the best fantasy turn-based strategy game around. festering, is the process of finding a good defensible position using it as a base to eventually start regaining terrority. In AOW:SM it was underground or even better an island in the shadow lands. The only way to reach them is be directly above it and do a shadow shift. In this one I was able to fester in a nice cave underground that had two narrow entrances. I build a tower just inside the enterance, and then a city behind that. So an invading army could only bring in 6 units to attack my 18-24 units. They wouln't even try, well after I created a trap city nearby. Thats a city with nothing in it, so the AI would immediatley take it, but its close by enough for me to use forge blast many times a turn till they are weak enough that I can send my heros to mop up. Just keep your base safe while  you farm high level units to eventually take the whole board.My yes to recommend this game is only because its possible to fix these issues and the game looks really good.

content:
Posted: February 15, 2015
												*CAUTION*: I would rate this game 3.5/5 stars.Bottom Line: What this game does, this game does well; but it's what it doesn't do that hurts the most. It's worthwhile for multiplayer, but for singleplayer I'd look elsewhere. My personal recommendation would be Fallen Enchantress Legendary Heroes.This game offers some of the most advanced features found in any 4X game, but at the expense of bread-and-butter features we've all come to love and expect. For example: Every unit has numerous abilities, but you're only allowed to cast up to a certain amount of magic per turn (ie. campaign map turn); this means that you could have hundreds of battles per turn, but end up using magic in only a handful. Personally, I think this is extremely unreasonable and silly. I am not opposed to having a global mana pool (which this game does have), but I think it is much more realistic and enjoyable to have casting units use spells every battle round than just be subject to a global cap. Even a per-battle cap or per-unit-per-battle or per-unit-per-turn cap would have been more reasonable. I understand that this must have been implemented as a way to prevent exploiting battle through repetitive casting, but it would have been better to counterbalance the repeated-casting system rather preventing it from happening in the first place.I also very much miss the "crowd attack" feature, in which allies adjacent to the enemy join in on melee attacks, that games such as Fallen Enchantress have. Sure, we might have multi-army battles, but what's the point when the quality of an individual battle when down the toilet?And the campaign maps are so boring! Yeah, the terrain is very well varied, and naval battles aren't terrible (though they aren't great either), but the almost complete and total lack of events, and the very elementary spawning of mobs and acquisition of heroes leaves much to be desired. Contrast, again, to Fallen Enchantress, in which events are varied and frequent, both good and bad, both global and local, and where mobs spawn and respawn as opposed to be eliminated once and for all once they are defeated. Yeah, Fallen Enchantress isn't perfect (the #1 problem: it lacks multiplayer!!! But I still think it is the greatest single-player 4X game of all time, at the time of writing), nor is any 4X game (currently!), but the best way to describe AOW3 in one word is disproportionate. Enjoyable in aspects, and frustratingly deprived in others.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 11, 2015
												First I'd like to say I don't totally hate this game. There are aspects that are done well and are enjoyable. The graphics are very nice. The battles are well done. Having the ability to decide whether battles are AI controlled or manual is nice. The options for kinds of leaders are well done.That having been said there are several aspects of the game that are deal breakers for me. First, having to connect to the AOW servers even to play a LAN game is annoying. Not having an IP connection option unless through a VPN is more than annoying. The lack of this feature that we use in many other games makes the game feel unfinished at best.It's obvious that the AOW servers do not really have the bandwidth to accomodate the numbers of players that they have. Of the three players I normally play with I have the middle connection to the internet. I have been completely unable to get a speed adequate to host a game. Weirdly, the player in our group with the fastest connection also can not get a connection fast enough to host. However, our player with the slowest connection has been able to, though it fades in and out. Since we play other games that have similar connection requirements and we are all able to host, it is clearly a problem with the bandwidth at AOW. Not being able to host makes the game unplayable.We started playing as allies vrs AI players. The game taking us into the battles of the other players from whatever we're doing and focing us to watch the battle rather than allowing us to continue our turns in a simultaneous turn based interface is a very poor programming choice. That alone makes the game frustrating enough and actually makes it unplayable for the duration of the battle.At this point, several of us are playing through our first game. I can't wait to finish the game and go back to playing another simultaneous turn based game. I'd really like to like this game, but without a direct IP connect, inadequate bandwidth at the AOW server, and forced watching of battles during turns of allies, I won't be back to play again and can't recommend this game to others.

content:
Posted: October 21, 2016
												Just bought this game earlier this week and have been playing it non-stop with a friend of mine. It shares many economic and empire-building mechanics with Civilization 5, but gameplay is much more focused around combat and conquest, and games tend to be shorter (at least thus far). Combat, unlike in Civ, is done on a small-scale tactical level, where the camera essentially zooms in to the individual hex where the units are battling, and both players use their armies and units on a small scale. To me, this is the most significant thing that makes this game enjoyable (along with the leader customization, which had me in tears laughing on day 1). While $30 is a high price, this game certainly feels worth it this far in.TL;DR: Like Civ, except fun.

												Every time I play this I have fun.Also I just made a 5 level map with protected areas and one way portals.  Here are my maps.AI Improvements:And now the AI seems to be smart enough to handle that map without drooling like an embecile!  I think this is great - because now I can continue work on that map and make it what I had envisioned in the first place, or close to it at least.The big drawback to most randomly generated maps is that once an area is "cleaned up" it remains mostly dormant.  So that is somewhat mitigated with the map I'm working on.Because the AI has improved, I can seriously consider getting the other DLC I was holding back on.Atmosphere:Atmospherically, this game is possibly THE BEST LOOKING FANTASY 4X OF ALL TIME.  Go ahead, just try going into the editor to create your own map.  It's like spending time painting a picture - very relaxing way to spend time and it's productive and fun to make an atmosphere people might enjoy.Other than the board, the UI is very nice.  I guess I don't really notice when a UI is nice - I only notice when it's deplorable - and this one is artful and it's clear a lot of love went into it.  Hero Generation:The character generator has personality.  Really - this is the first game with a character generator (I guess I mean avatar) where I spent time with the appearance giving each one personality.  Because the range of appearances and role play are vastly beyond anything I've seen before - making a creepy witch was my favorite.Tactics:This is a great tactical mind workout playing the tactical map for each battle.  Because the maps are relatively large, interesting strategies can take place.  I don't anticipate Endless Legend will ever come close to the tactical experience AoW provides.City Building:There are maybe 6 or so different building "paths" to choose for a city.  So to get access to specific units you might have to build several buildings on a specific path.  These paths aren't very obvious and there's a learning / memorization (or documentation lookup) curve involved with cities.  I like it, but it might not suit everyone.Units:Units are not customizable, although heros are.  This is where Endless Legend seems to provide a vaster gameplay experience in comparison.  All units do level though, which is at least somewhat engaging to track which units are closest to leveling to prioritize who gets the kills and reap XP.Community:The modding community is very active and supportive.  I got a lot of encouragement and comments and that makes a huge game engagement difference, if you enjoy trying other people's mods or making them yourself.Missing Things Nobody Misses:There's something you can log into.  I have no idea.  I just play as guest all the time.  So it's a non-intrusive experience unlike other games.  Guess what?  That lack of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t commands a higher price tag and is well worth it.  [I'm looking at you HOMM.]

content:
Posted: June 27, 2014
												I have no idea where the praise for this game comes from, probably because I'm not ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. It is without a doubt the worst game purchase I have made in the last few years. Unbalanced and idiotic mechanics only serve to highlight the astounding incompetence of the development team when it comes to everything about this pile of trash aside from the visuals. I feel ripped off after spending a few hours with the game now and only out of competitive compulsion will I put any more time into it… That and it's not like I can get a ****ing refund so I might as well punish myself for buying it until I feel like I’ve gotten my money’s worth in suffering. Pros: Pretty for what it is.Cons: It exists. Aside from that...Build walls around your fortress expecting those to aid in defense? Jokes on you dummy, every pissant unit in the game has ladders that they will scale your stupid walls with in a single move before killing all your units with rocks. Spend a lot of time juicing up your armies so you're churning out tons of high end units? Jokes on you ***hole! In the first round the enemy will MC all your awesome units and use them to destroy you! (Cue evil laughter) Build a few cities to generate better income? Better not upgrade those new shanty towns because every turn you're not producing droves of crap units, the computer is and it will use them to penetrate your happiness and ruin your day much like a drunken priest who stumbles upon an aloof alterboy eating icecream and watching hanna barbara cartoons. It will make you feel♥♥♥♥♥♥♥and molested, that is what I'm saying.I work hard for my money and I like gaming, I love strategy games, and from the screen shots to the apparently paid for positive commentary on here I thought "hey this looks like a great game!" It's not, it's not worth your money and it's not worth your time. Want an RTS? Grab supcom: fa for 8$s or whatever it's going for right now, pick an eight person map, fill the other slots with hard AI's and enjoy the next 3 hours of screaming and ranting your way to a satisfying nuclear victory while under constant assault and relish the dependable joy of seeing your naval factory get blown up by bomb ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ the minute it gets to tech 3. That is a strategy game. This is a useless wannabe civ clone that plays like it was made by a bunch of LOTR fanbois who might have watched someone else play a game of total war and thought "hey I can make that". You want to know how stupid this game is? Fallen Enchantress is about 300xs better, at least in that I can get a pet bear to suffer the incompetent fight mechanics with me until I tame a dragon and laugh my way to victory (TROGDOR!!!!!). There is no absurdity to lighten up just how much this games sucks. It's not that I "don't recommend" this game, it's that I vehemently discourage ANYONE from purchasing this PoS and hope the jack*** developers go broke, get run out of the gaming community and are forced to take lame jobs working in fast food while they watch the bank repossess all their stuff because they suck at life. That is how♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥off I am at how crappy this game is, because that's how much I hate feeling like I got robbed when I buy something.

content:
Posted: April 18, 2014
												A turn based strategy game in a similar vein to Fallen Enchantress. Game takes place on two levels, the overall strategic map, and a tactical battle map to resolve conflicts. Units come in quite a range of flavours from simple swordsmen up to and including what are basically tanks but the end game consists mainly of building large armies of whatever your single best unit is and throwing them at the enemy. You have a range of different different races with different base abilities but this only really impacts the early game as the special units (based on what class your leader is and researched into the middle of the game) tend to be massively better and are for the most part the same regardless of the race that built them.The AI isn't too much of a challenge on the strategic map, it does however do a decent job in the tactical battles.So all in all: not brilliant but certainly not bad. I got my money's worth out of it but I don't think I'll be replaying it anytime soon.

content:
Posted: June 14, 2015
												I played this game right after playing Galatic Civilation III. It is very similar yet vastly different.Its much simpler, in the fact you don't have to micro manage little things (Unless you really want to) and the fact that the controls are streamlined.I love the different heros and classes and the fact that you can make your own is so much fun. The fact I can make these vast armies lead by such interesting and diverse heros riding on horses drakes and boars. One of my favorite things to do after getting a bunch of heros is going to assault fortresses, because you need to send different units to different walls and makes flanking a vital (and FUN) tactic!However, I will admit its so simple it feels sort of cheap at times. I haven't played long so this may be my own ignorance to certain features, but at times I feel I have a lack of control over development of my cities. For example, I'm not entirely sure how to increase my currency gains, or increase production and research rates.Lastly, THIS GAME IS GORGEOUS! It is so good looking for a turned based empire builder that its actually distracting! I love it! Each city looks fantastic, mines have productive animations, the abandoned fortresses, crypts and dungeons look appropriately mystic and intimadating; its like playing on a masterpiece!

The combination of race and class can lead to a very stereotypical warrior-like orc-empire or to a holy goblin-nation of saints. Its up to you. The focus is a bit more in fighting compared to CIV, nevertheless there are four different ways to win. Also there is great campagne and online-community too. Buy this game.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 24, 2015
												I have put 62 hours of gameplay in, so far, and have greatly enjoyed this game. The setting of high fantasy is well portrayed, the gameplay (as of right now) is well balanced and enjoyable. I can play and enjoy all of the classes and options  (although I've already develeped preferences). The gameplay, I find, to be much more engaging than a game like Civilization V. You have many more options, and combat is far quicker and graphically more interesting to view. The gameplay for large maps, and multiplayer games, can be fairly slow. It will take a long time to complete large mulitplayer games, and hours at least to complete the small ones. However, the game is well set up so that in every phase of the game there is plenty for you to do and to plan out. The stories are also quite enjoyable. The default campaigns are decently long with an interesting story and plenty of background on the world that it is taking place in. One drawback however is the main leader of your faction shifts in almost every level, which I find a bit annoying, but at the same time you get to play with much more diversity than you do in say Warcraft 3. My only other dislike about the campaigns is that the DLC campaigns are far shorter than I would prefer, and none of the campaigns are as long and complex as what you will find in Warcraft 3. That aside the gameplay is fantastic, the options are great, and I would fully recommend this game to anyone who enjoys turn based strategy and/or high-fantasy game settings.

content:
Posted: April 20, 2015
												Age of Wonders III is a great game, the gameplay is exciting and the units are cool and interesting. The mechanics makes my body shake in happines, especially when I see that I can make an army of skeleton units. Cool right?, Well this is not the enitre deal with this game. This game suffers from performance issues, mostly noticeable in multiplayer games. What I'm talking about is that the game like lags but doesn't. The game flows on in it's 60 fps or whatever it's locked in, but as fast as I issue an command to my unit, like equip this weapon the game will atleast take 6 - 10 seconds before it's actually equipped. I have only noticed this while playing online with a friend of mine. How's the campaign than, atleast that's good right?Well.. no, it's not that interesting. I prefer the scenario mode or just random map mode.But in the end I still recommed this game for hardcore strategy players

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 20, 2015
												Of all the genres that can devour hours like seconds, there are two - 4X Strategy and Roleplay.  Age of Wonders takes both of them and offers up the addictive hybrid genre that is 4X Roleplaying Stategy and presents it in a classical fantasy setting.  If you enjoy both Sid Meier's Civilization and Fire Emblem, Age of Wonders is an awesome franchise to get stuck into.Word of warning though - The recommended AoW3 campaign for "New Players" isn't overly beginner-friendly.  Watching Youtube tutorials, experimenting with random games and using The Tome of Wonders should better help new players gain a feel for the game.

Posted: April 20, 2015
												I'm a fan of Heroes of the Might and Magic. I did like the Civilization series, I was very dissapointed with the insanely huge waiting times in Civilization V  - I am no longer playing because of the waiting times. I like a lot the Dungeon and Dragons types of games. I read some reviews about the Age of Wonders before deciding to buy it.I have not played too much, but I already have an opinion about the game.Is it a game where I would like to own the best items on the map, to own the whole map? Not really, the game becomes boring, I do not find myself attracted by it as I was attracted by HOMM (I played 5 of them, I didn't like the fourth). Maybe increasing the AI difficulty will get some more competivity - I am not playing this game in multiplayer, it would take ages for a medium to large map.I did not encounter  bugs - for me the game works fine. City building? Nah, this game does not compare with Civilization, they are not in the same zone, Civilization is far more "advanced" and way more polished. Combat? Bring the bigger army and generally you will win - I did not see too many exceptions. Empire building? More cities, get more ressources - I think we could check this as an "yes", empire building is there. RPG? So-so. I do recommend the game though. Nothing is perfect, if you didn't play Heroes of the Might and Magic, this game might partially make you enjoy some time playing it. But don't get your hopes too high, it is not by far of the same feeling as Baldur's Gate, Civilization, Icewind Dale or Dragon Age: Origins. Theoretically it competes with Heroes of the Might and Magic, but I would recommend without any remorse HOMM III or V over Age of Wonders III.I will not rant too much. The conclusion is: there are much much better games out there. A lot of work has been put into this game as well, if you don't want to play the "best" rpg/empire building game, Age of Wonders will do just fine.A later note: after a while in the game, mainly 2 spells are used in the important battles. Only 2. And the one who defends has the first move in the battle, so guess who is using first one of the "big" spells. The third spell, the dispell, has a percentage of being successful, so... Yeah, 2 spells.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 24, 2015
												I have put 62 hours of gameplay in, so far, and have greatly enjoyed this game. The setting of high fantasy is well portrayed, the gameplay (as of right now) is well balanced and enjoyable. I can play and enjoy all of the classes and options  (although I've already develeped preferences). The gameplay, I find, to be much more engaging than a game like Civilization V. You have many more options, and combat is far quicker and graphically more interesting to view. The gameplay for large maps, and multiplayer games, can be fairly slow. It will take a long time to complete large mulitplayer games, and hours at least to complete the small ones. However, the game is well set up so that in every phase of the game there is plenty for you to do and to plan out. The stories are also quite enjoyable. The default campaigns are decently long with an interesting story and plenty of background on the world that it is taking place in. One drawback however is the main leader of your faction shifts in almost every level, which I find a bit annoying, but at the same time you get to play with much more diversity than you do in say Warcraft 3. My only other dislike about the campaigns is that the DLC campaigns are far shorter than I would prefer, and none of the campaigns are as long and complex as what you will find in Warcraft 3. That aside the gameplay is fantastic, the options are great, and I would fully recommend this game to anyone who enjoys turn based strategy and/or high-fantasy game settings.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 25, 2015
												There are some huge negatives for me:-Lower tier units rapidly become useless compared to higher tiered units. Although higher tiered units require some investment to acquire, they are not much more expensive than the lower tiered units. This makes it such that the best strategies are just spamming leviathans, flame tanks, or archon titans. I don't like that. I prefer the skirmishes the early game has to offer, with lots of archers, swordsmen, and caster armies. These feel tactical and well-suited, but once players can begin to amass the higher tiered units it just becomes a race to see who can build these the most. War is then less about exploration and tactics, and more just who managed to assert a few good cities and start pumping out the stronger units. It's a classic problem for most strategy games, but here it ruins the fun for me. This problem has been solved reasonably well in the past - it's not like riflemen in Warcraft 3 suddenly went out of style even towards the end of a game, yet archers rapidly become useless in this. It's annoying.Otherwise, it's a fun turn-based game in dire need of some hard balancing (honestly, leviathans are insane since you can sumnmon them anywhere with mana and have a fear effect PLUS they can mind control units, it's not even fair if a player gets six of these up and running, which isn't hard to do if you get enough shrines).

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 25, 2015
												People have been, understandably, comparing this game to Civ V and the more recent Endless Legend.Let me get one thing straight. All three games are the best in their genre. Period. If you wasnt historical/fantasy 4x empire building then look no further than AoW3, Civ V and Endless Legend.Now, let's get another thing straight. Civ V may have the large scope and fine-tuned balance, Endless Legend may have the complex city-building and diplomacy, but Age of Wonders III has so, so much more.For starters, city-building is not the focus, and you won't miss it. AoW3 gives you enough to satisfy, but then focuses your attention on much more epic things, like tactical combat on a zoomed-in battlefield, fully customizeable, RPG characters with gear, inventory, mounts and skill-trees (no joke!) and diplomacy options that cut to the chase and get the job done.The ONLY negative thing I can say about this game so far is that it feels mildly unbalanced at times. But not to worry! The game is regularly updated and it gets better every time.If you want a 4x empire builder/tactical combat/role playing game in a fantasy setting, well, this really is the only option, and boy, is it a good one!BONUS: Michiel van den Bos' original score for this game is ABSOLUTELY.FREAKIN.STUNNING. Seriously, you're going to find yourself humming his epic tunes to yourself when you're not paying attention.

content:
Posted: February 2, 2015
												I played the original, then the second, and now this. The game has made both incremental and drastic improvements over the years. If you're a fan of turn-based heroes of might and magic or civilization style games, this might be sort of up your alley. The "best" part is the fact that there's a fairly complex turn-based piece battle system waiting there for you as well. The story line is the best kind of fantasy camp.33% empire management, 66% tactical battles, 1% giggling as your giant/dragon/elemental bashes archers in their god damn mouths.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 22, 2015
												Kind of disappointed after really getting into Shadow Magic a few years ago. This one just isn't as good - the campaigns are nowhere near the great level of story we got in AOW:SM, and while the Wizard classes have been separated out a bit (so you're playing more a style rather than an element), there's a morality system (straight Good / Evil) which makes roleplaying properly pretty difficult. There are the usual mobs guarding each useful resource, but a good Elf killing these independent elves gives you evil points - the same goes for if you're playing Orcs killing independent goblins or trolls guarding a mine - you would get "Good" points for doing this..... Doesn't make a whole lot of sense to me, but the main sticking points for me are the campaign story and secondly the zoom-in battles. I realise a lot of people complained that ranged units were a bit OP before, but now you just can't get in a shot in city sieges before climbers and wall-passers are on you! Another smaller not-really-a-problem was that there was a lack of heroes turning up. The levelling system for them seems improved and my few ended up with far too much gear - have more turn up please!6/10 - If you like this kind of 4X exploration / city-building / TBC then I'd buy Shadow Magic instead. Much better.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 23, 2014
												A great iteration on a classic series - my favorite of the three by far. The game was pretty solid on release, wandered over into "excellent" territory after Golden Realms and the accompanying balance/content patches, and is looking to cross over into "unbelievable" with the Necromancer/Frostling expansion coming in early 2015 (new content, well-thought out balance and strategic adjustments, and a unique server-side Play-By-Email variant!)Icing on the cake - the dev team at Triumph is incredible; they've always been very sharp, responsive, and friendly.The one area I'd give this game a lower grade for would be its campaign. While they've tried to fill the campaign with a rich story and interesting events, sometimes the underlying 4X game doesn't mesh so well with the campaign goals, and those maps turn into tight rushes or long slogs. The game truly shines in its individual scenarios and especially in its well-done random map generator, both in SP and MP.

Civ V may have the large scope and fine-tuned balance, Endless Legend may have the complex city-building and diplomacy, but Age of Wonders III has so, so much more.For starters, city-building is not the focus, and you won't miss it. AoW3 gives you enough to satisfy, but then focuses your attention on much more epic things, like tactical combat on a zoomed-in battlefield, fully customizeable, RPG characters with gear, inventory, mounts and skill-trees (no joke!) and diplomacy options that cut to the chase and get the job done.The ONLY negative thing I can say about this game so far is that it feels mildly unbalanced at times. But not to worry! The game is regularly updated and it gets better every time.If you want a 4x empire builder/tactical combat/role playing game in a fantasy setting, well, this really is the only option, and boy, is it a good one!BONUS: Michiel van den Bos' original score for this game is ABSOLUTELY.FREAKIN.STUNNING. Seriously, you're going to find yourself humming his epic tunes to yourself when you're not paying attention.

												Following my "ex-favorite" game of all times, Age of Wonders III does not disappoint. It expands in every aspect possible. And even with lesser races availible at the beginning, it expended quickly with affordable dlc. Free Updates every few months are making the game even bigger. Age of Wonders III follows my favorite game Age of Wonders: Shadow Magic and takes his rightful place as my favorite game of all times after 10 years of love for Shadow Magic.Thank you Triumph for making this awesome game. You put fairness back into the gaming industry. Thank you! Demiurgus

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 19, 2014
												I just started. I have only completed one map, but I played for eleven hours straight because this game warrants it. Everything levels up, and as they do all sorts of upgrades occur. Many of them are automatic, but you get to customize your heros in useful ways. They give you 5 points to spend as you please. These can new passive or active bonuses including, but not exclusive to: attack up, defense up, life up, rapid regeneration, resistance up, new abilities like heal, rust, first strike, increased vision. The settlements have a simple spread, but it is deep enough for you to specialize with the bonus reasources inside of your domain. There are not many units that cannot be dealt with by tier 1 (the lowest) units if you get their experience all the way up. Archers are actually protected by the infantry you place in front of them because attacks of opportunity are present. The only real complaint I have is with the notifications system. It tells you most things twice, and in such a way that you may not know how to respond. For instance, if an enemy enters your territory you get a notification that will highlight the square the enemy entered. Unfortunately, this is not normally going to be the last square the enemy occupied, so you will need to search in up to a 12 square radius for said enemy. This is a fast paced game. If you don't overrun your enemy quickly, expect a long uphill battle.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 21, 2014
												This game has a great many aspects I personally enjoy, the most prominant being the ability to create the leader of your faction/ primary hero unit. With the ability to customize class, race, and skill specialization (as well as appearance, of course), AoW pulls off their mix of fantasy RPG and strategy game deftly. The 3 choices above have a real impact, given that they determine what elite units you can produce and what spells you can cast.The only weakness of the game is, sadly, its battle system. For fans of the Total War series, who will find most of this game rather easy to adapt to, the lack of ability to plan and strategize battles as well as you do diplomacy or city development can be very frustrating. One example of this is pre-battle deployment, which arranges all units in a long line, seemingly at random. One often feels slightly helpless in these battles, as the whim of the computer will sometimes place powerful ranged units with no armor in the center, in striking distance of the enemy infantry, while your infantry are placed on the end of the line, and are therefore useless for the first few turns. In essence, deployment becomes the deciding factor in many battles, and you don't control it.This is a rather gaping hole of bad design in an otherwise well put together game. Buy it if it's on sale, as the rest of the game is quite fun, but honestly if you've got enough money to pay full price just buy Endless Legend (which is better, apparently; I've never played it)TL,DR : Fun blend of strategy and fantasy RPG with a few oversights, esspecially in the battle system. Buy it if it's on sale.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 23, 2014
												Awesome follow up to Age of Wonders: Shadow Magic that isn't content to just rehash the same old mechanics. It manages to recreate the atmosphere of the older Age of Wonders games while changing up the game is some pretty dramatic and intelligent ways. Age of Wonders III separates race and culture for units; a goblin, for example, can now be any type of class from Theocrat to Rouge. This not only adds a tremendous variety and replayability to the game, but is also a statement that race shouldn't define one's culture. Things to complain about? I get nostalgic for the awesome 2D art of the older games. All the graphics are now rendered in 3D which have less charm and sometimes makes it difficult to distinguish low and mid tier units from one another. On the battlefield, mid and low tier units are no longer individuals, but small stacks that function like individuals. As such, they are smaller and sometimes indistinguishable from one another. It's something you get used to, and since the units are as full of personality as the older games, it's ultimately a minor complaint. There are also less races to choose from than the older games, but since you now must choose both race and class, variety doesn't suffer as much as you would think. Still, the more races and classes as Triumph Studios makes available, the better. I'm personally hoping for Dark Elves and Lizardmen. This is one of the best fantasy 4X games out there; a nice balance of new and old, great music and atmosphere, and a bright future ahead of it in the way of expansions and patches.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 28, 2014
												AOW3 is a solid title. It can be compared roughly to Fallen Enchantress or Heroes of Might & Magic/ Kings Bounty, with a few major, major differences. There's significantly less emphasis placed on the range of options in strategic meta-game (the focus is on war, full stop) , and hero development is more of a shallow affair.However, it more than makes up for these deficiencies/differences with its combat system.Games are fast, and combat has a great deal of depth (flanking, better use of 3-D space) that you won't see in other fantasy 4x titles. The pacing is such that AOW doesn't want you waiting 20 turns between battles, but keeps them coming, turn after turn. I would recommend it to anyone who enjoys online or random map play and likes the genre, although I am really enjoying the single player campaign after I've discovered the secret to making it easier (and having more fun) is to play a breakneck pace constantly on the rush. The intial learning curve is a little steep, but once you get the hang of it, you'll enjoy playing the battles (for the most part, as large engagements are neat to see, but kind of a mess to coordinate).

content:
Posted: October 29, 2014
												TLDR Version:      Come for the solid magically enhanced and customizable strategery, stay for the lawlz. Worth.Long Version:     Want a game that's similar to the Civilization games but with a magic system and customizable troops that you can make awesome squads out of like a goblin with a stick riding a bug, a majestic pegasus, a dragon that spits fire, a sprite(the magical creature, not the soda but that would be awesome and they should add that in future DLC!) and a huge gassy obese fishman thing? It has that!     Want a game where you can make a goofy (or not goofy, if you're so inclined) looking being out of a bunch of fantastical races and classes that can actually change the way you play the game so you can dominate the map as a grotesque goblin magitechnowizard that summons spy drones so he doesn't ever have to leave the safety of the initial spawn point in order to troll his neighbors?It has that TOO!      Want a game where you can make a magical boar fight a regular ol' boring natural boar to the death all while fighting an undead menace and at the same time shoot them with a catapult while sieging a castle and setting the battlefield on fire with your mind so you can find out what treasure they have been hiding from you, all while cackling menacingly as you ask someone (politely, mind you) in the room to bring you a pee bottle/poo bucket so you don't actually have to leave the game for one minute?All this can happen to you, AND MORE, if you buy this game.

content:
Posted: November 3, 2014
												While the game retains the same charm and interest of its predecessors in the series, the developers for the game have not resolved some of the gameplay faults of the older game, allowing the player to "trial and error" their way through learning the functionality of the game rather than providing a solid tutorial or "advisor" option, common in more modern games, in order to reduce the tedium of learning how to interact with the complex systems within the game.While I am recommending this game, if the next generation of AoW doesn't include more modern QoL features, I will not be recommending any future installments, and won't purchase any past the fourth (provided in the 4th they don't improve the QoL).

Also the only way to win the game i through dominathion peace treatys mean nothing in this eventually out of no where the AI will declare war on you and you cant do much to hold your lines as their massive armies quickly overrun you espically when you have a war on 4 fronts your not going to last long. The AI will never allie with you so that ones out or so i found anyway. All in all i would say for the sheir replay value its worth having a run on just to see all the races and classes in action.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 22, 2014
												When I first tried Ago of Wonders 3, I was struck by how similar the interface felt to Civ 5, so I found myself comparing it to Civ 5, but really, Heroes of Might and Magic or Disciples are a much better point of comparison.  If I compare it to Civ 5, I keep gettign disapointed about how simple the city building is, but it is not really more simplified than HoMM or Disciples.  The magic system is on par with DIsciples (which is to say not quite as good as HoMM, but still very respectable), and the tactical combat is very good (better than HoMM or Disciples in my opinion).  The storyline for the campaigns is also well done, but the actual campaigns felt on the short side - The campaign maps were large to huge and offset the lack of scenarios as far as gameplay time. The number of scenarios in each campaign were around 5-6 for each of the two campaigns (with a branch in each to add aother couple scenarios for each).  I prefer more scenarios with smaller maps, but others might prefer the AoW approach.Overall, I find AoW to be a good enjoyable game, but I can't quite put it up there with the same ranks as HoMM 3, or Disciples 2, or the classic Master of Magic.  Quality wise, I would put it int he ranks of HoMM 5, which I still consider to be a very good game.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 27, 2014
												This game is as complex and deep as it is fun, and let me be clear here, It's REALLY REALLY FUN. If you've played civilization and enjoyed watching a unit raise in rank as you grew your empire. It's a strategy that rewards saving every individual unit with advancement and power, and on top of that there are heroes you can equip and evolve into army clearing baddasses. All the while on the home front your cites are developing spells and pumping out warriors and building roads, The trouble is that you have to learn to do all of this in one turn, which takes some time, but when you do you'll be a Sauron skewering monster in no time, or you could just as easily be the monster yourself.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 24, 2014
												Age of Wonders III is a 4x stratergy game that is a product of passion. One can really tell that the developer has put a lot of effort into putting attention to the details of the game ; The graphics, the effects, some of the perks and much more.Overall, a very large bag of good ideas, one could say! But there is, however, a rather large glaring issue with Ager of Wonders III.It's that, for being a 4x game, it's incredibly shallow. And i don't mean to say that to insult the game in any way - But the game is really, really combat-centric and the structures of what is effective (rushing higher Tier units and favoring to find certain Dwellings that provide this possibility (Dragons, for instance)) - Makes this game rather lackluster.The diplomacy system is not that impressive at all, it's very basic - it merely moves in steps of shades, with no real sense of consequence to them other then obvious ones - dwellings attacking you if you tresspass etc.The tech tree is pretty standard, nothing too exciting, nor is it too impressive - A lot of other games do a lot more complexity on this front and offers a lot more powerful ideas on the whole. While not bad, AoW III's tech trees leave much to be desired - as it really only feels like you prioritize some certain spells and then go for higher tier units in your tech. Which is very, very straightforward and shallow, as far as a 4x game goes.There is a very underwhelming item crafting system in the game - While the idea is good at heart, and amazing if expanded upon - it's incredibly limited. It becomes a rather standard routine of churning out certain items to provide certain slot bonuses (as only some slots give certain bonuses, as far as crafting goes), which makes it feel dull and repetetive.What about the gameplay then? Well, the majority of the game, is combat. It's like Heroes 3 of Might and Magic, except with a lot more combat rules and more intrecacies to combat. And the combat is fine, with some rules such as attacks of oppurtounity, flanking and what not.But even this, gets to be rather routine and flawed - leaving not much strategum to be thought out. As really, it will take a very overwhelming force to force you to actually try and fight tactically to the point of thinking about positioning and sustaining your units. Which, frankly, dulls off after a while - because you do combat almost all the time.Hero customization regarding skills is rather generic and the skill up system is very basic. It is not incredible, but it's not bad either. It follows a point system, where of you put points into stats that will enhance your hero - and sometimes, traits. Which leaves it to be very generic and lackluster - In the long run.All in all, if i had to sum up Age of Wonders III, i would say that i can recommend it at a discount - Or if you feel you can afford it, just to have an experience. The game is definitly not bad per say, and is quite a blast in the beginning!But overall, the game really, really lacks longevity and the flawed ideas of it's design become very apparent after a while, making the game feel very shallow and lackluster, compared to other 4x games.

content:
Posted: December 26, 2014
												I was looking for something reminiscent of Heroes of Might and Magic, King's bounty, and Civ. I found it here. I find it very fun both for the campaign and for local coop play. There is a loyal and dedicated following of players, and they discuss tactics and balancing issues on forums everywhere. There is also a very helpful wiki online. The pace is slow and not for casual gamers.Great game. I recommend it.Update: this remains one of the few games that I keep coming back to. This game is full of variety and depth. The artwork is beautiful. The strategy and tactics vary tremendously and you can find a hundred different ways to combine races, classes, and schools of magic. These combinations also play a role in what kind of special skills or abilities your units have. There are different kinds of games to play, with many customizable options.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 30, 2014
												If you are a fan of 4x games, Civilization, or turned based games in general - this game should be at the top of your list. What really has me coming back is the art direction and randomized maps.-Highly engaging and complex tactical combat (Flanking, Magic, Damage types, Diversity in playstyles)-Interesting strategic variety on the world map-Best art direction in the strategy genre - this cannot be overemphasized!-Highly randomized maps and world editor for infinite replayability*UPDATE* - 04/2015 - BETA PATCH 1.5The developers have consistently made large updates to the game and it has turned into a classic that will be played for years to come. Issues Addressed-1. Tier 4 units toned down - better insentives through veterancy to keep lower tier units alive.2. Large balance tweaks - has resulted in better balance in multiplayer games.3. Diplomacy expanded  - more diplomacy options and nuanced vassal system.4. Interface improved - Cloth map (strategic map) has icons that mark out dwellings and treasure.ETERNAL LORDSAn absolutely huge expansion with all the meat you would expect from a full-blown old school style expansion; a new race, new specializations, new buildings and new units to do battle against.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 19, 2015
												Like Civilization, but fantasy. You get to choose from a range of races and hero classes. Classes include the Dreadnought, a poweful inventor that rules through machines. The Rogue, that hides in the shadows, attacking their enemies when they least suspect it. Warriors, mighty heroes that seek out power through raw strength. Sorcerer, a conjurer of magic, capable of summoning gigantic minions that would make even the bravest of men flee. Theocrats, which believe in the holy gods, often aligning with the good side rather than the bad. And the ArchDruid, a class that prefers nature over machines. They can call fourth the powers of nature to turn the tides in battle. The races include Humans, Draconians, Drawves, High Elves, Orcs and Goblins. Then there are hero traits. Three can be chosen, which will lead to new spells and units being available. I would highly recommend this game while it's on special.

content:
Posted: June 14, 2015
												I played this game right after playing Galatic Civilation III. It is very similar yet vastly different.Its much simpler, in the fact you don't have to micro manage little things (Unless you really want to) and the fact that the controls are streamlined.I love the different heros and classes and the fact that you can make your own is so much fun. The fact I can make these vast armies lead by such interesting and diverse heros riding on horses drakes and boars. One of my favorite things to do after getting a bunch of heros is going to assault fortresses, because you need to send different units to different walls and makes flanking a vital (and FUN) tactic!However, I will admit its so simple it feels sort of cheap at times. I haven't played long so this may be my own ignorance to certain features, but at times I feel I have a lack of control over development of my cities. For example, I'm not entirely sure how to increase my currency gains, or increase production and research rates.Lastly, THIS GAME IS GORGEOUS! It is so good looking for a turned based empire builder that its actually distracting! I love it! Each city looks fantastic, mines have productive animations, the abandoned fortresses, crypts and dungeons look appropriately mystic and intimadating; its like playing on a masterpiece!

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 25, 2015
												Favorite fantasy turn-based strategy rpg since Lords of Magic.  Waited 16 years for this - a true successor complete with modern 3D graphics.  You want to start from nothing and grow to a magnificent empire spreading your influence across the map - check.Level up heroes of different types each of unique races with several classes with many abilities - check.Research improvements to your units, new spells, and build fortresses, watchtowers, and even build new cities - check.Change the environment to suit your needs or make the land inhospitable to others - check.Participate in the defense of your cities defending against the monsterous hordes or lead an epic siege against the enemy - check.Can equip your heroes and leader with artifacts (items) to make them more powerful by increasing stats, granting new abilities, and even entirely new mounts for them to ride on - checkYes Age of Wonders 3 is everything I wanted in a game and it actually turned out to be better than I expected!  I eagerly await the next expansion or new game in the series ;)

content:
Posted: June 29, 2014
												Complex and Beautiful, two words that quickly and simply describe this game. and with an expansion drawing ever closer it truthfully is a great time to buy this gem of a game, it is a great 4X game (4X for those unfamiliar with the genre means eXplore, eXpand, eXploit, and eXterminate) on par with the amazing Civ series of games. it may not be as complex or in-depth as previous installments to the series but is a great starting point for people who are new to AoW or new to a 4X game in general. The early game is a bit unforgiving as you learn the ropes, but as you play you learn, and as you learn you conquer, and as you conquer, you become more and more familiar with the beauty that is this game. everything from minor choices made, to alliances forged and pacts broken, chances are you will find yourself enthralled in ensuring your kingdom thrives and outwits all who would stand before it. i give this game a hands down 10/10 however it's up to you to decide for yourself wether you agree with my score :)

Posted: November 29, 2016
												One of the best turn-based strategy games with a wonderful fantasy setting. If you liked Heroes of Might and Magic or CIV then I have to recommend this game. The most important feature of AoW3 might be the creation process of your leader. Like in roleplay games you can choose out of 9 different races, 7 different classes, a view traits and many styles. The combination of race and class can lead to a very stereotypical warrior-like orc-empire or to a holy goblin-nation of saints. Its up to you. The focus is a bit more in fighting compared to CIV, nevertheless there are four different ways to win. Also there is great campagne and online-community too. Buy this game.

content:
Posted: January 1, 2015
												A great combat focused tactical 4X fantasy game. It needs the balance tweaked a bit for some units, but is immersive, gigantic in it's scale. You can play as Humans, High Elves, Dwarves, Orcs, Goblins, Draconians in the base game and Halflings with the expansion, Golden Realms. You can also create and customize a hero and the starting class can change how the different races play entirely. The classes include Arch Druid, Dreadnought, Rogue, Sorceror, Theocrat and Warlord and each feel very different. 4/5 stars for me.

												A great successor to the original AoW games...and after so many years! This is a fantastic game in every way

												Do NOT purchase this game if you're planning to play mainly singleplayer! The AI is infuriatingly cheap and cheats like crazy. It gets resource bonuses and can see the entire map at all times. In the campaigns, enemies get such resource and army advantages it's ridiculous. A typical scenario is you starting with your hero and maybe an army, while the AI starts with 3 cities, 5 armies and only grows from there. Tedious and frustrating. Avoid!
