number of helpful: 4 of 10 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 4, 2015
												It's a nice take on the AoW formula, and if you're craving for something new in this regard, it's probably worth a try.However, the game has a couple of serious problems, that in the end, made me go back to previous AoW titles and HoMM.  UI is all over the place  Most units are quite literally copy-pasted between each factions  AI is utterly predictable and leader classes are unbalanced.  UnoptimizedThe UI, you can get used to. But I still can't stop shaking my head, at how they managed to make it bare-bones and cluttered at the samt time. It's just not focused, and some elements are all over the place, instead of having a designated place for similar elements(like in Civ5, or Endless Legend for example.) Some things are even shown twice, as if they couldn't decide where to put them.The unit situation is something I couldn't get used to though. They are simply copy-pasted between factions, and this is where it gets ugly: they even look the same. Sure, Orcs are green, and Dwarfs are short and stocky, but they still share the same units, wearing the exact same equipment. They tried to make this more bearable with faction traits(Elves for example don't like to fight underground) or leader specific units. But it's a bare minimum, that doesn't help in that regard.The AI has only two modes: go full force, or sit there and watch you steamroll the map. It's really that simple. The difficulty doesn't change this, but rather gives them bonuses(gold & production, start with larger armies) and that's where the devs called it a day. And if you want an easy win, just play Warlord class. Because the classes are unbalanced and exploitable.Optimization... well this game has none. I'm running this on a i7 3,4GHz, R9270, 8GB, Win8.1/10 Pro x64, and I only make around 30-40fps.  I looked this up on the forums and Google, and apparently there's no real reason behind it. For some people it just runs great, for others it just doesn't, completely independent from the PC specs. Literally what the term "unoptimization" is for.And to top things off, you can even find a cynical thread on the Steamforums, in which the devs joined in on making fun of those concerned about bad performance. Really nice move...In the end, AoW3 just isn't a game that's worth playing over already existing 4X titles. Especially if you're a fan of the old AoW, HoMM, or moved on to EL. It just doesn't offer enough to stand out. Really, the biggest thing it has going for it, is it's existence, since many people considered the AoW franchise to be dead.

number of helpful: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 12, 2016
												This review of for Age of Wonders III on OS X.This game seems extremely interesting and full of promise.  I played the original Age of Wonders years ago and have long since lost touch with the franchise.  I find many things to like about the game design, in particular how most actions you will take will effect your good/evil rating such that over time you are seen by others as either a good guy or a bad guy.  The map is interesting to explore, with lots of strange and menacing discoveries to make.  The AI seems pretty good.Unfortunately on my recent iMac running OS X 10.10, the game runs terribly, worse than any game I have ever tried to play on this machine.  It goes without saying that I am forced under such circumstances to turn the graphics quality all the way down (which leaves the game looking like an early 90's game, and not in a charming retro way), but even with these measures taken, the game is either borderline unplayable or completely unplayable, depending on your patience.  (Mine wore out after about 15 hours of gameplay marred by stuttering frame rates, slow screen redraws, unresponsive buttons due to lag and so on.)  Generally if I reboot the computer between sessions I can play for perhaps 20 minutes before the frame rate bogs down to the point of being unplayable.  I find that zooming out on the map causes the performance to plummet in such a way that it never recovers even after zooming back in to the normal perspective. Every time I exit the game I receive an error message that "Age of Wonders III unexpectedly quit", which is a good sign that all is not right with this build.  With the issues I encountered I can't recommend this game to any Mac players whatsoever.

limited, the maps are smaller then age of wonders 1, if you surround a city in units they will all end up in the same hex when attacking, and the game places your units how it feels like, so makeing specialised partys in large battles and balanceing them means nothing, and troop placement doesnt mean much as the deffenders can offten run up and fire on you on there first turn preventing you from side the walls and on the outside of the walls.health bars in battles are tiny, so bad that you must click on units to see there hp.. the flanking system is broken as the unit attacked spends a movement to face the unit that flanks them. pretty stupid to see a unit turn its back on 4 units with backstab becasue an archer took a pot shot from a bad spot.units dont poke out on the map becasue the map is so 3d in the same way the units are, the units should poke out so they are not lost... or hidden. everything looks like its the same shade of color, and that doesnt help either.all attacks hit, only the damage is effected by cover and whatever, units in the way of other units dont have a chance of takeing the hit for the intended unit, so you can gaurd archers with whatever unit you want to give them the bonus with no risk of loseing them, just put a 1 hp dicklord infront and he will have to be attacked first... how does a unit reduce the chance of another unit geting hit by a ranged attack by standing in front of it without a chance to get hit???!research is random, you research something, then something random fills its slot. before what you reserched was importantcombat is very rock paper sissors, instead of units naturaly being better at takeing out other units they add in stats that only benifit units,   before attacking a unit with first strike with a flyer was a bad idea becasue it removed the good thing about flying, (picking off weak units) now attacking a first stiker with a flyer makes the first striker do more damage.weak units cant be protected by walls or moved back as all attacks are garenteed hits.... in fact with garenteed hits low hp units are pretty worthless they are just meat shields, they cant retaliate back cuze they are dead. instead of, oh, i could miss and then get hit in retaliation so this 1hp super monster is still kinda dangourus and i should pick it off with archers..

												This game is a really good turn based sRPG. It has 4X elements, but I'd honeslty call it more a sRPG than anything based on the mechanics of the game. Think XCOM combat()Pros+ Satisfying Manuel Combat+ Easy City Management System+ Encourages Different types of playstyles with due to having ALOT of different skills to choose from whenyou level up your hero.+ Transparency with Race/Class/Units make them all seem the same, butin reaity are very different.+ Playing Campaign content is satisfying.+ Great Co Op capabilities.Cons- Class Balance- Starting Spells are random and Spell  tree isn't visible(Your "Build" might be on hold until you get theright spells)- No real reason to use Sea Units(there is, but it isn't )- Combat between players pauses the overall game (the game resume's when the battle is over)

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 13, 2014
												This is a remake of one of my favourite old-timey games; Master of Magic.  Age of Wonders III, has faithfully preserved the features of the original, which I think is a good decision.  Sometimes people just hit the nail on the head, so why stray too far from a winning formula.That's not to say that Age of Wonders III hasn't made improvements along the way.  The tactical battles are especially good.I have experienced some of the bugginess that others have experienced as well (my computer would reboot suddenly).  Mine got solved (fingers crossed) without too much fuss, but from what I read it looks as though the studio is willing to work with people to help things get fixed.If you don't experience any bugs I give this game an unequivocal endorsement.  If you do experience bugs, I think it's worth it to fight through the pain and get it running smoothly.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 17, 2015
												Anyone else finding themselves not blown away by this?  The units lost that hand-drawn feel from AOW 1, and the variety we saw with all the races in AOE 2/Shadow Magic.Which race you pick matters less than the type of magician you chose to be, and melts away a lot of the variety.Battles are frustrating and repetitive.  You're constantly swimming upstream against an incredibly fast current in the later missions (the current being neverending streams of elite armies pouring out of the NPC enemies' territory).  After the 10th time fighting several full stacks of whatever those jesus boxes are called, you want to try something new, or at least auto-calc the battle, but you can't afford the casualties they'll inflict on you, so back again to the grind, where the finicky hit system will drive you nuts.I don't know.  Maybe I'm somehow not getting it, but it seems like the Endless series just does a better job at keeping things fun and interesting.  Or maybe I'm meant to buy the game a few more times to get enough variety from the DLC's.

												Don't believe the hype. AoW3 is great.You should get it if you like turn based fantasy strategy.This game is NOT Civilization.  It never was. And I knew it would be worth it.  For fans of the series - the same classic game is here, although certain aspects have changed.  Much like between 1 &2!  I have yet to play through but have enjoyed it.

Product received for free
												AoW II has long been my favorite turn-based strategy toping even the Civilization franchise, and this game is a worthy follow up, going even further. The biggest plus is a well made storyline and campaigns with multiple endings. content:
Posted: July 16, 2014
												Do NOT pay full price for this game. It is nowhere near worth the £30 asking price, but that said, it's still a good bit of mindless fun. A fairly obvious clone of parts of Civs 4 and 5, with heavy fantasy elements. The game looks gorgeous, and runs well, but is heavily lacking in depth and polish. There are some finicky ways in which you have to micro manage things. Builder units cannot have their orders queued up, so if you're building, for example, a long road, you have to give the builder the order to build a road every turn, rather than giving it to them once at the start of the road and the builder autobuilds to the end. The custom-map menu doesn't lock in your settings from use to use, and the amount of times I've forgotten to change one of about three things, and had to restart a game to change simultaneous turns (which I cannot stand, and as I've said, is the default setting which can't be changed) is ridiculous. These are just a couple of ways in which the game lacks polish. Depth, as I have mentioned, is also sorely lacking. All cities can only build the same buildings, aside from buildings coming from the racial and class bonuses of your leader. Any variation of cities only comes from the bonus improvements in the land around them. These are in the game from the beginning, and cannot be created, destroyed, or changed. You cannot build farms or any other kind of improvement as in Civ, but are limited to Watchtowers, Fortresses and roads. Roads don't give any sort of bonus, other than your units moving faster. There is no negative effect to having more cities as in Civ, where tech costs and such go up. In AoW3, having fewer cities isn't a playstyle. You want to expand as fast and as much as possible. So yeah. Lacks polish. Lacks depth. Is still a lot of mindless fun. It looks gorgeous and it works. I recommend this game, but get it on sale. It is nowhere near worth £30.

content:
Posted: December 2, 2016
												A Review For Older Gamers: This is a good game, After 26 hours, I haven't seen any bugs, play is smooth, and there is great depth, well sort of.After playing for 5 hours, it is easy to get bored. You load up a new battle instance (yes - instance), place your units and move this unit, cast a spell with that, shoot with this one, click next turn. After a few turns the battle is over. Now it is time to move your units around the big map, make a quick empire-building move (maybe tell your city what to build next) and BACK TO BATTLE. That's all this game is: over and over, the same freaking battlefield instance with a few slightly different skins. Oooh! This time the battlefield instance has palm trees blocking the way instead of pillars of rock! Oooh!After 12 hours, you see there is a bit more to this game. Leveling up hero units, planning where to build cities on the big map, some exploration. After 25 hours, it becomes apparent that the decent amount of depth to the game barely matters. It is all elves and halflings and necromancers and eagle mounts and spider mounts and cities with walls that you break with trebuchets. It has been done so many times before, that even though they do a good job, it is just boring. The tired old tropes of spell casters and healers and warlords, mana potions and fairies and wisps and goblins...there is no WONDERMENT in Age of Wonders! It should be called Fellowship of the Ring, episode 293. And that includes having bought both DLC.When I  play ARK: Suvival Evolved, my jaw was constantly hanging open. Everywhere you turn, dinosaurs, fishing, sea diving, changing weather, stuff I had NOT done ten million times before. This game is the opposite of that, at least if you have read all the Tolkien books, seen all the movies, played all the games. Tired subject matter makes for a boring game. And the soundtrack is anything but exciting. The music never once lifts you up or tries to put you in a good mood. This is THINKING music. Furrow-your-brow, get a headache from thinking too hard for hours on end kind of music. Bleh! BORING!It is a polished, fun game, and even I will probably enjoy 100 or 200 hours in it, but only as a break from other games with more staying power. This game tries to be Medieval Civilization. To its credit, it is as well-polished as CIV, but it is too one-dimensional. Very little time is spent building the empire. Partly because they didn't build the tools you need to manage your empire. No over-riding view of research window where you can hang out and plan ahead, strategize. The in-game help is a little weak. Most of your time is in cookie-cutter *instanced* combat, which is fine, but deciding yet again how to flank a dragon and draw him out of volvanic lands into the fertile grassland your elven cavalry and druid prefer is just so totally yesterday, that even though this is a good game, I just can't bring myself to recommend it. Except on deep discount with no expectation of staying power. If you're going to remake Dungeons & Dragons One. More. Time., you should build the hell out of the game. Make it so you can rename your heros or at least enter notes so you can tell at a glance "oh yeah, this is my dude with high fire resistance." If you're not going to customize each heros character data sheet, at least ORGANIZE it so the important stuff is easy to find! The unit's ability to WALK isn't that interesting to me. Could you maybe not put that at the top? Let me click that slider bar and drag down til I find... oh there it is... no, this hero  can't buff his squad with extra damage... where is the dude who can? If this were 5 years ago, I'd say buy it. Today, this is just boring. Like your third replay of the entire Breaking Bad series on Netflix. Don't do it!Married people cheat on their spouse because they get bored and want something new. In the real world, there are reasons that gets complicated. In the fantasy world however, the excitement of getting some strange should be easy. Why isn't it? This game is good.... good in the way that sex with your wife of 22 years is also good. Yawn!! That was great! ...again. Yawn!! I'm sorry honey. But I know you understand. We've been married so long, you understood ten years ago. Want to watch some t.v.?

number of helpful: 5 of 13 people (38%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 21, 2016
												Note: This is only a single-player review. I usually don't do multiplayer in games.TL;DR: Runs a bit slow on my rig, which is somewhere between potato and top of the line. Graphics people mostly did their job. Music is good. Campaign programmers and AI programmers did pretty bad. All of the scant voice acting is done with a British accent. The major challenge with the AI is its cheating, so I ended up spending my time figuring out how to exploit the AI and keep it from exploiting its advantages. 100 hours of frustration.Longer:Graphics: Not top of the line, but strategy games have never been about graphics. There are a few areas, like jungles and tombs, where battlefield objects make it difficult to see the map. Naval battles involving units aboard ships are also difficult because it's difficult to tell units apart.Sound: I play with volume low, but the music was neither annoying nor engrossing. Lets you focus on other stuff while adding atmosphere. Unit sounds are also good, like shamans casting magic streams making a 'whoosh!' sound.Campaign-related categories:Story: Cliché shadow organization, stop a war-type deal. Win every battle for no good reason against sometimes ridiculous odds.Level layout: I could complain about this for hours. The basic requirement for most missions is the same: capture the enemy capital while the leader's recovering from defeat. They like to hide the capital either underground or on the other side of impassible mountains and you find the teleport to get to them. Maps also tend to be very large, with a lot of hindering terrain (mountains, islands[it takes all move points to enter water]) that makes an already slow game even more so. The layout alone would make the experience tedious.Level layout(2): The AI starts with most of the map under its control, and has a very strong economy to build units and perform research. In most maps, all players start with no research done, and a small army. This alone wouldn't be a bad thing, and it's done in a lot of great games: Warcraft, Command and Conquer, Supreme Commander, BUT the enemies have the tech and economic advantage, so you've got to be getting favorable trades in battles, and losing a single major battle pretty much means 'load your save or restart'. On its own, this would put some pressure on the player.AI: This is the worst, most cheating AI I've seen in a strategy game. Though I haven't played Civilization V; I've heard it is ridiculous. This AI is all-seeing and acts on it. If you have half the map and decide to station units in cities on or near the border, the computer will immediately send a single unit between your defended cities to claim your defenseless ones, trying to stay out of view as long as possible. If you capture a city and don't leave defenders, the computer will immediately send units to take it back. To the best of my knowledge, it's never mentioned that the AI can see everything. It's a frustrating learning experience asking "How did the computer sneak that unit in to take my town?", then "How did it know my city was empty?", and "How did it know my city existed!?", possibly "How did the computer know a city could even be there!?". There's a stand-alone scenario 'Taming the Great Kahn' that frustrates many. I've turned off the fog-of war just to watch the computer players beeline to the important stuff in an absurd way. The computer never scouts, but even for defended cities, it will bring enough units thoroughly beat you if you set the fight to auto-battle. If you bring reinforcements that will arrive in time, the computer will bring its own reinforcements before attacking, despite the fact it shouldn't know your reinforcements are on the way. I'll skip the rest of the examples, but there's not even a player option to turn off the fog of war (though there is a cheat code), presumably to hide how horrendous the AI is.The computer seems to decide to attack based on some simple algorithm, like their unit_count*avg_hp*avg_defense*avg_attack vs. your stats in the same style. So their five swordsmen will take on your four archers, and four of them will get picked off before they get into melee range. The tactical AI priority seems to be (1)Heal; (2)Buff/Debuff; (3)Attack the highest priority unit in range (usually support or heroes, and the computer will take a lot of damage to do so sometimes); (4)get into attack range. Basically 'Buff 'n Rush'. You often won't notice in the campaign, though, because you'll often be positioning your units to somehow try to win every fight at 2-to-1 odds.I have a feeling that random events, called 'Cosmic Events', are generated to help the computer; any benefit to you is a side-effect. I used armies of fragile and weak ranged units to take on superior armies of tough, strong melee units. An event reduces all dealt damage by 3, reducing my units' damage by about 60%, and theirs by ~15%. The next event gave +5 to melee damage. The next event reduced vision range by 2 (refer to all-seeing AI for why this only hurts human players).Every campaign mission is like the most notorious mission in Heroes of Might and Magic V, the Agrael vs. Gilraen mission, pre-patch, for those who played that game. If your preferred tactic is rushing and aggression, the campaign is easy. If you prefer to build up and tech up, you'll lose until you learn to rush aggressively. Each mission seems best played twice on normal difficulty. The first time you sacrifice your cities and try to find the shortest path to your main objective before you lose. The second time you keep 2-3 units at each of your cities and move the bulk of your army in a desperate attempt at a decapitation strike. Rinse and repeat four times (the first mission is easier, though it tries to bore you by making you go in a 'U' shape around the map).Miscellaneous:Due to the haste of single-player, you don't really get to explore the tech tree. The enemy often does, because they're researching at 2x-3x your speed. This isn't about not getting the whole tech tree, the problem is that you usually don't even get to the end of a single branch, so why are those options there?To be fair, I do have horrible luck in life. I may have completed the worst campaign and wasted days on the worst scenario in the game. Unfortunately, from my experience, what could have been a wonderful strategy game with slick moves and fantastic creatures ends up feeling more like pushing a heavy barrel uphill on a road with a strong storm pushing you back and threatening to crush you. Sadly, a cheap Civ knockoff, even worse because I'd prefer magic and fantasy over historically inaccurate pikemen vs. tanks.

content:
Posted: June 6, 2016
												I realise this isn't going to be a popular review but the fact remains that I've never really understood the appeal of the AoW series. When it first came out it was graphically and playability-wise behind the times and very little has changed as far as I can tell. This is not to say that I think AoW3 is a bad game by any stretch, I just feel that the whole genre isn't producing anything new any more. If I had to pick a "best" out of a slew of civ clones I would likely choose Fallen Enchantress Legendary Heroes over this. You can go on about oldies like Master of Magic or newer attempts such as Endless Legend...none of which are BAD games...it's just...ugh..this again? When all is said and done none of them really have the depth of even the earliest Total War games and haven't progressed in any big way since the original Civilization. Learn the basics...build powerful armies, click auto resolve, repeat until so bored that you dribble like Homer Simpson thinking of gravy. For me, at least, this isn't gravy - more like early onset senility. Sorry fanboys it's just my opinion.

												I sadly can't recommend this game, I feel as if they really screwed us on content compared the the pervious Age of Wonders games, which each offered a massive variety of races and customization. The classes you can pick are extremely uninteresting and they removed many of my favourite races such as Dark Elves and Undead with no explanation, promising us DLC that will bring in more races and classes. I believe like the feeling of customization was very important in the previous Age of Wonders games, and this one tried to fix something that wasn't broken and ruined the game. That, or the devs simply got very lazy and assumed a shiny new graphic style would cover up all the cons.The game does look pretty, some of the additions are nice, however this simply isn't a good game, at least compared to the previous installments. I also hate the fact that they promise us features that should have been in since release as paid DLC. I would suggest Shadow Magic over this any day, simply because I feel it has more content and is a much more enjoyable game overall.

content:
Posted: April 16, 2015
												This is a beautiful character creator with an extremely deep concept... attached to a totally crap game engine. The character creator is so promising and varied it's hard not to keep going back and trying to find that "sweet spot" that makes the rest of the game playable, but it isn't there. This game sucks. Maybe future updates will get around to making it not suck so much but so far it's a steaming heap with one of the best character creators I've yet seen on a 4X game.It's a mediocre alternative to Fallen Enchantress, the difference being primarily that Fallen Enchantress is a playable (though not terribly fun) 4x game with low-end graphics and boring gameplay. What AoW3 brings to the table is prettier artwork... and almost nothing else, as yet.Considering it's been in a "finished product" state for over a year now and already has content updates, I've got little hope that it's actually going to be upgraded to a "decent" game at any point. It's a bad game... but again, the graphics are pretty and the character creator is top-notch.[EDIT]: I really want to love this game, I really do... I've given it a solid 80 hours of trying now, and I still can't do it. I've worked out how to stack starting conditions and faction options in a manner that allows me to eventually sometimes expand beyond my first city before getting overrun by wandering barbarian hordes... I've learned how to exploit the subterranean map for everything it's worth... I've figured out dwellings and their various diplomatic side-effects... I've even learned how to mix the various magical schools and which race/class combinations benefit more or less from several varieties of pre-game picks selections. I've also discovered now how to make use of the "growth momentum" meta-economic (which has no indicators, and is not apparent because there is no 'development tree' of any kind on cities, units, magic, or otherwise... it's just implied by one stage unlocking another one as you progress) and I've figured out how to use hero hiring to "blend strategies" for empire development......but even through all of that, the game is still... shallow like a puddle on the sidewalk. It's got no depth. City specialization boils down to placement near world-bound resources like "dungeons" and "tombs" and such. While you can do a tiny bit of terraforming, it's extremely restricted (you can change the surface mapping of a tile amongst a limited range of options based on your initial picks, you cannot raise and lower terrain and you cannot branch your empire out across multiple environs). The morale system is disappointing in a variety of ways, and makes the initial starting conditions extremely unbalancing if you do not rig the game heavily in your favor before you even begin.As a final note, the artwork is absolutely fantastic, I can't say that enough. This is probably the most beautiful 4X currently on the market... but that's all it's really got going for it. The UI is counter-intuitive, the gameplay dynamics are so biased that every game is a foregone conclusion before you even begin, and the development/progress system is literally a flatline rather than any kind of curve.The people working on this game seem to be missing a critical element from their team... it's like a bunch of art students tried to make a game none of them would ever actually play. It's got no passion, no depth, no sense of accomplishment, no actual challenge, no emotional value.It isn't a problem with the engine, it isn't a problem with the graphics. It's just a complete lack of engagement between design and implementation.

number of helpful: 1 of 5 people (20%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
												There are a lot of good games in this genre. Unfortunately, this isn't one of them. It is boring and simplistic compared to many others in the genre. It is trying to be a cross between a Civ game and something like the King's Bounty games or Heroes of Might and Magic and the crossover just ends up being the most mediocre of both worlds. For example, research consists of picking one of 12 seemingly random choices of spells or empire upgrades. There is no clear progression of research, it's just picking whichever random ability you want to research and most of them don't have a noticeably huge impact. Even worse than the annoying research system is the city development system. Your options for developing your cities are almost identical, no matter what race you are playing as. Every race gets 1 archer, 1 infantry unit, 1 irregular, 1 pikeman, 1 calvary unit, 1 siege tower, 1 support unit, and 1 special racial troop. The only differences between them for the different races are the traits they have and those don't have a huge difference. The class you choose for your hero has a bigger effect on what units you can build than your race but even that isn't much. No matter what class you pick, it adds 3 new building options to your city that must be built in order. Those buildings are what allow you to produce your class specific units. For the magical classes, that may be only 1 unit because you can use spells to summon more. For the non-magical classes, you get a few more troops but ultimately it is still an unsatisfying number of choices.The one thing I do like about this game is that if multiple armies are in hexes next to the army being attacked, you can have more troops in combat than a single army can have in it. However, combat still feels like a rather boring clone of King's Bounty or Heroes of Might and Magic's combat system. I'm not saying that those games are bad, just that this doesn't bring anything new to the combat table.All in all, I wouldn't recommend this game at all. You want to manage an empire, there are better games for that. You want to have turn based roleplaying game with tactical combat, there are better games for that. If you want to play both in the same game, then unfortunately this is the only game I know of for you but that doesn't means it's a good choice.

number of helpful: 1 of 5 people (20%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 27, 2015
												I would not recommend this game, for singleplayer. There are a few issue's i have that cause me not to enjoy this game.Warning: this is highly subjective, based on personal experience. Therefore i recommend keeping that in mind!- First the depth.When you start the game and see all the different races and the specialisations you may get the idea that there's alot to discover. However every race play's very alike, there are differences ofcourse but the general concept is the same throughout. (swordsman, archer, pikeman, horseman etc). The specialisations do bring some variation but the research-tree's attached to them are short. The extra units for each specialisation is a welcome addition, however it's not quite enough.- Combat/balance.The combat has some meat to it, it's the focus of the game. Some interesting mechanics suchs as attacks of oportunity and hero skills add to the strategic element. But because of the low variety of units it becomes more of the same much too soon.-Pacing.The big focus in this game is as i said the combat. Sadly around turn 50-60 all units but tier 4 units get less usefull. Wichs results in tier 4 unit spam, it takes away from the already limited choise and variation. And for me that is were most of my games ended, because i did not feel like spamming one unit.- Diplomacy.Diplomacy is barebone in this game, it's about declaring war or signing a peace treaty. You can interact some more with independant city's, like vasalisation. But when you tend to wage war everyone will like you less, making it harder to have good relations with anyone (as a war decleration effects every other player/independant) it's simply the most viable mechanic by far to just wage war as the only option. - Strategic placement.This is combat related, you get to choose 6 unit's for each stack. Then you can fight with multiple stacks in one fight to up to (i believe) 48 units. This sounds very nice but there's a big problem that i personally have with it.If you fight with 2 stacks versus one the AI tends to advance towards one of them. That leaves the other to catch up since the distance between allied stacks is relatively large. Because of that the reason to fight with multiple stacks becomes less important, your main stack is gonna do most of the work (hopefully, the AI might attack the other stack). Or the AI splits it's army destroying it's chances on it's own.In encounters (versus independants roaming or placed around the map) the battlefield is so small that ranged units can reach your army in the first turn. And they get to go first because you attacked. So they get a free attack in.... does not seem very strategic.- City defense.This seems to be done by placing units within the city, wich cost upkeep. The AI will ninja your city, it even intends to do so. The only way is to use units wich should have bin fighting in your army, there should be a building for it, but none to find.-Graphics.This is done fairly well, the game does look beautifull and the animation quality is high. It also runs very well and support for the game is good, the devs are very active and helpful!All in all i expected something along the lines of Warlock or HoMM. But this is a different creature entirely. That said the issue's i have may not be a problem for others, as many people do like this game. And for good reason, i did like aspects of it very much. Sadly the points mentioned made it not so enjoyable for me personally.I would not recommend unless none of the above is an issue, if you do get it i'd recommend to wait for a sale (it happends frequently)!

number of helpful: 1 of 5 people (20%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 31, 2015
												In order to do Age of Wonders III justice, I would have to write two reviews. The tactical layer works very well. The strategic layer doesn't. Regardless of whether I recommend this game or not, I'm letting my opinion on one subsystem trump the other.The tactical layer uses a fun and flexible system that involves frequent trade offs between moving fast and being able to deal damage. It encourages you to move your units carefully and orchestrate coordinated chains of actions. Unit types are well balanced against each other so that there really is a point to using a bit of everything. The spellcasting system is somewhat less robust and clearly favours damage dealing over buffs, but still provides added depth. All of this is made even better by varied tactical maps and enemy factions. This is game design at its best.It is, sadly, wasted to some degree, because the strategic layer is a classic case of form over essence. Strategic maps are large and full of landmarks, but there are no mechanics for making all this complexity "observable". You just keep stumbling upon things that hide in the fog of war - or they stumble upon you, usually at the least convenient time. There's no way for you to take all the necessary precautions, so you're often at the mercy of randomness. Most scenarios make assumptions with regard to optimal play style but never tell you about them. Sometimes you're supposed to rush. Sometimes you're supposed to turtle. Sometimes you need to clear NPC nests, and sometimes they are just red herrings. There's no feedback from the game's dynamics until it's too late. It's been over 70 hours and I'm still just picking city upgrades at random.So there's one system that works, and one that doesn't. The reason why I'm going for "not recommended" is the storyline and setting. It's childish, naive and not at all compelling; full of cliches, and saturated with casual imperialism. You could say storylines are not important in 4X games, but then why not just make a 4X game without a story, like good old Civilization or Master of Orion? If the story is important enough to justify preceding every mission with a five-minute, three-act briefing, then it should be judged just like a proper story that it's trying do be. Age of Wonders III fails miserably in this respect.Additionally, the game does a poor job at explaining its systems to the player. There's just a huge infodump of a manual that you're supposed to read, and the visual language takes some getting used to. It took me a good few hours to sort things out on my own.

content:
Posted: September 28, 2014
												I have played the prior games of Age of Wonders and like the basic game.  This last one however is just a bug, bug,  bug filled mess.  It may be that there are to many connections required.  There is steam and also a second one for the game developer.  There might be problems with being sold an unfinished game.  I am not a tech person, but have played computer games for many years.  This one either gets a bug report or gets frozen about every twenty minutes.  The bug means you have to drop out of the game, reload and go back to your last save.  This takes about two to three minutes.  When the game gets frozen you have to shut down your computer and restart everything, for a five to six minute delay.  The condition of the game takes all of the fun out of playing.  Untill the thing is fixed you would be better off playing something else.

												Good game overall but with some issues. The spell side has very little choice, no unit enchantments. In short a bit dumbed down from the previous version but still good enough. The major problem I have with it is how long it takes for the computer to take it's turns after you go into turns 90 or 50 (with the expansion) on extra large maps and 8 players. the game really drags down to make you wait over 5 minutes for your turn and the developers are simply unwilling to solve the problem... I'd give it a 7/10 for this reason as I only enjoy doing 8 players extra large maps and am forced to either not play or play into smaller maps that are unsatisfying for me... As you may have noticed, the expansion makes the slow pc turns get much worse and it doesn't adds that much to the game so be warned.

content:
Posted: April 27, 2014
												sadly AoW3 took a stab at 4x and failed, every race has the same buildings at the start with only the special units that require something else to be built. theres no diversity like elves build trees for woodland creatures and orcs build mines for thier shock troops.gameplay is just build an army that can attack move it from city to city watch your cash and mana and hope someones flying unit doesnt break in the back door and take everything you have worked for. the resourses dont really allow for defensive units to be left guarding the cities you conquor so its hit and miss if you progress far in a very long time.low tier units are cheap but can be 1 shot killed by higher teirs so are completely redundant. just build tier 4 or higher armies, watch your gold and you're good. downside is you may need to wait several turns to heal before continuing and loosing just 1 unit can have a massive effect on your progress.12 hours of game play to hit mission 2.....some spells are completely useless as the AI will dispell everything on the next turn so waiting for the cost of it is just impractical and the banish spell never works on large monsters.currently stuck on the mission to capture the bad guys, the main baddie keeps dying to mission fails every time....could have been a lot better...

number of helpful: 1 of 6 people (17%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 10, 2014
												I could write a very long review detailing all the problems, but I will keep it simple.First this is not an Age of Wonders game it just looks like one, on the cover and they used the name. Let me explain, 90% of what made all the other AoW games special is gone (multiple races each with its own troop types, three levels, and flaggable resourses just to name a few) whats left is so corrupted as to be nearly unAoW. Second Graphics they suck!! what you see above is not what you will get, on the world map it jerks around and after an hour of trying to look at it your eyes are so sore you want to dig them out of your head! Then there are the battles (two words) Multiple Sprites, who for the most part look similar to the enemy sprites, so hard to tell apart, much less tell what they are used for. Third THE EDITOR I make maps, I like making maps, with AoW 3 I can't make maps or at least not good ones (no F***ing instructions as far as I can see)There are some good things top one being the Jobs for the leaders its a nice touch but not enough to make up for the rest of this mess.My hope is that just like with AoW 2 they will realize mistakes and fix and reissue the game with no number just a cool name. Of couse that is a pipe dream because unlike AoW 2 that just needed to be polished better and have some content added. This crap fest would need an entire rewrite, remove mutiple sprites, remove systems stolen from other games that are five to fifteen years old ie. The area of control from Civilization three thru five worked for that game doesn't for this one - big time.Finally two things GIVE ME BACK MY HALFLINGS and GIVE ME BACK MY UNDEAD!!!!!!

number of helpful: 1 of 6 people (17%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 22, 2014
												Ok so the game is amazing! However the main attraction of the game is the multiplayer. But it requires setting up the UPnP! Which if you have comcast or a another major provider requires a long phone call resetting your router and if done wrong will corrupt everything. This is not a simple matter, and should have been in the main design phase. There is a lot of issues. I liked how the dev's tried to create a neat game. But they do not have the chain rule where for supporting armies next to each other only applies in hexes not linear lines nor other issues.Players expect way way too much of you if you simply want to play a nice multiplayer game. Most people lock their games so only their friends can play. Now if you don't have friends, are a steam, social rogue like me. (Which is probably the majority) You are left out. EVEN IF YOU CAN get into a game If you play any manuals at all they add you to their troll list. If you are winning decisively because you are better they quit. It's like why even have the multiplayer? Why?  I wanted to be able to play against other humans because they are smarter then the AI, but it's almost not worth it. After awhile the AI gets way too easy and your strategies after about 4-5 games are set in for warlords etc. The game unlike legendary heroes doesn't allow full customization of creating new units and this overall is for simplicity and streamlining of the multiplayer. Unfortunately this makes the game really horrible in that reguard. Now the game overall is amazing. The graphics good, etc. Read other reviews on the graphics. But the fact that this was to be a multiplayer game it fails.

number of helpful: 1 of 6 people (17%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 2, 2015
												Being a fan of the series i´m rather disapointed by that one - though - to be fair - it´s quite good..selling factions that were part of the game as a dlc forces my thumb down - that´s a bad habbit - that this got common is no excuse..there are some improvements - the best of them came with a patch - the possibility to have "allied neutral" cities that provide you with some troops or money - without micromanaging them and taking too much concern on their defence..the fights are in some points a step back - because besieged cities have only one side fighting front.. so there is much strategy taken away.. the armies are smaller and the rounds are quite slow - the loading time of a battle is wuite slow.. and i don´t like that nearly dead enemies fight with full strenghth aswell.. though that helps your own nearly dead units..though there are more leveling up stages for the troups than in earlyier games .. what i actually like.. weak troops on highest level still die on one attack of a stronger one .. so the good thinking of higher levels - doesn´t really work out in practice..the weaker units have 10 - middle units 3 - higher 1 - persons shown.. actually i like that change alot.. but though the grafics are improved of course.. the units dont look really good.. it´s like looking at them from very far and so i miss the feeling of playing orcs elves ore whatever..the campaigns are ok - but a chance given away - why not let the player decide to conquer a province on the campaign map - that could have gotten a campaign map - but is just an illustration..so overall - of course a must have of fans of the series - thats why i got it - but they could have done alot better - and actually don´t deserve our money when letting us extra pay for hobbits and frostlings and improvements of the game..besides the prices for the the dlcs.. other people wouldn´t stay polite on this.. greedy lazy work..if you like games like that check out falling enchantres legendary heroes - though there are lots of dlcs aswell.. they are  much cheaper and you don´t need them at all beacause the basic game is so rich of content itself.. (while hobbits in aow actually are essential..) falling enchantres is another dimension of gameplay the lazy aow creators could learn alot from..

												Neat but♥♥♥♥♥♥still isnt fixed which among a few things are. City spam is still the way to go, nothing changed there, i spammed a few cities and was stomping the ai. alignment is barely relevant. i wish they fixed it so that when i turn on simultaneous turns i am not waiting forever or clicking 3 times for it to go threw. its as if the system is made for turn after turn, yet they wrenched in the option and it is crap, in the beginning it works around turn 20 it begins slowing down and at turn 30 it becomes unplayable. some races are barely useable at all, and some are just so damn superior that its nearly impossible not to pick em, and since every class has atleast one unit that steals units. and some races are more suceptible to this then others, why even pick em. they did protect the more valuable loot around the map this time around so you can't just summon a scout every turn for the next 9 turns, ((and steal everything so your cities develop quicker then others.)) yet gold and mana and population is still rife for the taking so why not make em. Spells are still overpowered as can be.which is good yet, they tend to be abit tooooo overpowered you can win a battle by spells allone destroying a entire army whimsically because reasons. also the creation of items fun idea poorly implemented as i can make anything and everything. making trades off such items irrelevant as i can get em maybe the next turn. ((the exception being the mounts the sorceror can summon, but you can find em in dungeons aswell,  your gonna be doing those dungeons anyways.))the only thing i liked was the combat but after doing that for a while it gets boring too. since its allot off the same. no real tactics needed other then mmm i need to shove a meaty guy infront off em and get a sneaky guy behind em. all in all i wanted this to be fun, and still want it to be fun. i keep trying keep getting dissapointed.P.S. 40 bucks and 20 bucks per dlc, are you kidding me. thats 80 bucks...

content:
Posted: May 8, 2014
												If you are a casual gamer, stay away from this game! I have been playing games my whole life and feel I am decently skilled (I usually play games on moderate difficulty settings), but I consider myself a casual gamer because I play games to kick back, de-stress, and have some fun, not to become even more stressed and frustrated that I was before I sat down. The major flaw with this game is purely that the difficulty settings are horrible. When playing scenarios, the "Easy" setting is not easy. After restarting the second scenario on Easy 5 times, I have done my research and it appears to be that only one tactic works to win in certain scenarios, leaving no room for error if that is not how you are used to playing these types of games. I know this is a new game, so I am crossing my fingers that I did not waste my money and that a patch will be released that will make it a bit easier to play.

number of helpful: 0 of 4 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 25, 2015
												Look no further. This is the best turn-based fantasy game so far. I got addicted to Age of Wonders 2 way back, and needing a bit of a graphics overhaul shifted to that fantasy mod in Civ 4, then to Fallen Enchantress, then Warlock. But no other high fantasy game immersed me as much as AOW 3. Its not just the gameplay, its also the UI design. It may seem complicated at first then it becomes second nature - how all important infos are accessible right in front of you, and shifting from surface to underground and back is such a breeze. One of the things that made AOW 2 satisfying before is its combat - and so, soooo much deeper than any Heroes of Might and Magic game. Now, for AOW 3 - everything has been revamped, the graphics are gorgeous colorful yet without being too kiddie, and really requires some deep tactical thinking. You want some intense, strategy combat thats fast, and still deep - this is it. AOW 3 is here to stay :)

number of helpful: 0 of 4 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 3, 2016
												I so much want to recommend this game.  The first turn based strategy game I played was Warlords.  And later I became obsessed with Heros of Might and Magic.  Age of Wonders III is like Warlords and Heros mated and had a beautiful new baby.  I loved it at first.  The UI looks good and is pretty intuitive.  It takes a little effort to learn, as there are a ton of different units and abilities,  but that is part of what you are there for in a game like this, no? At first I was overjoyed.  The AI played pretty well and the game felt challenging but fair.  I could tell I was going to sink a lot of playtime into this game.  Then in the middle of a campaign mission (thats about 4 hours in) the AI starts spamming my cities with something called "Incite Riot".  So the way this works is that your cities have a HAPPINESS level that determines how hard they work and fight.  Normally my cities mid-game are in the 50-150 range of happiness.  Incite Riot drops the happiness -600 AND if you don't get rid of it in a few turns the city riots, spawning a bunch of enemy rebel units you need to deal with.The way these GLOBAL spells (that you cast on the strategic map, not the tactical) is that they cost an certain amount of mana and if you generate say 70 mana per turn and the spell costs 90 it will take 2 turns before you can cast it.  So you say "I want to cast this" in preparation and then a countdown will tick each turn until it is ready.    And these city/empire affecting spells last until the opponent casts a Disjunct to get rid of it.  So say the AI casts Incite this turn.  The spell integrity is at 100%.  I then cast Disjunct this turn.  The game says "you have a 50% chance of disjunction".  The formula seems to be (200 - INTEGRITY) / 2 is the chance to Disjunct.  And if you fail the roll the INTEGRITY is cut by half for your next try.  But meanwhile your opponent can REINFORCE an active spell all the way up to 200.  In that case, your chance to Disjunct would be 200-200 = 0, but it never goes below 5% so you always have some chance of Disjunction.And that is exactly what happens.  The AI spams both Incite Riot on a new city and reinforces the ones it has out to 200%  integrity EVERY turn.  And I can only fire off Disjunct (at a 5% chance) every other turn.  Because happiness is so low my empire production grinds to a halt and my units start getting beaten up in every fight.  Plus the rioting sometimes breaks out.  Basically the game becomes chasing to put out fires that keep getting re-lit until the opponent (who's economy is fine) crushes you.  There doesn't seem to be anything you can do to counter or get out from under this once it starts.  I replayed the level 3 times and the same thing happened each time.  So basically the game is too unbalanced for me to recommend.  Hope my explanation is clear and helpful.

number of helpful: 9 of 23 people (39%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 21
												As someone who discovered the previous games after playing this one. I can assure you this game is not worth buying. The game by itself is not bad. Decent gameplay, plenty of units, stats and items, nice music... However it just completely lacks the charm of its former titles.The 3d graphics are not an improvement, as Age of Wonders 2 and even the first Age of Wonders look much better and are more appealing. And the map editor is a buggy mess. You'll get crashes and world corruptions all the time.Age of Wonders 2 handled this better and in a more comprehensive way. The dev tools here are not user-friendly and require a beefy computer to handle. As for the character editor. Sure it's nice to have some variation, but it provides too little, and at a high price, since the characters look like something out of World of Warcraft. The previous titles offered a selection of portraits, which though limited, provided quality instead of quantity.The best+Good gameplay+Decent Campaigns+A large amount of spells, items and units+ModdableThe worst-Sacrifice quality for quantity in almost every aspect of the game-Map editor and dev tools feel like an unfinished product-Graphics Again, it's not a bad game and has a lot of unique innovative features, but it's way to expensive for what it offers. Better stick to the classics and enjoy countless hours of fun at a much more affordable price.

content:
Posted: June 17, 2015
												Such a disappointment. I have played over 500 hours and every race and class and came to the conclusion that this game is horribly poor in concept, Playability is lackluster at best and... enough said. The problems are:Poor unit balancingPoor Spell balancingAOW Shadow Magic is by FAR superior in concept and design. I had expected that AOW3 would be similar and I couldn't be more wrong. This newer format has serious problems. As a player in a game I wish to enjoy what I am indulged in.....which is playing in a fantasy game. I do not wished to be lectured by the Political Correct Police that my action to invade a town is an evil act and thus get scolded by negative race relation points.  I mean really?? I will give you an example: I am an Elf Druid (good). I fight a neutral city (orcs slighty good alignment) and win. My reward is poorer racial relations with orcs and a drop in my stading to slightly good.Do yourself a favor get AOW Shadow Magic and don't purchase this abomination.

Posted: January 26, 2016
												I loved this game.  I love epic single player turn based war games.  But the developers have ruined AoW3 with patches for the single players.  The capitals start far too close, the game has become a 30-50 turn slug fest just like multiplayer.  It basically caters now to multiplayer and all sense of long games has been destroyed.  The map selection aspects are pointless - you can select capitals to be FAR apart and they end up a few turns from each other (this used to be different with them being equally spaced around an extra large map but the devs changed them so they are grouped together and most of the map is empty space.)SO if you are into multiplayer - get this game.  If you are into quick single player - get this game.  If you like epic long games - don't get this game - the devs have ruined it.

content:
Posted: April 7, 2014
												I purchased this based on the hype online, expecting some sort of engrossing strategy experience to draw me in for weeks, months, years. In reality it's just not all that enjoyable. It's not HOMM3, it's not Civ, it's not Total War, it's certainly not King's Bounty, it's less appealing to me than HOMM6. It's a very slow paced, boring game with dull graphics. I've sunk more than 30 hours into it over about two or three days and I've got very little enjoyment back from that. It's possible that with time I'll grow to like it, but it's certainly not what the Internet hype machine is saying about it.If you're looking for something to fill a HOMM/King's Bounty sized hole in your life then this isn't it. Might be worth checking out in a few months if the price has dropped and the game has been improved & rebalanced.

												I loved this game at first, but it lost interest fast. I wish steam had a better rating system cause I would probably rate this 6/10, it's worth buying if you are fine with a couple hours of multiplayer fun.But however, it is absolute garbage as a multiplayer game, unless you like games that take days or weeks to complete.  Manual combat stops everything in the game, and forces other players to just sit there and watch or wait, you wont be able to do anything else. The devs were asked a lot to fix this and their response was "There was no tricks they could do to change this without changing the essence of the game itself", so apparently the essence of their multiplayer is to bore people out of their minds. The games take so long they even have an option to E-mail you when it's your turn.My other mainj issue with this game is difficulty settings. As someone who always plays on hardest mode for a challenge, I love a challenge, but there is a big difference between smarter AI and just giving them a big hammer to smash you with. This game opted the lazy way out and gave them the big hammer. Hard mode? Sure, we will give the computer units that take an entire army to kill, who can jump over castle walls, AOE instakill your entire army, and while we are at it, we will increase their resistances till the point your best units can only take out 5% of their life per turn, and then increase the computers damage to do 200% of your best unit's health in damage per turn. Enjoy.

content:
Posted: February 25, 2015
												Big long-time fan here of the Age of Wonder series. Still have them all.AOW1: awesome. runs on my old laptop so when I travel, nice to pull-up and play, map-editor rocked.AOW2: worst of the series, story stucked, mechanics sucked, bugs, glitches, clunky, weak, lame.AOW: Shadow Magic: Best of the series, stand-alone expansion, basically, super-fixed all the problems with AOW2s very well and a total classic. Map Editor rocks the house.AOW3. The New One. With other series pushing ahead with the fantasy/4x-style games, it made sense for Triumph to go back and make a sequel. Immedicate CON: total lack of story, not cutscenes, totally DOA in this department but the gameplay itself more than makes up for this. It's more going towards a "Civilization" 4X style of gameplay, like AOW:SM introduced to the series. NO PROBLEM WITH THAT!!!!Sadly gone are the "Wizard Towers" and the treasure trove of spells to troll any invaders into your domain.Gladly gone are roaming independent/allied units that take over parts of your domain without any resistence.Gladly gone are the over-powered doman spells that royally pwn any army that accidently enters your demain under peaceful circumstances.Like the prior games, they push the graphics envelope a bit. However, this game does so most unfairly. Let me explain: This game runs like crap on newer systems even. It turns my CPU into a hamster wheel with Hamster-Cyborg 3000 running on it. What the hell. No time to optimize? The graphics are NOT EVEN THAT GREAT, they look about 5 years behind the times AT LEAST and this crap can chug at times. Solution: turn everything down, still looks okay, but so very disappointing. Lazy programming? Who knows.Gameplay, if you liked AOW:SM, the the exception of the loss of wizard towers and a few minor things, you will feel right at home. Improved style of tactical combat mode looks great, it is nice. I hated AOW2 and AOW:SM removed all the blood/minute gore of AOW1. Same crap here, it's homogenized for you and your 5 kids in your nuclear family. I suppose that was to appeal to the kids who like The Hobbit and LOTR because there are art decision that seemed inspired by those movies, in my opinion. A bit too much in fact.On that note, it seems about half of the races in the prior AOW:SM are totally gone.No more nomads, or Archons (they are Undead now) but the "Undead" race is fully gone, so are the Shadow and those other guys that like the Shadows guys, no Dark Elves or offshoots, it all feels rather sucky now.I KNOW, probably because at some point they plan to go the DLC route and play those stupid tricks/games with their fanbase. Time will tell, eh? Whether that's the case or not: BRING BACK THE OTHER FAAUKKING RACES PLZ!So overall, it feels like a graphically amplied, but stripped down version of AOW:SM. It makes improvements, here, there, and overall I recommend it. It is a trusted, trial'd, true fantasy strategy game, with 4X elements because you can build new cities and grow them CIV-style. My complaints are not that big in the grand scheme of this game. I wish there was more options, more choices, and the engine was optimized which I think is far given the aging graphics. There is more to like than to not like, and to list what I like would make this 2 pages more. Last note, it's a "complicated" game like CIV 4, so don't expect detailed diplomacy AT ALL or too much detail in anything. It is rather simple on many levels but can be very rewarding and dynamic in its own right.

number of helpful: 5 of 16 people (31%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 3, 2014
												It's better than I feared, but it's worse than I hoped.I really hope patchs fix this game.NOT DLC OR EXPANSIONS, because ♥♥♥♥ you for making me pay you to fix your broken game.Yes the environment looks great, fantastic even.Characters are well modeled and well posed.Hair is completely awful.Clothing/armor textures are very blurry and low res.AA is broken.Yes, these are on highest settings.Tactical maps are unbearably small, it takes 2 turns for the enemy to engage your front line. Furthermore, ranged units have abysmally low hard limits on range (about 1 turn of a melee unit), whereas Shadow magic handled range quite well with soft limits via accuracy penalties.There is no longer a height advantage to be gained for ranged units as tactical maps are nearly all perfectly flat, and they can even hit units behind giant boulders at reduced damage, whereas the previous AoW games would've laughed at you for attempting such a thing.You cannot manaually place your own units or even rearrange their positions.6 units MAX, seriously?Most magic is in the form of global passive spells now (which are incredibly easy to research, cast, and dispel). Tactical magic is practically worthless now and all boils down to "do damage by throwing X", where X is whatever element your specialize in.MOUNTAINS ARE TRAVERSABLE BY ANYONE. Seriously, who thought this was a good idea? Mountains used to be natural roadblocks, and every faction and their own unique ways of dealing with them; flying units, transport units, tunnelers, terraforming, etc. Now they're just speedbumps.Terrain costs are a joke, harsh terrain is so easy to move on now that roads are hardly neccesary, whereas before they usued to nearly double your range, even on already good terrain, now they merely increase it by 20-30%.Research is much too fast, and much too linear. You used to be able to branch out and pick and choose want you wanted, now you're restricted to linear paths, and even some things are research for the sake of accessing more research.AI becomes incredibly passive on large maps, on every difficulty setting.Independant cities are practically desperate for you to take them over since they hand out quests like candy (completeing the quest gives you their city), now they're no longer bastions of death that are difficult and rewarding to take over.Every faction is homogenized: everyone gets a cavalry counter, everyone gets a handful of ranged units, everyone gets one tanky unit etc. No one has unique mechanics anymore like packing up your cities and moving them, spreading death as your city expands.Cities themselves don't specialize anymore, now every city can be just as good as every other city, since they don't get bonuses from gods and buildings are extremely quick to build. Hoorrraaay everyone gets gold stars for participation :), ♥♥♥♥ specialization am I right guys?

content:
Posted: November 11, 2015
												I really wish i could give a thumb up for this game, but i just can't. The first couple of days was amazing and i especially loved the music as the old tunes forged together with the new elements and preserved something from the first game's atmosphere. After a good start the game is run out of steam as slowly the weakness are surfacing. Borrowed elements  from the great classic Master of Magic, but not enough just to borrow the good ideas.First i would like to mention of the Heroes. There is miserably lot of ways to develop their skill and on the end they are not worth much more than another stronger units. Except catch the bullet first on the battlefield because if the battle won they newer die.Next is on my list is the fortifications. The purpose of them is to be able to protect a place with a small force against a much bigger, and that will not happen in this game. Maximum garrison is the only effective way to repel attacks, or it supposed to but the enemy is always up to date about my under defended cities and ready for action.You would expect a massive metropolis able to support all the building and an army. It won't.The AI is irrational, sometimes set back and pathetic, other times  too good and to beat it you have to wait until it make a mistake.The map design is not always work out as the creators wanted, and cause difficult situations. This list can go on longer on smaller unrefined thing and bugs during the play. Like why an army have to appear like ragtag on the battlefield and spend turns to set up a proper formation. Or why the spells and tehecs are mixed in the book when i chose the next research and so on...Now i have to say the game is good but not good enough for a veteran who played AoV in the past. If you see it on sale around 10€ you should consider to buy it and it will keep you busy for 3-4 days hopefully. The current 30€ is just too much pain for the fun.

content:
Posted: September 27, 2014
												Age of BlundersLike the other reviewers have pointed out, you need to rush to tier 4 units!  The combat is very basic, you never miss, very short ranges and you get  less units then AoE 1 and 2.  I really think the developers were going for a faster MP style game play.  That explains the rush feel, however this is terrible for the single player and does not feel like you have time to explore.   The enemy spawns in  areas that you knew you cleared out and there is no path for  them. If you  leave one of your cities empty it will get taken over without a fight.   Walls are useless now because most units have wall climbing.  This game is frustrating not because it’s hard but because the rush feel and the cheap spawning city attacks.   The graphics are just ok, but some units are hard to see against the background as well as some of the places to visit.  Over all I’m disappointed

content:
Posted: September 15, 2015
												Game has become exceptionally boring compared to the previous games where all units had a purpose and could still be useful during the late game. After turn 50 all the heroes in AOW3 become useless and the only units to produce are the T4 units which overwhelm all other armies including heroes. Diplomacy made far more sense in the previous games of the series with like minded empires allying with one another. The AI in AOW3, specifically the absolute good, empires will declare war just to conquire the player, if the players armies are weak, which goes against the entire premise of what it means to be good. The graphics in the game are nice but due to the extremely simplistic AI and the focus on making single focused armies the game becomes nothing but an attrition combat game where all the tactics/combat and armies are exactly the same. This game is boring.

The whole point of this review is to simply say that I am saddened that this company has gone the way of the paid DLC.  The stupidity of the people unfortunately has allowed this to thrive to what it is today.  The simple fact that companies release games that are "incomplete" just to release a paid addition (that was already complete at the time of release) a few months later, is just sad.  I truly miss the days that you could pay money for a complete game. ... Age of Wonders I: 12 Races, all released at inception.-I will not buy another product from this company, nor will my friends.

number of helpful: 1 of 9 people (11%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 16, 2015
												Hello everyone!I've just finished both campaigns in the game where I could use all classess. I have mixed feelings: dissapointment and enjoy. I have to mention that I am a fan of HoMM 3 Universe and never played games like AoW before. So, here are positive moments (in my opinion):- using several armies in the battle at once; - nice differences between races and armies with their own strong and weak points;- good soundtrack;- authentic Universe.Negative moments:- it could be strange, but I didn't understand how to use all armies you want. For ex, I surrond my enemies city, attacking with my 3 armies, but why it is showing that can use only 2 of them. Maybe this is lack of my skill;- on one hand, you have nice variety of units, on the other, you don't have enough time to produce the strongest ones. The tactics is simple in that way, use your default army and try to capture resources around your base, saving before and after every battle, earning promotions for your fighters. Using this tacs you have to destroy your opponent using 1-3 lvl units, because you don't have enough time to develop and produce the strongest. AI will do it much faster. AoW III has it's own unique style, but whenever I played this game I always had a feeling, that it was still raw. There is lot work to do, especially in balance. In this present condition of this game I can't recommend it.

content:
Posted: May 24, 2015
												Cannot recommend this. It is neither as simple and smart as its predecessors nor is it very elegant.1) The economics/strategy layer is way off balance 2) the single player missions are horrible (by the very first mission you're in control of a thousand cities and all races of the game, and it just gets worse. It's basically the same mission over and over again).3) The combat system we all know and adore is there, But the most fun parts are gone... You can no longer assault a city from several directions. It's just one long battle line now...4) Extremely stupid design decision took all the focus away from the races and now it's "classes" instead. So what race you are matters very little. There's hardly any differentiation beyond a few ability scores here and there. It is NOTHING like AOM2 where every race was completely distinct in almost everything.In short, this is not as good as the one before it, so how could I recommend it?

number of helpful: 2 of 13 people (15%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 16, 2016
												So, here is my story:I got the game as soon as it was released. Any multiplayer game - I wasn't interested in singleplayer from the start (never ever played campaign) - ended with the runtime error during battles or crashes between turns.I had decided not to bother developers personally, as I wasn't the only one (Steam forums were full with "This p2p does not work!"), so I waited, and while I was waiting I had decided to gift this game to my neighbor (man got a grade in chess, so it was a desperate doing).2 months of waiting - same as ever. And 4 months later they've released Golden Realms DLC as their project claimed to be "total success"...No need to say it's useless to buy just the base game: people with DLC got adidtional skills even for base factions, at least they had when it was released. It's not even close to the competitive play.What about connection? I got some issues when playing through Steam in other games, yes, but not with the man I share the same Inthernet (only 2 exceptions up to the date, AoW is one of them).If you going to buy this game, buy it with DLC's. And ask other people on forums beforehand: how exactly the connection is in your region and even with your provider. No one would play with you if they would know you are crashing the game (sooner or later they would).Otherwise, it's pretty good game.And if you want to ask about my 37 hours, here is the answer: like 16 hours were spent on training (it's not very polite not to know the basics), 10 hours on afk (it's pretty slugish to play alone), the rest goes for crashes, accusations of how noob I am (some people think you are ctrl+shift+esc the game, even if a battle was won by you, morons), unfruitfull reconnections. Not the best proportions.

content:
Posted: June 16, 2014
												To me, this game is completely lame. Seeing the graphics, I felt as if I fell back through time into 2000 (or earlier). Awful. Seeing the gameplay, and lots of the "story" texts accompanying the units - well, in most games, it brings some level of immersion (if not useful information), here, it is just excessive "information" garbage. Completely unrelated to anything ingame, just some "random xy character" telling some "story" (could even be my aunt...)As for the customisation of the avatar - 3 clothes? Really? (Checking the year again) Looks of all the races - am I the only one who thinks they all look like ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥? Really?Tech trees - with no invention whatsoever. That's where I felt disappointed most. Actually, no... I got disappointed everywhere in this game...Ingame information - it is there, but you can access it only AFTER you start the game. Why cant you see what type of terrain Goblins like/dislike before picking them, for example? Or anything else, for that instance? Why don't I see what skills will picking air or fire or anything bring me? Besides of most of the skills being absolutely useless, or all of them being absolutely useless for certain types of characters? Why do I have to learn about this after I start playing? Also NO MANUAL?!?! Like, at all?!Anyway. Comparing this "sequel" to the AoW II - it fails completely. I am really sorry I bought this game. Played it for a week, gotten bored immensely, not only by the really "pulp fiction" story, but by the scenarios, by the random maps even! Awful!If I could get my money back, I would, trust me. Blerg. Way overpriced, should have gone right to Good Old Games, only it would be Lame Old Games.0% fun

number of helpful: 1 of 11 people (9%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 22, 2014
												*Sigh* where to begin... The game is garbage in every sense of the word, there is so much wrong with it I can't list every thing all at once but I can list some of the major issues.Difficulty is a joke, the lowest difficulty is full of♥♥♥♥♥♥and if you don't out tempo it ( IE don't play Necro) it will steam roll you.  How you say? well timmy let me tell you.  The AI gets so much extra bs it is unfair even at Squire (lowest) setting, it expands very fast and the AI cheats to get damn near every extra attack (you can get up two 3) AND is damn near immune to every form of debuff (ie I cast dispel several times and it resisted).  The units are full of♥♥♥♥♥♥as well, I took two forces max of 6 with a mox of tier 1,2 and 3 against a unit with 6 (it had two heros and some tier 1 and 2 units) and I walked away with only 4 people my main hero included which to me is bs.  Water combat is very flawed and you can and will be crushed if you come to the fight unprepared, NO♥♥♥♥♥♥I hear you say well when you have archers, some good tier 3 units and powerful spells yet still unable to take one whole force of like 6 guys vs your 8 then there is a major issue.  Counter attacks suck nuts in this game due to wimpy units being beast sometimes when counter attacking and I feel that is beyond wrong.  I can't tell if the roaming units of mercs basically target the enemy AI but so far I have not seen it and imho if they do not then that is also a major flaw and you are hindered entirely to much to have them on, unlike Civ V where the barbs bug the living hell out of every one else.  The is a lot more I wanted to put here and I will add it as I remember or encounter it but over all for a 4X type of TBS I would not recommend this to any one, the DLC that adds Necro and Tigeran or w/e is kinda cool but the base game is to crap to make it worth the 20 bucks.

number of helpful: 2 of 14 people (14%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 9, 2016
												The basic problem with this game is the lack of balance for roaming / random forces.  The game starts with those units in camps around the map.  But even on easy level, these camps / bands will quickly grow in strength, often faster than you can grow.  And the AI of the other empries is to stupid to try and do anything about the camps.  What that eventually leads to is you slowly defeating some AI empire, and then out of nowhere a large random high level monster group comes rumbling, stumbling in to crush you.  Amazing how they did nothing to the AI player but only attack once you control the city and area.  But I guess if they did attack the AI they would wipe them out -or- the AI would wipe them out leaving no roaming bands later in the game.  And this is all on the easiest of levels.  When you try higher levels, these camps quickly start pumping out forces you can-not-defeat.  All in all a very frustrating game.

content:
Posted: July 31, 2016
												Well what we have here is yet another sequel to a venerated serie in TBS genre that falls flat on it's face. I'm starting to think that the whole genre is dying off, with the few games that manage to come out, all being subpar experiences. Only the most fanatical TBS players would enjoy this glass of wheat flavored water. Game introduces you to host of different races that all function almost identically to one another, nice reminder when back in the day games could pull off just reskinning same units and calling them with different names. Combat being the only thing differentiating this from all the other run off the mill TBS games, but you'll be autocombatting in no time just to save you from the tedious exercise in futility of spending any more time playing this bland game.The game is boring, it feels like it was made by small indiestudio and finishing a game leaves you with bitter taste regret. You'll wind up wondering when did your life become so♥♥♥♥♥♥that you'll willingly waste hours on end trying to find out what happens in the story that appears to have been added in as afterthought.Even taxidermist couldn't capture the cold dead eyes of this game. Game that stands as a tombstone to once great and thriving genre of classics. If you wan't better use for your 30 euros, take them out as 10cnt coins and dump them in middle of intersection near some elementary school and watch the ensuing chaos.

number of helpful: 10 of 35 people (29%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 2, 2014
												After playing it long enough to see a city fully upgraded and pull out all the new troops; it goes by fast if you know how to build up right off the bat. I can say this is a great standalone revamp of the game, but I wouldn't recomend it for full price, unless your really acking for a fast paced turn based that thinks its an RTS made by blizard.The class system isn't bad, but minus the new graphics it could have easily been a cheap standalone expansion for the old ones. If you use the same tactics you did in the past games this will be rather easy to play, with a few momments of 'look at that" when you see one of the class system units fight the first time, then it will be just another unit to use, some of wich will have vets going "didn't that use to be part of some other race?"Its ok novelty experince, but at its core its easier to play, wich is a plus I guess, but I didn't expect it to get more simple considering the first one came out when I was freshman in high school, and picked it up rather fast for a first time turn based strat.
